editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: John Owen's LATINE EPIGRAMS Englished By THO. HARVEY, Gent. Dedicated By the Author Mr. John Owen unto the Lady Mary Nevil, Daughter of the Earl of DORSET.

q.p: Nec verbum verbo curabis reddere— Horat. de Arte Poet.

div.p: Licensed May 25. 1677. Roger L'Estrange.
LONDON, Printed by Robert White, for Nevil Simmons at the Sign of the Prince's Arms in St. Paul's Church-yard, and Thomas Sawbridge at the three Flower de Luces in Little-Britain. 1677.
THE LATINE EPIGRAMS OF John Owen, LATE One of the Fellows of New Colledge in OXFORD.
Rendred into English by Thomas Harvey, Gent. Once a Commoner in the Colledge at Winchester; Both Colledges being Founded and Indowed by William Wickam, heretofore Bishop of Winton, in Anno Dom. 1389.
Anno 120. Richardi secundi Regis Angliae.
Dignum laude virum Musa vetat mori. Horat.
LONDON, Printed by Robert White, for Nevil Simons at the Sign of the Prince's Arms in St. Paul's Church-yard, and for Thomas Sawbridge at the Three Flower-de-Luces in Little-Britain. 1677.

div.head: To Mr. Thomas Harvey upon his Translation of Owen's Epigrams.
div.l: VVHo could divine a Branch so old could bring
Such specious Blossoms as might suit the Spring
Of youths best Fancy? for here stand at vye
The Cream of wit, and Oyl of Industry.
I wonder how this English Muse could sink
Into Owens depths, into each hole and chink
Of his hid sense: Sure All thy year is May,
And owns no darkness; For I needs must say
When I read Owen, I conceiv'd each part
Of his Laconick Epigrams so smart,
So sharp, so short, so comprehensive, that
No English Genius could it adequate.
Pardon my Country, that my Thoughts so rov'd
And undervalu'd Thee; For here 'tis prov'd,
An English Pen makes That inventive Brain,
For all its intricate Conceits, so plain
That now each Epigram, each Riddle lies
Anatomiz'd to All unclouded eyes.
His Criticismes dissected and made bare,
And so Diaphanous, that now They are
(Although not word for word, yet sense for sense)
Unriddled, and with such quaint Eloquence,
That as I read Both, I could swear almost
That Harvey's Muse consulted Owen's Ghost;
For but Compare Them, and you'l censure, that
Harvey hath hit what Owen aimed at.

div.head: To Mr. Thomas Harvey of his Englishing Owen's Latine Epigrams.
div.l: SMooth Ogleby for Virgil; Sandys won
The Garland, what for Ovid he hath done.
And Martial's Epigrams hath Fletcher drest
In English Garb: Horace is so exprest
By divers Persons, eminent for worth
•• genious Brome (deceas'd) did set them forch.
But as for Owen's Epigrams, there's none
As yet, hath vent'red a Translation,
But only Harvey; and He Mantuan thus
Hath made most happily conspicuous.
The Sun's unclouded now, what Owen writ
In shadowed mysteries of Roman wit,
His de • t'rous hand Translated hath, and Pen'd
That • h •• h none yet attempted, f • w can mend.

div.head: Of the same.
div.l: OWen compos'd, Harvey Translated well;
The question's, which of these doth most excell?
The answer in few words is quickly done,
Which like you best the Shadow or the Sun?

div.head: To the Book.
div.l: OWen had many Patrons, I have None:
None that will be my Patron, no, not One.
None that to Me will give a Quire of Paper,
Nor Pens, nor Ink, nor a poor Farthing Taper.

lg.l: THough I These Epigrams which Owen writ
Have done int' English, Thou must not expect
Like quaint Conceits, like Criticismes of wit
In the Translator, as in th' Architect.
For in their Idiome and Dialect
Each Language diff'rent is, as man from man:
One from Another differs in Aspect,
In Nuture, in Condition; nor Can
Translations with th' original hold weight;
In sense They may Consent, not in Conceit.
But take't as 'tis, and with a Candid Eye
Read, Ruminate, Remember and apply.
MIne English Owen Patron-less did pine,
Wanting an Heros, or an Heroine
To Potronize It: Almost in despair:
Until a candid Nymph (Mecaenas heir)
Not willing Papers fitted for the Press
Should be suppress'd, became my Patroness.
IN rendring mine, with Owen, parallels,
I am like One than rings or Chimes the Bells;
If I do jangle (venidl's the sin)
It is to soule a better Ringer in.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.l: A. Clerick art? or Laick? read This Book;
Here Thou shalt find thy will, if well Thou look.

div.head: 2. To D. John Owen of his Book.
div.l: What hinders, but thy Book should pass the Press?
If I know Verse, This Age will say no less.
Suppose not, so great hazard's of thy wit:
Yet This my judgement is, I think it fit.

div.head: 3. To John Owen of his three Books of Epigrams.
div.l: Results of Love, the Graces effluence,
The Muses mirth, Apollo's Eloquence,
Wise Sentences, and Criticisms of Art,
The Genius of an ingenious Heart;
All These Thy Book, O Owen, represents
Unt' us, replenish'd with rare Arguments.

div.head: 4. To John Owen.
div.l: Owen, dost ask what Epigrams w' approve?
Those, which That Engine of thy wit doth move,
What's short, chast, learned, quick, polite withal,
That many Satyres hath, yet free from Gall.
Thy Muse, thy Genius gives This; no less
By Thee 'tis promis'd to thy Patroness.

div.head: 5. In Praise of the Author.
div.l: What was, is, shall be still the Poets use,
Women and Men are Censur'd by thy Muse:
Yet in my Judgement, thy rare wit, thy Pen
Deserveth Praise of Women and of Men.

div.head: 6. To the Reader, in Praise of the Author, whose Epigrams were published the second Time within a Month 1606.
div.l: Greek, Latine Authors, Epigrams have writ,
Whose Work took up their Life to finish it:
Owen except, he sole unparallel'd,
Hath equaliz'd Them All, if not excell'd.

div.head: 7. Of the Third Edition of these Epigrams.
To the Author.
div.l: This Book is like the world, moves, and is mov'd:
Though silent, It is by the Printer prov'd:
For These thine Epigrams have had Access
Thrice to the Printer, and half tir'd the Press.

div.head: The First Book.
To the Lady Mary Neville.
div.l: I Dedicate, lest Patron-less It be,
My Book to th' Reader, and My Self to Thee.

div.head: 2. To the Reader.
div.l: The Folly's blam'd, if Thou Commendest all
That here Thou readest, no Thing if, thy Gall.

div.head: 3. Of his Book, to John Hoskins, a Lawyer.
div.l: This Book is as The World: as Men, The Verse:
Good Verses Here, as There good Men, are scarce.

div.head: 4. To the Lady Mary Neville.
div.l: If us Pythagoras doth not delude,
Thou, Juno, Pallas, Venus, dost include:
For in Thee, though but One, Three vertues be:
Where, One of Them is rare, in other Three.

div.head: 5. To the same.
div.l: As in the Skies the Sun, i' th' Sun the Light,
So vertue's splendor in thy Face seems scite:
Who comes a Looker on; becomes a Lover:
Thy Vertue, or thy Beauty's the sole Mover.

div.head: 6. To her Son Thomas Neville.
div.l: Such rare Things of thy Genius are Pen'd,
That though All true, they All belief transcend.
Hope in a Child, not present Worth, is prais'd:
Thee present Worth, not Hope alone hath rais'd.

div.head: 7. To her Daughter Cecily.
div.l: Thou like thy Mother art, and needst none other
Applause: It is enough, th' art like thy Mother.

div.head: 8. Know thy Self. Of Harpalus.
div.l: Thou worthy to be known art not of worth:
Fit for thy knowledge then seek something forth.

div.head: 9. To a Lawyer.
div.l: If happy's he who knows of Things the Cause:
How happy thou Cause-Pleader with Applause?

div.head: 10. Of John Prote.
div.l: To lead a Wife, that is, to marry One,
Oft hast Thou menac'd; Drunkards can do none:
Rather a Wife must marry Thee, to lead
Thee drunken from the City to thy Bed.

div.head: 11. To Aulus an ignoble Noble-man.
div.l: Thou to thine Ancestors ow'st All: to Thee
Posterity shall not indebted he.

div.head: 12. To Hernicus.
div.l: Thou bought'st a Fool for Twenty Pounds, but I▪
Will not at such a price the Buyer buy.

div.head: 13. Of Venus.
div.l: Love's first Sweet's better; bitter is in Fine:
Venus comes smiling, mourning doth decline;
So run fresh Rivers to the Sea, whose Taste
Returns Them brackish-brinish at the last.

div.head: 14. To Mr. Gilbert.
div.l: Thou th' Earth denyst to stand: prodigious Note,
Thus writing, Thou perhaps wert in a Boat.

div.head: 15. To Physicians and Lawyers.
div.l: Galen, thine Health doth from our sickness rise;
Justinian, our Folly makes Thee wise.

div.head: 16. O Times, O Manners!
div.l: Learn'd Scaliger The Worlds deformed Times
Reformed: Who shall Now reform Mens Crimes?

div.head: 17. Paris his judgement.
div.l: When Paris was elect a Judge to be
Between Three Goddesses, and of the Three,
Doubtful which to preferr; Pallas was wise,
Juno majestick: Venus wan the Prize.
Love Conquer'd All: were't now to vote again,
One money'd Juno would the Prize obtain.

div.head: 18. Germanical Truth.
div.l: Democritus affirm'd that Truth was drown'd
In some profound Abyss, not to be found.
If hid in Wine, as Proverbs have assign'd,
The Teutons have It found, or will It find.

div.head: 19. To Linus.
div.l:
Thou, Linus, hast Books.
Labrorum store, but more

Wouldst learned be Pounds.
Librarum hadst such store.

div.head: 20. To a certain young Noble-man.
div.l: Old Age, not Death's Thee wish'd: the Sickness; Age,
Not Death, the Cure, is wish'd Thee by the Sage.

div.head: 21. To a certain poor Physician.
div.l:
Thou that of late A Beggar.
Mendicus cam'st to Town,

Thy Name but changing A Physician.
Medicus art grown:
Physick Thou giv'st the Sick, he gives Thee Coin,
Thus his Disease Thou curest, and he Thine.

div.head: 22. Of a certain Woman.
div.l: Thy Form brought forth thy Fame: But O the Child
Did kill the Mother: fair Form; Fame defil'd.

div.head: 23. On Marcus.
div.l: In Nature why dost Vacuum. Emptiness deny,
Si • h in thine Head's so much vacuity?

div.head: 24. Upon modern Writers. To the Reader.
div.l: Whether the vulgar more untruths unmask
In Quart', Octav', or Folio dost ask?
In Sexto-decimo some Writers I
Suspect in ev'ry Folio to lie.

div.head: 25. Of Phillis.
div.l: Phillis, Thou wilt not give, but tak'st a kiss,
Knowing that taking One, a giving is.

div.head: 26. To the same.
div.l: If Love be Fire (as doth the Proverb prove)
Ah, woe to Me, how Cold a Fire's thy Love?

div.head: 27. A wicked Atheist.
div.l: Use present Times and Things: A Time will be
When there will be no Time at all for Thee:
Grammarians, Past, Future Times display,
But I will use the Present while I may.

div.head: 28. The Atheist's Epitaph.
div.l: He died, as if dead, no Life There were:
As if There were no Death, He lived Here.

div.head: 29. The Optative Mood.
div.l: Th' Infinitive is near th' Optative Mood,
For Infinite's the wish of Goods or Good.

div.head: 30. Of Alana.
div.l: Wedlock to be th' intolerablest yoke
Alana cries all day: but doth revoke
When Night is come her Clamorous Regreet,
And saith, No yoke like Wedlock is so sweet.

div.head: 31. Prophets, Poets.
div.l: Prophets of Things to come the Truth predict:
But Poets of Things past write false and fict.

div.head: 32. Of Life and Death.
div.l: Life tends to Death, as Rivers to the Seas:
For Life is sweet, Death bitter, doth displease.

div.head: 33. Of Vulcan.
div.l: Vulcan made splendid Arms for Mars his Breast,
Mars gave unt' him a specious-spacious Crest:
Thou wert well paid O Vulcan for thy pains,
Horns for thine Iron; Were such Glaucus gains?

div.head: 34. An English Grammer.
div.l: The Feminine doth unt' It self design
What's proper to the Gender Masculine.

div.head: 35. Free Will.
div.l: Freedom of will, which is The worlds Contest,
Husbands have lost, but Wives have It possest.

div.head: 36. Of Life and Love.
div.l: Though ev'ry Action unt' its End doth tend,
Yet Life and Love abominate their End.

div.head: 37. The Elysian Fields.
div.l: Through Hells dark-dismal Cell A • neas walk'd
Into th' Elysian Fields, as Poets talk'd:
For when He shot Elisa's Gulph, who can
Deny, He was i' th' Fields Elysian?

div.head: 38. An Husband, and an Adulterer.
The Husband.
div.l: I have A wife, others her Love: so rather
For Others not Themselves Bees Honey gather.

div.head: The Adulterer.
div.l: This Seed I rais'd, but in Anothers Field:
So Birds for Others, not Themselves do build.

div.head: 39. New Rhetorick.
div.l: His Arguments, who Money wants, are sick:
Gifts Now, not words, are the New Rhetorick.

div.head: 40. Of Cotta lately made a Monk.
div.l: Cotta perplex'd with's wife a A Monks Hood. Cucule bought,
That dying He might die no Cuckold thought.

div.head: 41. Geneva's Arms.
div.l: Geneva in her Ensign doth display
Th' Imperial Eagle, and the Popedoms Key:
But how Geneva Them to keep dost hope,

Should The Emperour.
Rodolph claim his Bird, his Key the Pope?

div.head: 42. Upon the Trifles of Borbonius a Poet.
div.l: Thou Trifles thought'st not, what Thou so didst call:
I call Them not, but think Them Trifles All.

div.head: 43. Of Faith.
div.l: Not Faiths, but Faith is mention'd on Record:
For former Times did but one Faith afford.

div.head: 44. Of Paulinus a Physician.
div.l: Wherefore's a sick Man call'd thy Patient,
Sith He's impatient at thine Advent?
By suff'ring He's thy Patient, for He
Doth suffer more, than by's disease, by Thee.

div.head: 45. Of Cottula.
div.l: If what Apollo said of Socrates One be true,
Th'art Wise: Thou knowst, Thou Nothing knowst: Adiew▪

div.head: 46. Of Fabiana.
div.l: If Fields be fertile call'd that bear much Corn,
Then Fab'an's fertile; for she hath many born.

div.head: 47. A Joque upon Covetous Men.
div.l: The Vulgar, Nature pleas'd with little praise,
And on the Covetous a Scandal raise:
Yet sole the Covetous pleas'd with least we see;
Nature, Enough thinks little, Nothing He.

div.head: 48. To Philopater.
div.l: Though for Ones Country noble 'tis to die,
Yet nobler 'tis to live for It, think I.

div.head: 49. The World.
div.l: I' th' world's no Constancy; All's Circular:
What wonder Then no Rectitude is There?

div.head: 50. Of Aretinus.
div.l: In All Things there's a Mediocrity,
Excepting in the Thing call'd Venery:
Lust hath found out a Thousand means, with Art
To do, what should be done on Natures part.

div.head: 51. Of Silius.
div.l: Th'art Atheist: For Papist Thou mayst not be;
And to b' a Protestant disliketh Thee.

div.head: 52. Against Atheists.
div.l: No House doth want Its Lord; shall Then (alone)
This specious-spacious House the World have None?

div.head: 53. A Physician.
div.l: Physicians take Gold, but seldom give:
They Physick give, take none; yet healthy live.
A Diet They prescribe; the Sick must for't
Give Gold; Each other Thus supply-support.

div.head: 54. Of Lawyers
div.l: Lawyers are prudent, provident beside,
For prudently They for Themselves provide.

div.head: 55. A Courtier.
div.l: If good, Thou mayst be better, but not greater:
If great, more great; not better, nor compleater.

div.head: 56. To Marcus a Monoculist.
div.l: Thou Marcus wantst an Eye; Enough's one Eye:
Both Eyes may more, not better Things espye:
I have both Ears, but hear no Truth now told;
Both Eyes, but can with Them no good behold.

div.head: 57. Of Paulus.
div.l: Thou to preserve thy Fame, hast built thy Tomb:
As if that Tombs should not to ruine come.

div.head: 58. A Secret against Grey Hairs. To Bithynicus.
div.l: Lest in old Age thine hairs should silver'd be,
Thy youth hath made Thee bald: O happy Thee!

div.head: 59. Of Theodore.
div.l: Thou newly married didst think th' hadst found
A narrow Passage to the Starry Round:
But that New Passage led t' another Road,
T' a lower, not the strait way, but the broad.

div.head: 60. Of Apollo and the Muses.
div.l: The Muses Femes, Apollo's Masculine:
For One Apollo's worth the Muses Nine.

div.head: 61. Of Alanus, grown old.
div.l: His Cubit with's Wives Cubit measuring,
Alanus said, O sweet concubiting!

div.head: 62. The Calends of January. Of Olus and Quintus.
div.l: To th' Rich Ole gives not, lest his Gifts ask more;
Nor to the Poor, because Himself is poor.
But Quintus gives expecting by that shift,
For what He durst not ask, a better Gift.

div.head: 63. Of Pontia.
div.l: One wish'd All Cuckolds cast i' th' Sea; but t' Him
His Wife thus said, Learn (Husband) first to Swim.

div.head: 64. A work of Darkness.
div.l: 'Tis to preserve the Species of profit,
But th' Individuum's th' Opposer of it.

div.head: 65. Thou Lyest.
div.l: Beware, t' a Souldier give not the Lye:
He takes it for the great'st Indignity:
Ye that the Lye for such Disgrace esteem,
Why then to Lye so great a grace d'ye deem?

div.head: 66. Of an Hypocrite.
div.l: Thou wilt not swear, 'tis Sin: but thou wilt Lye:
Is this Religion or Hypocrisie?

div.head: 67. Androgynus.
div.l: Who Venus-like, and Mercury's in fight,
Nor Man nor Woman, 's an Hermaphrodite.

div.head: 68. Venus.
div.l: Love like the Sea doth flow, doth Ebb again:
What wonder? For Venus sprung from the Main.
No Trust's in Her, she's light; and plac'd (with Mars)
Among the Planets, not the fixed Stars.

div.head: 69. Of Rivals.
div.l: Each unt' himself would Phillis have, but There
Doth more of Envy than of Love appear.

div.head: 70. A Woman.
div.l: A woman from mans Womb was ham'd: but Eve
Did from Mans Bone, not Flesh, her Form receive.

div.head: 71. The Alliance of Physicians and Lawyers.
div.l: Physicians and Lawyers in their Trade
Are like, their gain of others loss is made.
To Patients Those, to Clients These apply
Their helping-hand, but help themselves thereby.

div.head: 72. Of Pamphilus to Philippe.
div.l: Nature doth no Vacuities admit:
Pamph' therefore as his Leader follows It.

div.head: 73. To one Bald.
div.l: Leaves to the Trees, and Grass returns to Ground:
But not one hair on thy bald pate is found.

div.head: 74. Nilus in the Eyes. Aetna in the Heart.
div.l: Cold Nilus entred hath my burning Eyes,
Mine Heart with Aetna's Flames inflamed fryes:
No Floods of Tears can quench so great a Fire,
Nor burning Love can make those Floods retire;
So though discording Fire and Water be,
Concording yet They shew their force in me.

div.head: 75. Caeteris paribus.
The rest alike.
Of Camilla.
div.l: • wo Suiters did Camilla love and Court;
The beautiful, in Stature yet but short:
That other not so fair, but taller prov'd:
The Maid b'ing ask'd which of them best she lov'd,
• he looking on the Taller, when she spies
• is Nose, Arms, Leggs, Feet, all of longest size,
• he thus, or Impudent, or prudent spake,
• f all he like, I will this long Man take.

div.head: 76. Of Gyants and Dwarfs.
div.l: Giants and Dwarfs are Monsters in their Forms,
Those are like Elephants, and these like Worms.

div.head: 77. Of an Abbat's two Bastards.
div.l: When in the Temple with the rest you pray,
You two, not fictly, Abba, Father say.

div.head: 78. Of Priests.
div.l: Priests wedded are: what thereby gain they more?
They had as much as that in Tenths before.

div.head: 79. A Participle.
div.l: A Verb if Eras, Mus a Noun's declin'd,
What is Erasmus let the Reader find.

div.head: 80. A Cuse. To the Lawyers.
div.l: A Man lies with a Wife, which is his own
Whom he suppos'd Anothers, till 'twas known:
Whether the Child by such mistake begot,
Be spurious, legitimate, or not?

div.head: 81. Of the Morning.
div.l: Dost wonder why the Light's expatiated
• th' Morn before the Sun? 'twas First created.

div.head: 82. Of the Day.
div.l: Though Night than Argus be more full of Eyes,
The Day's One Eye more clearly things descries.

div.head: 83. Of the Night.
div.l: Why doth dark Night put on her black Array?
It Widow-like mourns for departed Day:
Should not the Stars inlighten mourning Night,
Grief would oppress us e're the Mournings light.

div.head: 84. To Marcus.
div.l: Thy Verses praise Me, but I think because
I should thy Verses praise with mine Applause.

div.head: 85. Of Death.
div.l: Thieves shall restore their Theft, Robbers their Prey,
But Nothing Death; For Death takes All away.

div.head: 86. To his Friend.
div.l: Half of thy Dear, whom Thou dost dearly love,
Sith th' art, and Half thine own, how Mine dost prove
Yet writ'st thy self still Mine: while having thine
Own Wife, art scarce thine own, how canst be Mine?

div.head: 87. A good Man.
div.l: If what is Rare 's preclare, and of Account,
A good Man doth all Rarities surmount.

div.head: 88. Of a certain Old man.
div.l:
Thy Beard once black, Age hath made white: thy Min •
▪
Once white 's now black; once candid, now's unkind.

div.head: 89. Of Paulinus.
div.l: When I thy Friend a Boon from Thee would borrow,
Thine Answer is, It shall be done to Morrow:
Wilt that I Thanks condigne should Thee repay?
Thou shalt have Thanks to Morrow, not to day.

div.head: 90. Of painted Ladies.
div.l: You that your Faces paint, may well, nay must

With Hora ••
Flaccus say, We Shadows are and Dust.

div.head: 91. Of Cotta.
div.l: Thy Wives Thou Wholly, but not solely art:
She's solely Thine, not wholly, but in part.

div.head: 92. A Politician.
div.l: Dissemble, Feign: Thy Self comport-comply
With Humours, with the Times: 'tis Policy.
If Thou be wise, thy Self comply-comport
To serve the Times, that Times may serve Thee for't.

div.head: 93. Of Venus.
div.l: Why follows Venus Mars his lawless Flame?
Because t' his lawful Venus Vulcan's lame.

div.head: 94. Of Marinus.
div.l: None can Two Masters serve (without disaster)
But Thou Two Mistresses dost serve, no Master.

div.head: 95. Of Marcus.
div.l: 〈◊〉 Beard doth grow, thine hairs from head do fall:
••• ve bearded, but light-headed th' art withal.

div.head: 96. To Mr. John Hoskins.
div.l: •• en I convers'd with Thee (my Friend instil'd)

• outh at New Colledge in Oxford.
Oxon,
Winchester Colledge where the Scholars are called Children. Winton at a Child:
〈◊〉 without doubts, in doubts I found thy love,
〈◊〉 Friendship without Fraud I oft did prove:
〈◊〉 that thy Love, which then thou shew'd'st to Me,
•• mands, commends These grateful Lines to Thee.

div.head: 97. Of Death to Epicharmus.
div.l: •• y wouldst not die, but yet be dead? O why
•• uldst without dying, Epicharmus, die?
〈◊〉 of bringeth Death; Death Grief extinguisheth:
〈◊〉 therefore (Epicharme) is worse than Death.

div.head: 98. Of Phylllis.
div.l: 〈◊〉 Parthians in their Flight shoot, wound their Foe,
〈◊〉 Lovers, Phyllis fleeing, woundeth so.

div.head: 99. Of Hallus the Grammaticaster.
div.l: •• mous am while fasting, but when full,
〈◊〉 , saith Hallus, Infamous and dull.

div.head: 100. Of the Loadstone.
div.l: 〈◊〉 Court Magnates Gold to Them attract,
〈◊〉 on the Magnetes; All exact:
〈◊〉 not deal with Such, in Asking learn'd,
〈◊〉 Giving flack, in Taking most concern'd:
〈◊〉 to Them go, none from them come again,
〈◊〉 I nill ask them, lest I ask in vain.

div.head: 101. Of Death.
div.l: 〈◊〉 ask what's Death? till dead I know not Verè ,
〈◊〉 to Me then, I will resolve thy Quere. Certainly.

div.head: 102. Of Clients.
div.l: •• nts before a Thief run singing home,
〈◊〉 from the City Money-less they come.

div.head: 103. To Zoilus.
div.l: 〈◊〉 I bad Manners check, thou carp'st at Me,
• onscious for reprehending Thee.
Why fear'st thou more than others? I perhaps
Blaming bad Manners, blame mine own Relapse.

div.head: 104. Children and Fools tell Truth.
div.l: Our Proverb calls Truth-tellers Fools: What then?
Is't Folly to tell Truth in English Men?

div.head: 105. To one Bald-headed.
div.l: Thy Front had certain Measure, till a blast,
I know not of what Wind thy Leaves off cast:
Thy Front hath sithence All thine Head ingrost,
And is perpetual at last, not lost:
Thou canst not tell the largeness of thy Front,
No Trust is therefore to be built upon't.

div.head: 106. To the same.
div.l: Mine hairs I cannot number, 'cause so many:
Nor canst Thou number thine, because not any.

div.head: 107. Fortunes Apology.
div.l: Dame Fortune doth an equiballance bear,
Shee fills the Poor with Hope, the Rich with Fear.

div.head: 108. On Cotta.
div.l: Cotta the Stews advent'ring in, return'd

T' his house ('tis said) with something that was burn' •
▪

div.head: 109. On Procillus a Noble-man.
div.l: If thou to Lyers wouldst not lend thine Ear,
None with a Lye before Thee durst appear.

div.head: 110. To Paulus a Lawyer.
div.l: Between thy self and Wife thou dost disjoyn
The year, so that scarce Half is wholly Thine:
One part's thy Wives, Vacation call'd, t' apply
Thy Wives Vocation, or Vacuity.
That other part's not wholly thine; thy Bride
Neglected, Thou by Clients art employ'd.
This Part o' th' year the Term is call'd, and why?
Because It Terminates thy Venery.

div.head: 111. To the same.
div.l: No Terms determine, no Vacation's vain,
Thou wholly Vacant art by Strifes to gain.

div.head: 112. To Marinus.
div.l: As oft as from the Bed thy wife doth rise
Untouch'd by Thee, her Nails assault thine Eyes:
Thou speak'st her Fair, but words in vain proceed,
She must be pleas'd in doing of the Deed.

div.head: 113. A Chirurgion.
div.l: Shall I wish Wars, or Peace? Each serves for me:
Fierce Mars, fair Venus, both my Patrons be.

div.head: 114. The Venetian disease.
div.l: My Country's Italy, my Parents Gauls,
'Tis doubt which of those Names to me befalls.

div.head: 115. Back-biters, Flatterers.
div.l: Anaxagoras. One said, The Snow was Black; an Author sad:
This Age hath Many seen as sad, as bad:
The Fox a Crow's white Feathers prais'd: Ah me,
How many Foxes in this Age have we?

div.head: 116. To Ponticus.
div.l: Thou said'st thou would'st repent: I scarce believe Thee,
For I did never yet so wise perceive Thee.

div.head: 117. An Herculean labour.
div.l: To tame a shrewd Wives Tongue, and haughty mind,
A Thirteenth Labour Hercules will find.

div.head: 118. Mars, Mors.
War, Death.
div.l: War bringeth Dearth, Dearth Death to Men on Earth;
War therefore's worse than either Death or Dearth.
Our Troubles War begins, Death finisheth,
In War small distance is 'twixt Dearth and Death.

div.head: 119. To Cynthia.
div.l: O that thy Feats were like thy Feature: And
O that thine Heart were candid like thine Hand.

div.head: 120. To Gellia.
div.l: In secret sins thou think'st thy self secure;
Though Nothing's done in secret that's impure.

div.head: 121. Of Albinus.
div.l: A Friend Albinus meeting, said, Retire,
Thine shakes, for O thy Neighbours Wall's on Fire:
Albinus hasting home, his wife did take
In th' Act; O Now, quoth He, my Wall doth shake.

div.head: 122. Of Claudius a Philosophaster.
div.l: Sick Claudius, poor, foolish, parts by's Art
Good in Three Parts; but of Them hath no Part.

div.head: 123. Of Bardella a Thief at Mantua.
div.l: A Monk the Thief Bardella judg'd to die
Thus Comforted, O thou shalt Sup on high:
Bardella then reply'd, I fast this day,
Please you to Sup There in my Place, you may.

div.head: 124. Of Flitting Flora.
div.l: In thy Coition thou didst boast thine Act,
Thy boasting was more sinful than thy Fact.

div.head: 125. Of Quintillus.
div.l: He nothing gives t' his Friend, but liberal
T' his Friendless, gives Himself, his Wealth, his All.

div.head: 126. To Aulus of old Quintius.
div.l: Though Quintius a young wild Wife did Wed,
Why sentst an Epithalamy t' his Bed?
An Epitaph were fitter to confer:
For his own Grave he digg'd in Bedding her.

div.head: 127. Of Costus.
div.l: Thou sinn'st impunely, but thy Fore-man paid
Thy Pennance with his Head: 'twas burn'd, 'tis said.

div.head: 128. An Answer to Cynthia's Letter.
div.l: Thy Paper's white, thy Letter's black within:
This doth denote thine Heart, and That thy Skin.

div.head: 129. To Sextilian a Bastard.
div.l: Not to Create Thee, but to recreate
Himself, thy Father thee begot ('twas Fate,)
If Givers Minds than Gifts b' accepted rather,
Thou dost not owe thy Life unto thy Father.

div.head: 130. Of Porcia an Hypocrite.
div.l: Thou, 'cause my Book a Fore-man Names, dost flout it:
Books Thou wouldst have, but not a Man without it.

div.head: 131. Of Saturns Three Sons.
div.l: Divines, Physicians, Lawyers; These Three
Do regulate the World in their degree.

div.head: 132. Of a single Life. To a Married man.
div.l: Woe to the sole, said Solomon, Eccles. He, that had a Wife:
Saint Paul doth much Commend a single Life:
A Welch Proverb, Gwelh iw gua • si, na gua ni, that is, Better is woe to me than woe to us. That, Woe unt • us, saith: This, but Woe to Me:
That's double, This, but single Woe can be.

div.head: 133. Of Corneus.
div.l: Hear, mark, be silent: he whose Feminine
Is wanton, to these three must most incline.

div.head: 134. Of Cajus.
div.l: When Cajus was accus'd of Bigamy,
Confessing, he professing did reply,
A Bishop Husband of One wife may be:
May not a Lay-man then have Two or Three?

div.head: 135. Of Pomponia.
div.l: She's punctual, her self that prostitutes:
Because with profit, pleasure she commutes.

div.head: 136. Of Pinotus sick with the Colick.
div.l: Thy Life was sav'd by breathing out thy Breath:
That was thy Life which proves unt' others Death.

div.head: 137. Of Pomponia.
div.l: A Plume of Feathers brave Pomponia wears:
What Mars his Ensign was now Venus bears:
As Mars his favour She doth wear't, that she
May shew how friendly Mars and Venus be.

div.head: 138. To H. L.
div.l: Thou lov'st thy Neighbours wife, he thine doth love:
So that ones own doth not still pleasing prove.

div.head: 139. Venus.
div.l: Sith Venus is expos'd to sale like Wine,
Why hangs there not before her door a Sign?

div.head: 140. To Marinus. Difficilia quae pulchra.
div.l: If difficult what's fair, on this Result
Take Facile thou, give me the Difficult.

div.head: 141. To Theodorus.
div.l: By th' now▪new Law thou maist not wed, what then?
By th' old thou maist without offending men
But twice 'gainst Levit. 21.7, 13, 14. Moses Law th' hast done amiss,
Thy first wife was a whore, a widow this.

div.head: 142. Ka'end. Jan To Germanicus.
div.l: Instead of Gifts I Verses send to thee:
Send Gifts instead of Verses unto Me.

div.head: 143. Sara.
div.l: She that her Maid would unt' her Husband give,
As did rare Sara, now doth rarely live.

div.head: 144. To D. T.
div.l: Thy Titles, Scholars Servant, Masters Lord,
Mine Envy and my Pity both afford.

div.head: 145. Of Paula an Atheist.
div.l: Whether a Man two Wives, or Husbands two
A Maid should have, 'twas ask'd: This knot t' undo,
Thus Paula said, A Maid two Men should have,
Else how can two consist in one Concave?

div.head: 146. In Medio virtus.
div.l: Between two Men a pompous Woman sate,
Vertue the middle Place hath lost of late.

div.head: 147. Of Acerra.
div.l: He's blest, whom others Horns have made afraid,
Unwedded A'cer oft t' his Father said.

div.head: 148. To Pinotus.
div.l: Dost ask, What I would have a Feminine?
Not Venale, Vendible I would have Mine.

div.head: 149. Of Quintus and Quintina.
div.l: Quintus his Wifes Intreaties for Commands,
Her words for Laws, her Beck for Statute stands:
She leads, she drives at will, the silly Sot,
As if she had an Husband, and had not:
'Gainst Nature, Laws, Arts Rules: Grammarian
Avaunt: For Here's He Woman, and She Man.

div.head: 150. A Paradox to his absent Mistress.
div.l: I burn with Love: And I the more am burn'd,
The more remote from me the Fire is turn'd.

div.head: 151. Of Paulina.
div.l: False to the First false to the second Bed:
Both void, She liv'd unblam'd-unblemished,
Not for the fear of Sin; but fear of Shame
Preferr'd Her without Blemish, without Blame:
Though many did her treat, did her intreat,
She granted unto none the Vacant Seat.

div.head: 152. Of Gellia.
div.l: If it be Simony to Merchandize,
And at a price Things consecrate to prize,
We well may call thee Simoniacal,
Who sellest Love, For Love's Spiritual.

div.head: 153. Of a certain Woman.
div.l: In small time how immense thy Things did grow?
Of late but Omicron, Omega now.

div.head: 154. Aenigma.
div.l: Tell where that Creature is, on Hill, or Vale,
Whose Father Female, Mother is a Male?

div.head: 155. To Ponticus.
div.l: That Both thine Eyes thou hast I wonder: Why?
Because thy Parents Each had but One Eye.

div.head: 156. Of D. Vitus.
div.l: I know not whether Horn'd, I know (by signs)
That th' art a Bull, having Three Vitulines.

div.head: 157. Of a Dactyle, to a certain Lover.
div.l: Wouldst with a pleasing Verse thy Mistris Court?
'T were fit to know what Feet should it support:
Of all the Measures which a Verse do summon,
The Dactyle Measure best delights a woman.

div.head: 158. Of Love descending.
div.l: From th' Eyes Love riseth, by the Mouth descends
Into Loves Center, where It hath it's Ends.

div.head: 159. Of Balba.
div.l: Balba, leave taking of her Spouse, said Thus
Phi-Philip you'l b' I hope soon-soon with us.

div.head: 160. Of Theft, a Problem, to Lawyers.
div.l: But what if's Lordess in that Act be Chief?

div.head: 161. Of Ponticus.
div.l: Of Promise thou dost no Performance make:
Physician-like, who gives not, yet saith Take.

div.head: 162. Of Cerellia, married to an Eunuch.
div.l: Now to the Spartane Customs I agree,
That Men, Maids, when they wed should naked be:
For Cerill having late espous'd a Frank,
Thiking to gain a Prize, got but a Blank.

div.head: 163. Of Horns, a Probleme.
div.l: When any Wife betrays the Marriage Bed,
Why wears her Husband Horns? Because he's Head.

div.head: 164. To Germanicus, Calend. Jan.
div.l: Or give m' a Gift, my Verses or restore,
Which I on that condition gave before.

div.head: 165. Christ-Church Colledge in Oxford.
div.l: Though this imperfect House to ruine tend,
Its large Quadrangle yet doth it commend.

div.head: 166. Of Phyllis.
div.l: Phyllis pretends my Verse her Fancy moves;
She loves a Verse, but something more she loves.

div.head: 167. Of Himself.
div.l: I spend the Time in Trifles, and in Folly:
Thus lest my Time be lost, I lose it wholly.

div.head: 168. To the Reader, of Himself.
div.l: My Brevity perchance seems Sloth t' imply:
Believe me no small labour, 's Brevity:
I not as some, speak much in foolish sort:
Perhaps my Speech is foolish, but 'tis short.

div.head: 169. Of boasting Thraso.
div.l: Why doth Sir Thraso wear great Spurs? Because
Glory doth wear great Spurs to gain Applause.

div.head: 170. Of Himself.
div.l: Ask, saith Saint James, it shall be given thee:
O that King James would say the same to me.

div.head: 171. Court Musick consisting of two Voices.
div.l: The Favourite's advanc'd, and Elah sings:
Another, all his Tunes t' a Cadence brings.

div.head: 172. To the Reader.
div.l: Lest this my Book should make Tobaco vapour,
Wipe rather thy Posteriours with my Paper.

div.head: 173. To his Book.
div.l: My Book, Me living, thou maist die perhaps:
What then? A Child doth oft to death elapse
Before his Father: So then, whether I
Survive Thee, or Thou me, We both must die.

div.trailer: The End of the First Book.

div.head: To Mr. Thomas Harvey on his Translation of the First Book of Owen's Epigrams.
div.l:
WHen what's begun, tha' ast finish't, Owen sha ••
▪
Be the Translation, thine th' original:
Thy Native Tongue the vigour doth express
More of his Fancy, than his Latine dress.
So from thy Version, he derives this Good,
To be esteem'd, in being understood.

div.head: THE SECOND BOOK OF THE EPIGRAMS OF John Owen.
div.p: Englished by Thomas Harvey, Gent.

div.head: 1. To the Reader.
div.l: LEst this my Book please Fools, whereof are Many,
I would not have It many please, if any:
Few Readers are enough, but One (if wise)
If none do read me, none shall me suffice.

div.head: 2. To the Lady Mary Neville.
div.l: The Praise of many's rais'd by Poets Art,
But all thy Praise springs from thine own desert.

div.head: 3. To the same.
div.l: Thou to thy Foes, if any be, dost will-
Dost wish none ill, to Friends art Candid still:
This one thou never dost forget: That other
Thou never didst remember, Maid nor Mother.

div.head: 4. To the same.
div.l: In Tables men fair Faces paint and place,
There to survive, when Fates the Face deface:
I cannot paint, but I can Poetize,
And Verses can give Life, when Picture dies:
Though sole Apollo, sole Apelles able's
Thee to describe in Verse, to paint in Tables.

div.head: 5. To D. J. H.
div.l: I am no learned Poet, but a Learner:
No Learner Thou, but Poets learn'd Discerner.

div.head: 6. What News?
div.l: The foolish People, as I pass the Street,
I •• uisitive, thus ask (when me they meet)
What News? I tell them I know nothing New:
Or if I knew, I say no News I knew.

div.head: 7. The Court.
div.l: He that complies not in the Princes Hall
With All the witty, hath no wit at all.

div.head: 8. Of Aulus.
div.l: Wert Knighted, that thy wise should love thee more?
She loves thee less, her self more than before:
Her Garb, her Garments must new fashion'd be,
So that thy Dear will be more dear to thee.

div.head: 9. Of the Chymist.
div.l: The Chymist Gold decocts, till (leaving none)
He loseth all his Gold to find a Stone.

div.head: 10. A Trojan.
div.l: Troy lost, at last the Trojans Wiser grew:
What man is not in this a Trojan true?

div.head: 11. Loves Remedy.
div.l: Take Wood from Fire (thy Lust with Fasting tame)
Sit from a Woman far, as from a Flame:
If nor the former cool thee, nor the later,
Then take a wife, she will b' instead of water.

div.head: 12. Troynovant.
To the Londoners.
div.l: As Phoenix Ashes do the Phoenix breed,
So from old Troy new London did proceed.

div.head: 13. The Lawyers Deity.
div.l: Rome had one God, call'd Terminus of old:
But Westminster more Terms than one doth hold.

div.head: 14. Of the Earth.
div.l: In all things we the Middle things commend,
For they to Mediocrity do tend:
Th' Earth therefore than the Skyes hath greater grace,
Because i' th' world it holds the middle Place.

div.head: 15. To King James, Defender of the Faith.
div.l: Thou greatest art of Christian Kings, in this
That to thy Faith the Faith committed is.

div.head: 16. To the Lord Treasurer of England.
div.l: Th' art Kings and Kingdoms faithful Treasurer:
Thy Faith before all Treasures I prefer.

div.head: 17. To the Kings Principal Secretary.
div.l: Thou secret keep'st the Kingdoms Secrets, even
So secret, that Faith to thy Faith is given.

div.head: 18. To the Venetians.
div.l: Your Cities Scituation (O wonder)
Is Founded unconfounded; th' Ocean's under:
Lest only Fish should in the water dwell,
Y' have seated in the Sea your Citadel:
Where th' Ocean was, a City's now compleat,
What Nature made a Sea, Art made a Seat:
Y' have constituted (to your grand Renown):
Th' Inconstant water constant to your Town:
What wonder then by Laws your City stands,
When it the lawless waters countermands.

div.head: 19. To the Lord Chancellour of England.
div.l: Lest Force the greatest Enemy to Law,
Should violate it, Law keeps Force in awe:
But thou the Laws Extreams hast pow'r t' abate,
And in the Chancery to moderate.

div.head: 20. To Richard Sackeville Earl of Dorset.
div.l: Though thou from Noble Ancestors wert born,
And dost thy Birth with Noble Parts adorn:
Yet thou (which was a wonder heretofore,
And for a Prodigy now stands, or more)
Merit to Mercenaries, Peace to War,
Vertue to Strength, Worth dost to Birth prefer.

div.head: 21. Caecil Treasurer of England 1597.
div.l: Arms are, and Stratagems of small concern,
If Caecil's Counsel sits not at the Stern:
Caecil and Atlas nobly both prognate,
This doth support the Skyes, and that the State.

div.head: 22. To Guil. Caecil: Virtut Duce, Comite Fortuna.
div.l: Great Queen Elisa Fortune made a Count,
Why Vertue did She not t' a Dukedom mount?

div.head: 23. To Richard Vaughan Bishop of London.
div.l: O, of the British Thou th' immortal Grace,
Art the First British Bishop of London. this Place.

div.head: 24. To the same.
div.l: I like those Preachers best, who Preach and Act;
Not those that only Preach but wave the Fact:
Thou therefore dost excell, for thou dost teach
What should be done, and dost what thou dost Preach.

div.head: 25. To Thomas Bilson Bishop of Winchester.
div.l: Bilson, I was thy Scholar heretofore,
And to thy Precepts owe these Lines, and more.

div.head: 26. The Life of William Wickham, formerly Bishop of Winchester, written in Latine by Thomas Martin, Dr. in the Civil Law.
div.l: Life to the Dead to give, the Dead to raise
From Death to Life, 's a Work deserving Praise:
Which hadst not done, thou Martin hadst been dead:
But now both in this one Book live, are read.

div.head: 27. Winchester Colledge.
div.l: Europes prime School: whereof a little Part
I was to my great'st praise in Learnings Art:
Zoilus himself will not to thee deny,
(Thy Founder Wickham known) this Primacy.

div.head: 28. To Sir Philip Sidney.
div.l: Great Alexander call'd Achilles blest,
Whom Homer prais'd in Verse above the rest:
Unhappy I, because thou half Divine,
Canst not made happy be by Verse of Mine.

div.head: 29. To Sir Philip Sidney.
div.l: Whose Deeds worth writing, Lines worth reading are,
Is Rare▪ Thou therefore doing both art Rare:
Thy Lines worth reading, Deeds worth writing shew
Thee learned, candid: equaliz'd by Few.

div.head: 30. Upon the Marriage of William Earl of Pembroke, and Mary, daughter of the Earl of Shrewsbury 1605.
div.l: In Manners, Personage, Wit, Age, Estates,
And in Nobility, you Both are Mates,
Yet thou deserv'st a better Bride than Shee:
A better Bridegroom She deserve than Thee.

div.head: 31. To Elizabeth Countess of Rutland, Sir Philip Sidney's Daughter.
div.l: 'Twas Philip's Praise thou wert his Child: But rather
Thine, that thou Daughter wert of such a Father.

div.head: 32. To Lucy Countess of Bedford.
div.l: Iury, thy splendid Name à Luce came,
That splendent through the World might be thy Names
Thy Noble Parents brought thee forth to sight,
But thee thy Vertues brought into the Light.

div.head: 33. A Knights Ring. To Henry Goodyeer, Knight.
div.l: Nobility the Gold, the Gem be Grace:
This Ring upon thy Finger ever place.

div.head: 34. To D. J. H.
div.l: Thy Verse is Nameless, though not worthless, while
Others their worthless Verse with Names instile.

div.head: 35. To D. B.
div.l: Thou livest well, if one well hid, well lives:
And thy great wit conceal'd more splendour gives.

div.head: 36. To Th. M. the Princes Tutor.
div.l: Thou so dost form, inform the Prince, that He
King of his Realms, and of Himself will be:
This Fifth to prize before those Kingdoms Four,
And of Himself, as well of them t' have Power.

div.head: 37. To Th. M. the Princes Tutor.
div.l: Thou so dost teach (for times of Sword and Gown)
The docile Prince, prime Hope of Britains Crown,
That scarce in future times 'twill be discern'd,
Whether He be more great, more good, more learn'd.

div.head: 38. To Walter Gwyn.
div.l: Th' Increase of the good Prince thou votest fair,
Nature gave Wit, may Grace attend his youth,
Grow may thine Honour with the Princes growth.

div.head: 39. Francis Drake 1581.
div.l: Thy Travels, Drake, have reach'd Earths utmost bound,
Have seen both sides of the Terrestrial Round:
If men be mute, the Stars will blaze thy Name;
And both the Poles will sound-resound thy Fame
Beyond Hercules Pillars. the Gades: Thou maist these words repeat,
I greater am than Hercules the Great.

div.head: 40. Britains Strength.
To the Prince.
div.l: Camp, Seas; Forts, Bodies; Hearts, the Generals.

div.head: 41. The Terrestrial Globe.
div.l: Of Water and of Earth's the Globe, (Sea, Land)
That movable, this unremov'd doth stand.

div.head: 42. Health, unhealthy.
div.l: The more thou drink'st of drunken Healths, the less
Of Health, of Happiness thou dost possess:
I wish a thousand of such Healths to thee,
And envy not: One Health's enough for me:
One Health's enough for sober men and sane:
No Health's in Drinking Healths, no Boon, but Bane.

div.head: 43. The Divine.
div.l: To know thine's nothing, if not known 'tis known.

div.head: The Politician.
div.l: If known 'tis nothing then to know thine own.

div.head: 44. All Things affect good.
div.l: From Opto's Optimus, without contest,
For he that's wise doth wish himself the best.

div.head: 45. A Phoenix on Earth.
div.l: A certain Maid of Burgundy surpriz'd
With Maiden Sickness, helpless and advis'd
To take a little Ment, an Herb, a thing
Helpful to many (taken in the Spring)
She rather than to live by sin, would die:
Death being all the Purchase sin did buy.

div.head: 46. Democritus, and Heraclitus.
div.l: That only laugh'd, this only wept: but whether
Shall be laugh'd at, or wept for? Both, or Neither?

div.head: 47. Of Langa.
div.l: Langa (she Papist) 'spous'd t' a Lutheran,
T' avoid contesting, thus to speak began:
Lest future Discords should disturb our Peace,
To me be facile, and I thee will please;
Grant me the Liberty of Conscience,
And with all other things I will dispence.

div.head: 48. King Arthur's Round-Table.
div.l: Why thy Round Table dost t' a Square prefer?
Men made things Square, God made The World. the Circular.

div.head: 49. To Theophila B. C.
div.l: He must love much, and have no vulgar spirit,
Who doth thee praise, and love as thou dost merit.

div.head: 50. Of Hernicus.
div.l: His Soul to God, his Body to the Ground
Hernick bequeath'd: And lying in a Swound
He heard some whisp'ring, that his wife had gain'd
A new-another Husband, which disdain'd
By th' envious Man, he gave his wife the Lye:
Reviv'd, whereas before he thought to die.

div.head: 51. Of Love and Faith.
div.l: Love is from Faith divorc'd: that ever is
Suspicious, not once suspected this.

div.head: 52. A Lover.
div.l: Uncertain Hope, Fear constant, flying Pleasure,
Sad Joyes, sweet Grief, Love bitter. Where's the Treasure?

div.head: 53. The Golden Age.
div.l: Before the virtue was of Gold disclos'd,
Why was that Age the Golden Age suppos'd?

div.head: 54. Of Alana.
div.l: In Bed Alana's Place is lowest, yet
At Table in the high'st Place She's set:
Her facile Husband parts with her the Sway,
He rules by Night, She governs all the day.

div.head: 55. Germanick Death, to Polynicus.
div.l: Death's not to be, saith Seneca; some think,
(And Germans too) that Death is not to drink.

div.head: 56. Of Philodemus.
div.l: Rare things, 'cause dear, thou shunnest, seekest common,
To thee more dear's a vile than dearer Woman.

div.head: 57. Of Battus.
div.l: Thou secrets tell'st, crave'st pardon for the wrong:
Wouldst have no need of Pardon? Hold thy Tongue.

div.head: 58. The Gordian Knot.
div.l: The Gordian Knot cut once with Sword; Is it
Now rather to be loos'd by Sword, or Wit?
None can dissolve this Knot by Wit or Word:
Nor yet can Alexander with his Sword.

div.head: 59. Love.
div.l: Wars, Peace again: these things occur in Love:
Content, Contention in one Circle move.

div.head: 60. Strifes, Laws, to J. C.
div.l: Strife Laws produc'd, and Law produceth Strife:
None without One of these can live this Life.

div.head: 61. The Miser and Prodigal.
div.l: My study's Rhetorick saith Prodigal:
And mine the Miser saith is Logical.
Logick, close-fisted Avarice descries,
And Rhetorick mens Prodigalities.

div.head: 62. Labour.
div.l: Though th' active Romans Grief no Labour deem'd,
Th' inactive Greeks Labour a Grief esteem'd.

div.head: 63. A good, strong, wise man.
div.l: Good Men want Wealth (but have divine supplies)
Wit to the Strong, Faith's wanting to the Wise.

div.head: 64. The Order of the Golden Fleece.
div.l: Philip the Duke of Burgundy, 'tis feign'd,
That Order of the Golden Fleece ordain'd:
Whose Heirs the Golden Indies now possess:
This Order was an Oracle: no less.

div.head: 65. The Motto of Thomas Earl of Dorset.
Nec temerè, nec timide.
Not hastily, nor heartlesly.
div.l: Wisely suspect, and stoutly things expect;
Be circumspect, lei thee no Fear deject.

div.head: 66. The Motto of Henry Neville, Knight.
Ne vile velis: Not vile's thy will.
div.l: Neville, thy will ne-vile, or vain brings forth:
Sith vile things little, vain are Nothing worth.

div.head: 67. To Sir Philip Sidney of his Arcadia.
div.l: Thou did'st command, when passing to thine Urne,
(Witness thy Wife) they should th' Arcadia burn,
If it should die, for kindling Lovers Flames,
It ought not to be burn'd, but drown'd in Thames:
(In this thy Book no Line, no Letter's found
That merits either to be burn'd or drown'd.)
What ever censure on thy Book may fall,
Thy Wit nor censure merits, Death, nor Gall.

div.head: 68. To Jane Owen a most learned woman.
div.l: None of thy Sisters have I heard or seen,
Though Five to th' aged Father born have been.
How many then I know, but what they be
I know not: yet I know, if like to thee.

div.head: 69. To his Friend.
div.l: He be none's Enemy, nor twice a Friend;
My Friendship where it doth begin shall end.

div.head: 70. The Usurers Grammer.
div.l: Things Creeping, Swimming, Going, Fleeing, All
Love These, Those, all things, all Men doth inthral:
He, She, That, Coyn, Money, and Gold, these Three
Do conquer Love, by whom all conquer'd be.

div.head: 71. To one like neither Parent.
div.l: Why did thy Parents thee, not like unt' Either
Beget, when they Consented Both together?
Thou no right form of Either Parent hast,
While both of them to form thee did what's past.

div.head: 72. To two (nameless) returning from Venice.
div.l: That your Adventure fourfold might return,
Your Journey you to Venice did adjourn;
From whence, when with your gain you came again,
Your Friends, though to their loss, rejoyc'd amain.

div.head: 73. Adultery and Fornication.
div.l: What differs base Adulterers from vile
Fornicators? Tragick as from Comick stile.

div.head: 74. Of Hercules, to C. D.
div.l: No force could force, or Hercules remove:
What was the greatest of his Labours? Love:
A Lioness, not Manness he could tame:
No Monstress, him a Mistress overcame.

div.head: 75. A Saluting Kiss.
div.l: Give me three Kisses, Phyllis: if not three,
So many as thy Lips are, give to Me:
Thou giv'st and takest one, deny'st one more,
Or take thou thine, or mine to me restore.

div.head: 76. A Problem to Naturalists, of Kisses.
div.l: If Kisses to the Tast bring nothing sweet,
Why Kiss we with our mouth when Friends we meet?

div.head: 77. Of Labienus.
div.l: This Thief the Gallows mounting, there to die,
Thus, thus, said he, we scale the Starry Sky.

div.head: 78. Of Alexander.
div.l: One World, one Alexander not confin'd:
O than the world, immenser was his mind.
To this one World, one Man was not compleat:
Great Alexander, but the World more great.

div.head: 79. To Firmicus, of Aulus.
div.l: Thou Firmick credit'st none, all credit thee:
Aulus trusts all, but cannot trusted be.

div.head: 80. Of a certain Poetaster.
div.l: Thou pottest so as if no Pot, no Poet.
No Poetry; as if Pots only show it.
Drunken Carnifex, an Hangman. Carminifex, from out this word
Take Mi, the rest to thee will well accord.

div.head: 81. Of ones Lying Letters.
div.l: Thy false Epistle oft comes to my sight:
Or rare, or never thou dost Gospel write.

div.head: 82. Physician heal thy self, to Gilbertus.
div.l: Vain is advice to thee, thy self to cure,
For 'tis thy greatest care, that cure t' ensure.

div.head: 83. Of a certain Usurer.
div.l: The thousand Pounds thou did'st to Flava lend,
Thou for it with full Usury dost send.
If like for like she gave, th'art paid thereby:
Thou hadst her Bodies use for th' Usury.

div.head: 84. Of an Hypocrite.
div.l: All things he doth dissemble, or surmise:
Though Labour hence, thence Dolour doth arise.

div.head: 85. Of Erasmus his Book of Follies.
div.l: Erasmus was the first who Folly prais'd:
This Folly shew'd his wit, his wisedom rais'd.

div.head: 86. Of Anagrammatists.
div.l: Whither, O whither will your wits inforce.
Vowels and Letters here and there to course?
As when Augustus leisure gave, in one
Thyrsis his Sheep, his Goats brought Corydon.

div.head: 87. Of a certain indoctrin'd Doctor.
div.l: Master in Art, thou Beardless-Artless wert:
Now Bearded Doctor th'art, but more inert.

div.head: 88. Of naked Love.
div.l: Nature the Fields, the Birds, the Sheep, the Beasts,
With Grass, with Plume, with Fleece, with hair invests:
What ever under th' Air is born or bred,
By Nature, or with Art is covered.
Why are all cloath'd but naked Love? express,
The more Love naked is 'tis call'd the less.

div.head: 89. Of the Exchequer, to Sir William Pits, Knight.
div.l: Into the Treasury collected Coyn
Runs, as fresh Rivers run into the The Sea. Brine:
Out of the Treasury the Coyn dispers'd,
Runs as the Rivers from the Sea revers'd:
Nor all those Rivers can the Sea supply,
Nor are the Fountains in the Mountains dry.

div.head: 90. Of a persidious Person.
div.l: I learn by trusting, not to trust Pretences:
My false and hapless Hope beguil'd my Senses.

div.head: 91. The Silver Sin.
div.l: No Whoremongers did Saturns Kingdom stain:
The World was chast till Jupiter did Reign.

div.head: 92. A Bawd.
div.l: No part from Sale is of thy Body Free,
Nor is thy Soul, if one would buy't of thee:
Thy Soul's expos'd to Sale, but none will buy it,
For all, except the Devil, will deny it.

div.head: 93. Self-Love.
div.l: I the First Person, Second Thou, Third He;
Yet Each t' himself seems First of all the Three.

div.head: 94. Wisdom.
div.l: Who's Rich? the Wise: Who's Poor? the Fool: by which
If I be wise, I shall be quickly Rich.

Who's wise? the Rich: Who's Fool? the Poor: then se •
▪
If Rich I am not, I a Fool must be.

div.head: 95. The Etymology of Venus.
div.l: Venus (saith Cicero de Nat. Deorum Lib. 2. one) spontan'ous doth advene
Unt' all things: doth he not u • t' all men mean?

div.head: 96. Of a certain Drunkard.
div.l: If Potable, as Optable were Gold,
What Mines of Gold would thy vast Guts insold?

div.head: 97. To Polla.
div.l: A Kiss thou nor deny'st, nor givest one;
But turn'st thy Cheek, arid as is a Bone.
If new things must have new Names (not the same)
Kisses must have a New, another Name.

div.head: 98. A Friend and a Wife.
div.l: Life's dear unt' us, a Friend is therefore dear:
A Wife t' her Husband's dear, why? 'cause so near.

div.head: 99. Anger.
div.l: Because that Anger Valour doth precur,
Call'd Aristotle Anger, Valours Spur?

div.head: 100. The Roman Flora.
div.l: Proud Rome, to which the world did Tribute pay,
Paid Tribute unto thee by night by day.
For All that was contributed to thee,
For Portage thou may'st call thy Tribute Free.

div.head: 101. The Etymology of the English word Anger (Ira.)
div.l: Angry men Anguish have in Deed in Name:

Anger and ( Vexing.
Angor) then are near the same.

div.head: 102. Of Himself.
div.l: I grave in Trifles, Study playing: when
In grave things trifling, I play studying then.

div.head: 103. Womens Titles.
div.l: A Court, when spous'd, his Wife a Countess makes:
A Countess makes no Count the Spouse she takes.
So from the Sun, the Moon receives her Light:
The Sun's Light is his own, no borrow'd Right.

div.head: 104. To Zoilus.
div.l: The Praiser Praise, the Lover Love doth merit:
Praise then if Praise; Love, if thou't Love inherit.

div.head: 105. Of the middle Age an indefinite Definition.
div.l: While drawing is our frail Life's latest Line,
No Line the Middle Place can it assign.
That which th' unlearn'd and learn'd call Middle Age,
None knows, till finish'd is his Pilgrimage.

div.head: 106. To a Grey-hair'd Dier.
div.l: Thy Beard, once colour'd Black, 's now colour'd White:
This Nature, not thine Art wrought, brought to Light.

div.head: 107. To Aulus.
div.l: New Rome expell'd her King, proud she the proud:
What wonder? Pride Kings lov'd not, nor allow'd:
Tell why so few Kings Friends are found? 'cause there's
Few that are Kings Competitors, or Peers.

div.head: 108. The Bed.
div.l: What th' English Bed, the Welch call Sepulcher:
The Bed a Tomb, and Sleep doth Death infer.

div.head: 109. Riders Library.
div.l: What means arrided Riders Book, thus stil'd
A Library, sith but one Book's compil'd,
And that of words? It therefore should not carry
The Name of Library, but Dictionary.

div.head: 110. Nummus, Money.
div.l:
Do Latine Criticks Money.
Nume and Numisme name
That, which the Greeks Nome and Nomisme proclaim?
Or is't O Nummus 'cause thou numbred art,
Thy Name from Numb'ring comes, in whole or part?
Or is't because the world esteems Queen Coyn
To be some Goddess, Numen, or Divine?

div.head: 111. Of J. S. a Covetous Man.
div.l: An Iron Chest thy Gold, Iron bars inviron
Thy Gate, House and House-holder all are Iron.

div.head: 112. Of Roman Flora, to Grammarians.
div.l: The Romans for the Flowers of their Fruit
Did Flora for a Goddess constitute.
She too too prodigal of Flesh and Fame,
Did neither bear good Fruit, nor keep good Name:
But prostitute i' th' Flower of her youth
She lost both Fruit and Flowers in their growth.

div.head: 113. Of J. Protus.
div.l: As Leaves from Trees in Autumn by the wind
Are whiffled all away, none left behind;
The bald-man so, by shaking of his head
Hath shook off all those Hairs which there were bred.

div.head: 114. Of Theodorus.
div.l: When David threescore years and Ten was old,
A fair young Virgin kept him from the cold:
Thou to be like that Prophet great and sage,
A young wife hast espous'd in thine old Age.

div.head: 115. Of the Plague in England 1603.
div.l: This Plague so many men and women slew,
That scarce is place for any Plague anew.

div.head: 116. To a certain Woman.
div.l: If Fortune had thee favour'd, as did Nature,
England had not a more accomplish'd Creature:
When Trojan Wars began hadst thou been born,
Troy for thy sake might have been sack'd and torn.

div.head: 117. Of a Perjured Person Convicted by his own Hand-writing.
div.l: In vain perfidious; thy words deny
That Truth which thine own hand doth testifie:
That words more constancy than Deeds should have,
One Mouth to thee, not two thy Maker gave,
But one Tongue, though two hands to thee belong;
Why single are thine Hands, double thy Tongue?

div.head: 118. Of Cottula, a Grammaticaster.
div.l: Thus Cottula did Labyrinth expound,
Because (quoth he) great labour in't is found.

div.head: 119. Anagram of Rome, to the Carthaginians.
div.l: Stout Annibal in a few hours delay'd
His fortune, having not Romes wealth survey'd:
He knew to conquer, knew not how to prize
His Conquest, though an African and wise.
Alas, what loss had he? Procrastination
Though small, preserv'd great Rome from Devastation.

div.head: 120. Of a great Clark.
div.l: Sick Stomachs much receive, not much concoct;
So thou know'st much, I know, yet art indoct.

div.head: 121. Of one called Davis.
div.l: From London Davisses thou bragg'st Descent,
And dost dissent from British Orient.
Ignoble thou, a noble Stock and pure
Disclaim'st, and claim'st from Parents more obscure:
Thou with thy native soyle dost well agree,
For thou of it, and it's asham'd of thee.

div.head: 122. Of Aulus.
div.l: Thee wise men think a fool: Fools think thee wise:
What art? what think'st thou of thy self? Advise.

div.head: 123. Of Linus a Doctor.
div.l: Why dost for form things frame? so coveting
Wit slightest: Form gives Essence to the thing.
If thou deny this Philosophick Norme,
I vouch it; thou wert Doctor made for Form.

div.head: 124. Of Thais.
div.l: O would thou wert less fair, or honest more,
For no thing's fouler than the fairest Whore.

div.head: 125. Of a nameless Voluminous Writer.
div.l: When dire-dure Hunger, and sad wants opprest thee,
When Thirst insatiated did molest thee,
Thy Books thou (self distracted) didst distract,
What should'st thou do? Famine advis'd that Act.
Thee Poverty compell'd, thy Books (with sweat
Compil'd) first pen'd, after to vend, and eat.

div.head: 126. On a Bald Pate.
div.l: Lo, not an hair thine heads bald Crown doth Crown:
Thy Faithless Front hath not one hair thine own:
Before, Behind thine hair's blown off with Blast,
What's left thee to be lost? thine Head at last.

div.head: 127. To Claudius and Linus.
div.l: Lewd Claud, to make thee good, thou want'st sole will:
Thou Linus want'st sole Power to make thee ill.

div.head: 128. To George.
div.l:
Nom.
George, whether thou desir'st to b' in my Book,
Wherein a Verse averse is, if thou look:
Gen. Or whether of thy Kindred I should raise
Trophys in Verse, oft sounding Thine-their Praise:
Dat. Or whether I to thee would recommend
Due thanks, my Verse cannot due thanks repend:
Accus. 'Tis well no Verse of mine thee doth accuse:
In this thy Name well pleaseth Me-my Muse.
Vocat. If generous, O George, thou would'st be call'd
Thou in th' extremest Place shalt still b' install'd.
Ablat. Wo's me, that I my Verse cannot inforce
Longer to hold with thee a long Discourse.

div.head: 129. A Lover is a Warrior.
div.l: Souldiers with Harlots, Aulus well compar'd:
Mars bodies arm'd, Venus unarm'd doth guard.

div.head: 130. The Military Oath.
div.l: The Latines Sacrament, call'd sacred Oath,
Which Souldiers to their Captain did betroth:
If Sacraments be but an Oath, then there
More Sacraments than two will soon appear.

div.head: 131. Of Alanus, Covetous and Lame.
div.l: Give but a Gift t' Alanus, He, though Lame,
Is hundred-handed to receive the same:
But if for Gift a Gift he must restore,
He's Lame that hundred-handed was before.

div.head: 132. The Condition of Kings.
div.l: While This forbears, That fears Truth to relate
To Kings, O miserable Kingly state!

div.head: 133. Vis, Jus, Force, Right, to J. C.
div.l: Vis, Force; Jus, Right are adverse: yet the Name
Of Vis and Jus inverted, is the fame.

div.head: 134. Of Marcus.
div.l: Wives, Widows, Maids, Whores, Wenches, (women-kind)
Thou lov'st, but thine own Wife thou leav'st behind:
Among so many kinds of Venus sports,
Why leav'st the lawful, lov'st th' unlawful sorts?

div.head: 135. Desperate Debt.
div.l: Who's not in Debt t' his wise? who Solvency or Payment is not to be understood, but of one that is able to pay the whole debt. Jabol. de verb. signif. 1. solvendo. solvent is?
None solid, but insolvent is in This.

div.head: 136. Of Culianus.
div.l: Wise men are Cic. de Divin. lib. 2. wonders: wonders now are none:
Then now there is no wise man; no, not one.
But Culian, th' art wise: then wonders are;
Or thou from wisdom, Culian, art far.

div.head: 137. Of Marcus, a man venust or comely.
div.l:
Too much of Venus
Burnt.
usted part of Thee,
That in some Part thou maist Venustus be.

div.head: 138. Of Adrian 5.
div.l: Derided Epigrams, derided Verse
Thou writest, which with mirth have no commerce:
No mirth is in them; yet the Reader smil'd,
Because both wit and mirth from them's exil'd.

div.head: 139. I, Thou, He.
div.l: There's no man but prefers Himself unt' All
Hence the first Person, I, we count and call.
Thou fam'st thy present, blam'st thine absent Friend,
He Thou next Me, and He next Thee doth tend.

div.head: 140. Petite & dabitur vobis.
Ask and it shall be given you.
div.l: That which was promis'd Askers heretofore
Is given now to Givers: men no more
Will gratis give: what's gratis comes from Heaven:
Of nought comes nought: Give, and it shall be given.Date & dabitur vobi •

div.head: 141. Married Persons, Children, Parents.
div.l: Husband and wife once two, are now but one:
Once one, two now are Father and his Son.

div.head: 142. Of Marcus a Lawyer.
div.l: Thou pleadest for thy self not Client; he
Not for himself, but brings his Gold for thee:
The certain Laws uncertain Causes cross:
Thou sure of gain, thy Client's sure of loss.

div.head: 143. To his Father.
div.l: As man more excellent than woman is,
I so thy son do more excel in this.

div.head: 144. An Italian.
div.l: Th' Italians of their wives (as Books comprize)
The parts incluse-s • cluse Monopolize:
This, what God said unt' Eve, the woman gains
By this, I will multiplicate thy pains.

div.head: 145. What Wife the Author would have.
div.l: I like a woman facile to be lov'd,
To love difficile, comely, well approv'd:
Rivals in love I like; deserve she should
The love of all, not love alone I would.

div.head: 146. To one complaining that his Children were not like him.
div.l: Would'st on thy wife beget a Self-like Child?
First get a wife like thee compos'd-compil'd.

div.head: 147. To the Married.
Of Conjugal Love.
div.l: When Adam had espoused Eve his Bride,
No woman was for him to love beside:
Love Conjugal is therefore First and best:
Paternal doth the Second Love attest.

div.head: 148. Sir Francis Drake's Epitaph.
div.l: Though Papistry should rage in time to come,
It would not, Drake, I think, dig up thy Tomb:
Thou need'st not fear it should thy Body burn,
For in the water safe from Fire's thine Urne.

div.head: 149. A Childs Epitaph dying before his Grandfather and Father.
div.l: Death keeps no method, Logick's Art denies:
A Son before his Sire and Grandsire dies.

div.head: 150. Epitaph of Maurus.
div.l: His Soul of 's Corps, his Corps of 's Soul's hereft;
Maurus wants both: his Name is only left.

div.head: 151. Epitaph of Pyramus and Thisbe.
div.l: Death friendly-foe from you that grief remov'd
Which brought on Death before: because you lov'd.

div.head: 152. Tho. Moor, dying.
div.l: Moor had his Head from's Body severed:
But would not have his Hair cut from his Head.

div.head: 153. Three Languages Crucified.
div.l: Hebrew, Greek, Latine, First, Next, Third commixt;
Sacred, Learn'd, Roman, all three Crucifixt.

div.head: 154. Don Antonio King of Portugal.
div.l: Between thee and thy Kingdom a Divorce
Was lately made against thy will, by force:
Now thou maist of thy Kingdom (took away)
What Christ Himself My Kingdom is not of this World. did of his Kingdom say.

div.head: 155. Alexander, Aristotle.
div.l: He great'st of Kings, of Sophists this compleater,
Great Alexander, Aristotle greater:
This learn'd, made Alexander more compleat;
Great He, made Aristotle not more great.

div.head: 156. Of Plato.
div.l: The Bees which swarm'd on Plato's lips, do still
Distill rare Sweets from his mellistuous Quill.

div.head: 157. Virgil's Georgicks.
div.l: Thou, Maro, writ'st rich Verse of Husbandry,
And dost manure the Readers wit thereby.

div.head: 158. Persius the Poet.
div.l: Dark Persius I read, but not conceive:
I' th' dark he doth his Readers lead and leave.

div.head: 159. Tacitus.
div.l: Thee Candor made Truth-telling, Nature wise,
Briefness obscure, and Gravity concise.

div.head: 160. To Martial.
div.l: Persons thou know'st to spare, to speak of things,
All thy Conceits are honyed, have no Stings.

div.head: 161. To Petrarch.
div.l: While O thy Laura's read, the doubt will be,
Lawrel or Laura whether fitt'st for thee.

div.head: 162. Pliny, Englisht by Philemon Holland, a Physician.
div.l: Pliny writes many things, is long: is short

Much writing: Holland's Because more plene , longer, Because more plai ••
shorter for't▪

div.head: 163. Of Cicero, to Catullus.
div.l: What thou didst tell Catullus, and foretell
Of Cicero, was true: for it befell.

div.head: 164. Of Historians in this Age.
div.l: Historians of old wrote truth, no lyes:
Now to write lies, no truth, it doth suffice.
This Nay, that Yea concludes: O which I pray
Shall the next Age believe of Yea or Nay?
The certain Reader is uncertain, whether
He Neither of them shall believe, or Either.

div.head: 165. Kings. People.
div.l: By Kings unlearn'd the People's led-misled,
Like faultring feet by a distemp'red Head.

div.head: 166. The Senate.
div.l: Kings Reign alone, why rule they not alone?
He ruleth best, who's rul'd by more than one.

div.head: 167. To an Historian.
div.l: Thou conversant in Histories dost read,
And travelst without danger, without dread:
An History doth teach in Time, though short,
More than long Times Experience doth comport.

div.head: 168. Of Diet, to J. H.
div.l: If old thou wouldst be slowly, then use all
Med'cines, like Modicums, Reciprocal.
Like too much meat, Med'cines may health infest;
And meat like Med'cines us'd is most times best.

div.head: 169. The Peers of France.
div.l: Not altogether Peers: for it appears
Imparity with Parity co-heres.

div.head: 170. P. Magnus, C. Major, F. Maximus, Pompey, Cato, Fabius.
div.l: This great'st, less than the great, greater than he
The Greater: which is greatest of the three?

div.head: 171. To T. S.
div.l: Thy wit and Judgement in my Verse to show
My wit and Judgement are too weak, too low.
Thy wit and Judgement I transcendent find,
Or else my wit and Judgement both are blind:
But whatso'ere my Judgement is, or wit,
I to thy wit and Judgement mine submit.

div.head: 172. Of himself.
div.l: What wonder if bad Verse my Muse unveils?
For I nor claw mine Head, nor gnaw my Nails.

div.head: 173. The Five Senses.
div.l: These Five to will and pleasure that relate,
Do they their Office, or officiate?

div.head: 174. Seeing.
div.l: The more the sight assimilates the Mind,
The more it draws it, makes it more inclin'd.

div.head: 175. Hearing.
div.l: How soon sounds vocal vanish from our Ear?
Like Air they come, like Air they disappear.

div.head: 176. Smelling.
div.l: Between the mouth and Eyes th' expanded Nare
Doth carnal with spiritual things compare.

div.head: 177. Tasting.
div.l: That meat may be more pleasing to the Tast,
Hunger, like Sauce, will sweeten the repast.

div.head: 178. Touching.
div.l: Some Touch sole pleaseth, some hath Titillation:
This youth, that Age affects with Delectation.

div.head: 179. Objects of the Senses.
div.l: Sight, Hearing, Smelling, Tasting, Touching, these
Affect, infect my Senses as they please.

div.head: 180. Touching and Tasting.
div.l: Some are, who can nor Smell, nor Hear, nor See:
And of five Senses are depriv'd of three:
Why want none Tasting, Touching? 'cause of these
That th' individ, this guards the Species.

div.head: 181. Epigrams, Satyres.
div.l: Satyres are but long Epigrams; And these
Are but short Satyres, to displease, or please:
Satyres avail not, if they be not tart;
Nor Epigrams, unless like Satyres, smart.

div.head: 182. A dumb man.
div.l: He moves his Lips, but utters no true sound,
Let Apollonius his mind expound.

div.head: 183. Blind and Deaf.
div.l: Why this with's Eyes, with's Ears more quick is he?
This hears with's Eyes, he with his Ears doth see.

div.head: 184. Teeth and Tongue.
div.l:
A Tooth.
Dens comes from Edens, Eating; Lingua, Tongue,
From Licking; each from what doth t' it belong.

div.head: 185. The Phoenix and the Viper.
div.l: The dying Phoenix leaves a living seed;
But living Vipers dying are to breed.

div.head: 186. The Silk-Worm.
div.l: Me skill doth kill, I make my self my Tomb,
I draw my fatal Thread, spin Death my Doom.

div.head: 187. The Right-Hand.
div.l: To give or take I use my Right-Hand; Why?
Lest what my Right-Hand doth, my left should 'spy.

div.head: 188. The Left-Hand.
div.l: From Pleasantness the Left-Hand hath its name;
An idle Hand, and in all Labour lume.

div.head: 189. Sunday.
div.l: Why's that day call'd (when Light was first dilated)
Sunday, when yet the Sun was not created?

div.head: 190. Terra di Lavoro.
div.l: Why is Campania so fully fam'd
For Pleasure, now the Land of Labour nam'd?

div.head: 191. Garments.
div.l: New things wax old, and old things are renew'd:
Thus men are pleas'd with a vicissitude.

div.head: 192. Wine.
div.l: Wine from sad hearts expelleth Grief; and mine
Letificates, dilating when supine.

div.head: 193. A Sheep.
div.l: Want we flesh, skins, young, dung, dice, Musick-strings,
Wooll, Milk? one Sheep supplies with all these things.

div.head: 194. Soyling of Fields.
div.l: Dung's a vile Excrement; yet hath its worth:
Its Element mine Aliment brings forth.

div.head: 195. Harmony.
div.l: Discording Concords best concur in Nature:
So man and woman generate a creature.

div.head: 196. A Parret.
div.l: If words t' invert be lawful, and unblam'd,
A Parret then a prater shall be nam'd.

div.head: 197. Ink and Paper.
div.l: That it may more apparent be, we write
With cole-black Ink on Paper Snow-like white.

div.head: 198. A Comedy.
div.l: The Scene our facts obscene describes▪descries:
Our faults are found not feign'd in Comedies.

div.head: 199. A Cloak.
div.l: My Cloak from th' Earth, than I my self more far's:

div.head: A Gown.
div.l: My Gown sweeps th' Earth, my Mind transcends the Stars.

div.head: 200. A Satyre.
div.l: One reason Satyres did produce and Laws:
Ill Manners of both's being were the Cause.

div.head: 201. An Eunuch.
div.l: My Testicles I want, yet I attest
My self a Man, a Masculine at least.

div.head: 202. An Hour-glass.
div.l: False is the truest Hour-glass: for with use
The Sand wears smaller, wider grows the Sluce.

div.head: 203. A Merchant.
div.l: 'Tis hard to say That Merchant's rich or poor,
Who to the trustless Seas intrusts his store.

div.head: 204. Lust.
div.l: That thing's deform'd, fair form'd by night should seem,
'Tis not black Nights, but 'tis blind Lust's esteem.

div.head: 205. Donna, Lady.
div.l: By how much more man's Lord of 's wife, why than
His wife, his Lady calls th' uxorious Man?

div.head: 206. A Souldier.
div.l: Though Wars give bloody Skarrs, yet more are harm'd
By naked Venus, than by Mars when arm'd.

div.head: 207. An Army.
div.l: Huge Hulk, Faith faithless, inhumane, too greedy
Of bloodshed, to shed humane blood too speedy.

div.head: 208. Lovers Tears.
div.l: As fervent fire from wood the moisture drills,
So Love within the Tears from th' Eyes distills.

div.head: 209. The Stars.
div.l: He that affects th' odd Number (that is) God
Created all the Stars, in number odd.

div.head: 210. The Venetians.
div.l: As Seas with Waters, Skyes with Stars abound:
So Riches the Venetians surround.

div.head: 211. An Harp.
div.l: Sith th' Harps discording Strings concording be,
Is't not a shame for men to disagree?

div.head: 212. A Fowler.
div.l: Shun cruel Flames, not knowing sports events.
All Elements give thy sport Aliments.

div.head: 213. The Echo.
div.l: No skill nor Art a voice can form, or found:
Sole Echo doth reiterate the sound.

div.head: 214. A Looking-glass.
div.l: Than Phid'ias or Apelles wiser, thou
The Bodies moti'on form'st, they knew not how.

div.head: 215. The Echo, and Looking-glass.
div.l: Nothing of Life hath th' Echo, but to squeake:
The Glass would seem to live, if it could speak.

div.head: 216. Musick.
div.l: The name of Musick from the Muses came;
Best Art; none other Science hath this Name.

div.head: 217. Albion, To the King.
div.l: England was once an Heptarchy: that while
Into nine Parts was parted all this Isle.
Unhappy Britain when divided thus;
United, happy made by thee for us.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Book.

div.head: THE THIRD BOOK OF JOH. OWEN'S Epigrams.
1. To the Lady Mary Neville.
div.l: I Gloze not, lye not thee when I applaud:
None more deserveth, less desireth land.
Thou seek'st not praise, though thou deserv'st it best:
And of thy praises this is not the least.

div.head: 2. To the same.
div.l: Thou who before thy Birth a burden were
Unto thy Parent, born, her honour art.

div.head: 3. To the Reader, of his Book.
div.l: Lest this my Book displease the candid Eye
I fear; and fear lest it with Fools comply.

div.head: 4. The Virgin Birth of Elizabeth, Queen of England 1602.
div.l: England and Scotland are united by
Th' auspicious Birth of thy Virginity.
T' unite then multiply's of greater worth:
And thou best Parent by not bringing forth.

div.head: 5. To the Hollander 1602.
div.l: Thou not against Minerva's will didst fight,
Whil'st Englands Pallas back'd thee with her might.
But thy fate chang'd; Death (like Ulysses come)
Took hence thy Pallas and Palladium.

div.head: 6. To James King of Great Britain, &c.
div.l: The Golden Age is come, long since foretold,
When but one King should wear Brute's Crown of Gold
Who should the Britains, that divided were
Unite; of Peace should th' Olive Branches bear:
That having Peace, all good unt' us comes forth,
We now may say (most truly) from For Owen, Grandfather to King Henry the seventh came from North Wales: And King James from th • North of great Britain. the North.

div.head: 7. To the Prince.
div.l: Great Britaines Hope, son of so great a Sire,
Half of each Parent; for Example higher
Almost than imitation; in rare Parts
Follow'd by few, belov'd in all mens hearts.
Hadst thou these vertues from thy Sires instinct?
Or from thy Mothers Breasts? from both I think't.

div.head: 8. Basilicon Doron, to the King.
div.l: None needs this Author, none this Book proclaim:
He This, This Him resounds with Trump of Fame.

div.head: 9. To the Lady Mary Neville.
div.l: Thy Glass reflects thee fair, fame calls thee chast;
Thou nor from Glass, nor Fame a fable hast;
Fame that of all things hath the swiftest wing,
Dares not presume thy fame to stain, or sting.

div.head: 10. Of her daughter Cecily.
div.l: No Painter can delineate the mind:
Yet in this Picture thou thy self maist find.

div.head: 11. To the Candid Reader.
div.l: My good Verse, best: indifferent mine ill,
Kind Reader thou dost call with candid will.

div.head: To the malevolent Reader.
div.l: My bad Verse, worst: indifferent, my good
Thou call'st, (black Reader) so thy censure stood.

div.head: 12. Hercules By-way.
div.l: Some in Quadruples, some in Triples erre:
Th' Herculean Duple is most sinister.

div.head: 13. Of Vertue.
div.l: Vertue contemneth praise, though praise incline
To Vertue Shadows as to Bodies joyn;
