For Vertue's real, praise but verbal, bare
As Bodies something, Shadows nothing are.

div.head: 14. Lifes Dyal.
div.l: From East to West without return am I,
Born yesterday, live this day, next day die.

div.head: 15. Of God.
div.l: So great thy Greatness Euclide could not show:
And such as Aristotle did not know.

div.head: 16. Of an Atheist.
div.l: There is no God the Fool in secret saith:
But none so soolish as to make't his Faith.
If none a God deny, who's th' Atheist? he
Who doth desire that there no God should be.

div.head: 17. Charity.
div.l: As Wives where loveless, there do faithless prove,
So's Faith depriv'd of Charitable love.

div.head: 18. Dives and Lazarus.
div.l: The Gospel doth a nameless Rich man blame,
Where Lazarus hath an eternal Name.

div.head: 19. Increase and Multiply.
div.l: The first man was at first but one, till God
Of him made two, evening the number odd:
After when God unt' Eve did Adam tye,
God made them one again to multiply:
God first made one, then two, then (as before)
He made them one to multiply the more.

div.head: 20. Union.
div.l: Divine is Union, Division evil's:
For there's one God, innumerable Devils.

div.head: 21. Three Tempters.
div.l: The World, Flesh, Devil; are three Sophisters;
In Logick he, in Rhet'rick they converse.

div.head: 22. The Spirit and Flesh.
div.l: Me Flesh and Spirit hither, thither force;
Jove, Caesar are in me Competitors:
Peace to you both: were you but once at Peace,
Peace then in all the world would soon increase.

div.head:
23. Man to Man a
God,
Wolf.
div.l: Man is to man a God, a Wolf: why? when?
For Christ's a God, Adam a Wolf to men.

div.head: 24. God's word.
div.l: Men few things see, God all things sees foresees:
Hence men speak often, God but once decrees.

div.head: 25. The Broad and Narrow way.
div.l: The Scripture bids us strive ('tis our concern)
To walk the Narrow way to Life eterne:
If that way leads us not t' inherit Bliss,
The broader way will lead us down to Dis.

div.head: 26. St. John Baptist.
div.l: The Baptist Christ preceded, as the Light
Precedes the Sun, brings day, dispells the night.

div.head: 27. Of Autumn.
div.l: Autumn shakes off the Leaves, and for man's use
Produceth fruit: let us the like produce.

div.head: 28. The Misery of Life.
div.l: Who long would live, wretched although and poor,
That is, he would be wretched more and more:
Poor-wretched Irus dies against his will:
That i • , he would be poor and wretched still.

div.head: 29. Of Nature and Grace.
div.l: Nature like to the Moon gives pallid Light:
Grace like the Sun more splendid shines and bright.

div.head: 30. The Catechism.
div.l: Twelve things thou must believe, must pray for seven,
And ten things do if thou wilt enter Heaven.

div.head: 31. A Rich Man.
div.l: Why are few rich men sav'd? because their bent
Repents Expences, nothing else repent.

div.head: 32. O guileful Hopes!
div.l: O rather guileful things; our Hope a friend
Most faithful, us concomitates to th' end.

div.head: 33. The Redeemer.
div.l: One man by dying, man from Death hath freed,
Which was to man for one mans sin decreed:
Christ all things did post-pone, lost man to win,
Contemn'd-condemn'd, O Adam, for thy sin.

div.head: 34. The Holy Spirit.
div.l: As Doves to whitest Houses soonest come,
So th' holy God makes cleanest Hearts his home.

div.head: 35. Fortitude.
div.l: The Wise doth know, the Just will do what's right,
Who dares thus, shall b' esteem'd a man of might.

div.head: 36. Of a King.
div.l: Law, where's no King's like light when Sun's away:
King, where's no Law's like Sun without a Ray.
People first chose a King: The King with them
Made Laws, yet subject to the Diadem.

div.head: 37. A Welch Man.
div.l: English and Scots by name are one with thee:
Now Welch-man, sole thou shalt not British be.

div.head: 38. English-Scots.
div.l: Disjoyn'd in Laws, what Law shall them conjoyn?
The Kingdoms safety best of Laws divine.

div.head: 39. Henry the Roses, James the Kingdoms. To the King.
div.l: The Roses, English colours Red and White,
Like Cadmus new-sprung Host ingag'd in Fight,
And as the Twins, which one Egge did include,
Do Rise and Set in a vicissitude,
As Day the Night, as Night succeeds the Day,
The Roses so did bear alternate sway,

Till Mother Mona
A British Proverb, Mon Mam Gymri, in English thus, Anglisey the Mother of Wales. British Angles'y,
An Isle which Tacitus not tacitely
Recordeth, happy Mother, happier
By bearing British Owen Theodor:
From whom arose a Noble Prince, a Rose
Whose Wife and Mother sprung from Stem of those,
Who thousand dangers pass'd in Nuptial Bed,

United Remarkable here that the Triple Empire of Britain by a certain occult Fate was restored to the British Blood, (1) The Kingdom of Scotland by Stuart. (2) The Kingdom of England by Tyder. (3) The Empire of the whole Island by James the first, descended from both. both the Roses White and Red.
Which Union, lest Change or Chance divide
The Roses, His: The Kingdoms are thy Bride.

div.head: 40. The Apocalypse of John Napeir.
div.l: Ninety two years the World continue shall,
If as thou Calculat'st, it stand and fall:
Why dost not th' End to be more near surmize?
Lest thou a Lyer should'st be found: th' art wise.

div.head: 41. God, Man.
div.l: God cannot die, nor man Death conquer can:
But Christ did both, he was both God and Man.

div.head: 42. Death.
div.l: Death unto bad men bane, to good men bliss:
An endless Ill, or End of all Ill is.

div.head: 43. God.
div.l: God is Immense, all measuring alone:
And He's Innumerable; for but but one.

div.head: 44. Miracle.
div.l: Let others Miracles admire: but I
Admire their Maker only, God on high.

div.head: 45. Adam's Fall.
div.l: Mens Bodies, Goods, and Souls, Adam's foul fall
To Physick, Law, Divines did first inthrall.

div.head: 46. To Adam.
div.l: False Eve, Death's Parent, thee deceiv'd by Fruit;
And foully ruin'd with a fair salute.

div.head: 47. To Preachers.
div.l: The Cock (the Mornings Herald) claps his wings,
To rouze himself before he Crows or Sings:
Preachers should do the like, first should begin
To rouze themselves; next others raise from sin.

div.head: 48. The Tempter.
div.l: As Mice in Walls, so Satan in man's heart
Orfinds, or makes a way with his black Art.

div.head: 49. Mortification.
div.l: We live to die, and die to live: O why,
Then learn we not to die, before we die?

div.head: 50. Hodie, to Day.
div.l: This Day was yesterday to Morrow nam'd:
To Morrow shall be yesterday proclaim'd:
To Morrow not yet come, nor far away,
What shall to Morrow then be call'd? To Day.

div.head: 51. Against thee only have I sinned.
div.l: Subjects do sin 'gainst God, the King, the Laws:
A King 'gainst God alone: A King because.

div.head: 52. Prayer.
div.l: As Christ transpiere'd the Doors fast shut at Even:
So Prayers pierce th' Impenetrable Heaven.

div.head: 53. Mary Magdalens Tears.
div.l: Vain wandring Eyes sinning by seeing vain:
Wip'd off, by weeping with those Eyes, sins stain:
I err, if not that weeping faculty,
Because th' Eye first did sin, 's infus'd in th' Eye.

div.head: 54. Of Hope and Fear.
div.l: Riches and Fear, Hope want concomitate:
Hope's to be wish'd for, Fear's a froward fate.
Poor men have Hopes, the Rich men Fears: But I
These Fears had rather than those Hopes apply.

div.head: 55. Mathusalem is dead.
div.l: Life is not long, but still to live: what profit
Is in long life, when Death's the sequel of it?

div.head: 56. Of Law and Justice.
div.l: The way to Law than Justice more we trace,
Though this the shorter, that's the longer Race.

div.head: 57. Intemperance.
div.l: We who desire long life before we die,
Why do we shorten it by Luxury?
We will, and will not lengthen our short spans:
We nill our selves, will, by Physicians.

div.head: 58. To Ponticus.
div.l: Art poor? 'tis hard to make thee rich: but when
Th' art rich, 'tis easie to be richer then.

div.head: 59. The Pharisees.
div.l: They say, but do not: 'tis our Ages sin:
First say, then do: Faith so doth enter in.

div.head: 60. Liberty.
div.l: If happy's he that all things hath at will,
Why do men will, yet are repining still?
The best-great'st vertue's Liberty: sole he
Can live at will, whose will is well to be.

div.head: 61. Christ, whence.
div.l: Conceiv'd at Nazareth, at Beth'lem born:
Thy Natures two, two Countries did adorn.

div.head: 62. Christ Crucified.
div.l: To th' Erring, Dying, Sick, the Way, Life, Cure,
The Crosses Cross, Deaths Death didst Cross endure.

div.head: 63. Christs Cross.
div.l: The Cross bare Christ, Christ bare the Cross: and thus
Christ bare the Cross, the Cross Christ: all for us.

div.head: 64. Of Religion.
div.l: A pleasant Tree planted in pious breast,
Whose Root hath labour, fruit hath honours Crest:
Fear first brought Gods into the world: no lye:
For to fear God is the prime Piety.
In Piety's root's Gall, Honey's above:
For Fear's Religion's Fount, the River, Love.

div.head: 65. On the Prodigal and Miser.
div.l: This till his death gives nothing; that at's death
Hath nothing left to give, or to bequeath.

div.head: 66. The Married.
div.l: Let man love's wife, let wife submissive be
T' her husband; he's her Head, his Heart is she.

div.head: 67. Study.
div.l: Students grow mad by studying much to know;
None mad by studying to be good doth grow.

div.head: 68. Remember Death.
div.l: Death of uncertains hath most certainty;
Uncertain when, but certain once to die:
None from his birth, none from his death is far,
Yet none of this is a Remembrancer.

div.head: 69. The Blessed Virgin.
div.l: Gods Spouse, her Fathers Parent, her Sons Child,
Virgin by man, without man Mother stil'd.

div.head: 70. What's rare, not dear.
A Paradox.
div.l: Vice common is, yet nothing is more dear:
Vertue seems vile, yet rare it doth appear.

div.head: 71. A Beast.
div.l: Past hope, what's past; sole future hope doth rest,
Things hopeless pass, hopes fruitless with the Beast.
While past things vex, future perplex with care
Us men; Beasts, wiser, pleas'd with present are.

div.head: 72. Reason.
div.l: Reason's the Queen of things; their Mother's Nature:
This brings them forth; that is their Regulater.

div.head: 73. Nature.
div.l: Wise Nature hath with Reason us supply'd;
Which wills us to take Nature for our Guide.

div.head: 74. Freedom of Speech.
div.l: Thou seem'st t' have freedom fables to relate;
But free enough's the Tongue that less doth pra •• .

div.head: 75. To Marcus, a Problem.
div.l: Be'st good or bad what matter's it? For those
Force like the Lawes, these Laws like force oppose.

div.head: 76. Upon Old and New Fashions.
div.l: 'Tis foolish Envy new things to despise;
And envious folly new things sole to prize.

div.head: 57. A Christians Death.
div.l: Death, like the way, leads thee to life; and is
No dying, but an Entrance into Bliss.

div.head: 78. To Christ.
div.l: Anchor of Hope, Faiths Ship, Loves shoreless Sea,
Earth's Salt, Heavens Sun, the Souls sole saving Plea:
Death, by thy death is kill'd, Death dead doth lie:
Yet who would think that ever Death could die?

div.head: 79. Self-Love.
div.l: Who sees not his own faults, but others spies,
Is wise unt' others, but t' himself unwise.

div.head: 80. Saints Lives.
div.l: 'Tis vain Saints Lives to read, and not to lead;
Do both; the lives of Saints read, lead: lead, read.

div.head: 81. Our Country.
div.l: A good man's still at home, not in Exile:
Each Land each Sea is as his native soyle:
Exile's where ill, our Country where contrary:
In this Good, Bad are each ubiquitary.

div.head: 82. Upon an Atheist.
div.l: No faith of past, nor hopes of future move
Within thy Soul, the present's thy sole love.

div.head: 83. Of Hereticks.
div.l: Virgil from Enn'us dross did Gold extract:
But Hereticks from Gold do dross compact.

div.head: 84. An Encomiastick.
div.l: The Good by praise is better, worse the bad,
The Crafty craftier, the fool more mad.

div.head: 85. Not too fast.
div.l: None's on the sudden good: hast not too fast,
Although in Vertues way thou makest hast:
Good counsel us'd in hast, proves bad we find:
First recollect, and then correct thy mind.

div.head: 86. The Envious, and Fool.
div.l: This wants right Reason, that a candid heart:
This cannot, and that will not Truth assert.

div.head:
87.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Sermo, Speech.
div.l: Gods Speech all Reason's, ours all Oraizon:
So what God speaks, and man's a speaking Tone.

div.head: 88. Opinion.
div.l: None will believe, yet all would be believ'd:
• o faith like friendship is by gain atchiev'd.

div.head: 89. Art.
div.l: God hath all Arts laid up in Natures breast,
That man might thence require, acquire the best.

div.head: 90. Adams Apology.
div.l: Why am I blam'd as Author of mans sin?
I sin'd not first: Eve did to me begin.

div.head: 91. The Serpent.
div.l: Thou thy self-tempter, self-deceiver wert,
None did attempt to tempt, or thee pervert.

div.head: 92. Still the same.
div.l: One God in all the World was, is, and shall:
Why is not then the same one faith for all?
One faith, like day, the world t' enlighten, even
As one Sun's in the Sky, one God in Heaven.

div.head: 93. Mental Prayer.
div.l: Let Soul be pure, House Oratory, Reader
The Spirit, cleansed Heart, Prayers the Pleader.

div.head: 94. The five Wounds.
div.l: Balsoms not wounds were th' wounds which Christ endur'd,
For by those wounds our wounds are clos'd, are cur'd.

div.head: 95. Feigned Friendship.
div.l: While the dark World, the Suns bright beams accend,
The shadow on the body doth attend:
But when Clouds intervening shade the shine,
The shadow doth thy body then decline:
While Fortune smiles, thy friends will follow thee,
As shadows Bodies, when Sun shines, we see.

div.head: 96. Vertue.
div.l: Vertue consisteth not in words but Deeds:
Faith, Hope, and Charity are Herbs not Weeds.

div.head: 97. Rachel.
div.l: Why dost bewail thy loss in thy lost Son?
Thou brought'st him forth with pain, with grief he's gone.

div.head: 98. Solomon.
div.l: So many Miracles, as wise men, are:
For than a wise man, what's more strange, more rare?
But Solomon's before the seven Sages,
He's then the first, not the Eighth by our Suffrages.

div.head: 99. Hope.
div.l: Sith in things future, artless is my Skill,
Why should I hope for good, or fear what's ill?
Yet I despair not, without hope I die:
Long hope prolongs my short Lifes Brevity.

div.head: 100. Mans Ignorance.
div.l: I scarce know what's to live: no wonder I
Then know not what 'tis to be born, or die.

div.head: 101. Christ the Way.
div.l: Would'st know the way which doth unt' Heaven tend?
The Way from Heaven doth to thee descend.

div.head: 102. Of Fame.
div.l: Seek vertue, but the praise thereof disclaim:
Not of the man the praise is, but the Name.

div.head: 103. Faith.
div.l: Faith in Pythag'ras principles 's a Prince:
His Ipse dixit did convince-evince.

div.head: 104. Aequanimity.
div.l: Whether Deaths hour be come or not, abhor it
To be too willing, or unwilling for it

div.head: 105. Newest Times.
div.l: The Times which first produced things in view,
Were the New Times, for then the world was new:
Tell me learn'd Reader of the Books inroll'd,
Whether our Times be the New Times, or Old?

div.head: 106. The Will.
div.l: Wilt thou be good? Will sole, it shall be so:
Who gave thee Will, will on thee Pow'r bestow.

div.head: 107. To the Sun.
div.l: Fair Phoebus who twice fourscore times (by guess)
Art than th' Earth greater though thou seemest less.
Thou who to me poor worm so small dost seem,
How little (Ah) am I in thine esteem?

div.head: 108. Honesty.
div.l: The wise man than the good's more wise: no matter,
While that the good is than the wise man better.

div.head: 109. Man.
div.l: His Heart's but care, his flesh a Carkass, and
Sickness his Birth, his Life at Deaths command.

div.head: 110. Multiloquy, to a Preacher.
div.l: Multiloquy shews Ignorance: what needs
So many words when thou dost see the Deeds?

div.head: 111. Death with and against Nature.
div.l: By Natures course, O Death, thou shouldst not gather,
Nor take away the Son before his Father.
In Life and death we Natures Rules apply,
Nature will have men live, will have men die.

div.head: 112. Eloquence.
div.l: Not to speak much, but well, is Eloquence:
As fertile Fields good fruit, not much dispence.

div.head: 113. God.
div.l: As from our sight thick Clouds the Skies obscure,
So God's invisible to minds impure:
None have seen God: and few have heard Him speak,
Hence Faith is by Hearing: Love by Seeing. Faith's so rare, but Love's more rare, more weak.

div.head: 114. To Ponticus.
div.l: Thou ask'st what years thou hast? I answer None:
For what thou had'st, thou hast not: they be gone.

div.head: 115. Love and Friendship, to Carolus.
div.l: From a long custom Nature doth dissent,
As Love from friendship differs in th' extent.

div.head: 116. Princes.
div.l: You seem to shew a zealous-pious care,
For true Religions Progress to prepare:
But your Religion moves t' have Honour more,
Not th' Honour true Religion to restore.

div.head: 117. O Times, O Manners!
div.l: Why doth man blame the Manners, and the Times,
Imputing to their pravities his Crimes?
In Times or Manners is no fault at all.
Not by Them, in Them are we criminal.

div.head: 118. Philosophy.
div.l: All much would know, but to believe it few:
Hence many much believe, yet few do know.

div.head: 119. Infinite Evil.
div.l: Born but one way, a thousand waies we die,
Our thousand Sores have but one Remedy.

div.head: 120. Of Controversies.
div.l: Divines contend, and yet is their contest
Under the Judge: O would it there might rest:
Divines contend, and of the Judge complain:
O would that all the strife did there remain.
Or that in us there was such strife of Love,
As Love of strife in ev'ry Sphere doth move.

div.head: 121. Christ on the Cross.
div.l: When Christ was Crucifi'd two Thieves between,
Then Vertue, never, or i' th' midst was seen.

div.head: 122. Times Daughter.
div.l: Though truth be sometimes hid, 'twill be proclaim'd,

Hence by the Greeks it is Without Oblivi ••
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 nam'd.

div.head: 123. Physick and Law.
div.l: If Mortals would as Nature dictates, live,
They need not Fees to the Physicians give:
If men were wise, they need not have their Cause
Pleaded, prolonged by th' ambiguous Laws.
So Bartolus might (Feeless) go to Bed,
And Mice corrode Hippocrates unread.

div.head: 124. Man and Wife.
div.l: The total House us holds not, when we chide,
But one Bed serves us both when pacifi'd.

div.head: 125. The shortest Day.
div.l: One Day, the last is our Lifes shortest Day,
For it is next our End, and will away.

div.head: 126. Vertues Complaint.
div.l: Rare's love of love, love of Vertue's rare:
Price is now priz'd, and Honours honour'd are:
Riches are prostitute, Coyn Money buyes,
And Vertue's vile, she must her own worth prize.

div.head: 127. An hard Father.
div.l: A sparing Father is most liberal
T' his Son: For dying he doth leave him all.

div.head: 128. A Prayer to God in Sickness.
div.l: Nature of Nature, O good God, when I
Can live no longer, give me will to die.

div.head: 129. To a litigious Person.
div.l: If Judge to thee be deaf, thy Cause is lost,
Thy gain is vain Experience with cost:
'Tis better Judges please than plead the Laws,
Those before these indulge unto thy Cause.

div.head: 130. Of Brunonius.
div.l: Our Fathers instituted Fasts that (they)
Their Flesh, the Spirit, that it might God obey:
But with full Table thou keep'st Fast that thence
Thy Spirit may thy flesh, thy flesh serve sense.

div.head: 131. Time.
div.l: Age all things brings, all things bears hence with it:
All things have Time, and Time hath all things fit.

div.head: 132. Miracles.
div.l: Sith Miracles are ceas'd (what shall I speak?)
Is Gods hand shorter? or our faith more weak?

div.head: 133. To Irus.
div.l: Thou still wouldst live, but live thou caust not still,
Though still to live thou maist, dost wish, and will,
But sith thou liv'st so poor, I know not why,
Though life thou will'st, thou should'st not wish to die.

div.head: 134. Knowledge.
div.l: Methinks they sole are happy here below
That either all things, or else no things know.

div.head: 135. Christ.
div.l: As Morning ends the Night, begins the Day,
So thou Death's End wert, and Lifes rising Ray.

div.head: 136. Who art Thou.
div.l: Whom do mine Eyes behold, mine Eyes are blind:
What sees my mind, my mind doth want a mind.
If my best part, my mind, it doth not know,
How can I, what I am, unto thee show?

div.head: 137. The Kingdom of Heaven.
div.l: Why do so few the Kingdom gain of Heaven?
Because the way's so strait, uncouth, uneven.

div.head: 138. Grief and Pleasure.
div.l: Mans heart and body present Grief doth grieve,
Future with fear doth vex, past doth relieve:
Present Delight, bought with past pain, doth please,
But fear of future pain doth it disease.

div.head: 139. Peter.
div.l: Jerusalems last High Priest Caiaphas was;
But Romes first High Priest was (they say) Kephas.

div.head: 140. Of Sleep.
div.l: If Sleep be but as Death, Death but as Sleep,
The more I Sleep, the less of Life I keep.

div.head: 141. Rome.
div.l: The world begun, Abel was kill'd by Cain,
Rome Founded, Remus was by Rom'lus slain:
The world and Rome with blood alike stain'd stand,
Both did begin in blood by Brothers hand.

div.head: 142. Mans Perfection.
div.l: The chief Perfection of ev'ry Creature
Is to return t' its principles by Nature:
Then I shall perfect be, when I return
My Soul to God, my Body to mine Urne.

div.head: 143. Lord increase our Faith, Luk. Cap. 17.
div.l: Faith needs not an increase, but a decay,
Sith scarce so many men as Faiths bear sway:
Each hath his Faith, his Tutor of his own,
Never more Faiths, more faithless men were known.Lord, diminish our Faith▪

div.head: 144. On the Covetous.
div.l: He, Hercules Nil ultra, doth pass by,
And Carolus Plus ultra doth apply.

div.head: 145. Good Transcending.
div.l: Good all transcends and boundless is alone,
None therefore in the world is good, not one.

div.head: 146. All is Vanity.
div.l: Heraclite living would our Manners mourn,
Our Times Democritus would laugh to scorn:
Though to deride what vain on Earth is seen,
Democritus hath not enough of spleen:
Nor to lament poor Mortals miseries,
Heraclitus hath tears in both his Eyes.

div.head: 147. Of Epicurus.
div.l: Young men complain that short's their youthful sport;
And old men murmur that their Life's so short:
The life of pleasure, pleasures life arise
Both short, who vilipends them both is wise.

div.head: 148. Works.
div.l: Good men shall follow their good works: But then
Their wicked works shall follow wicked men.

div.head: 149. Wisdoms Beginning.
div.l: None would for Heaven hope, if none fear'd Hell:
Fear in the prudent hope creates: 'tis well.

div.head: 150. Of Battologus.
div.l: Thou not content to tire the learned ear
With words, and with vain babbling, Time to tear,
But after a Tautology long spun,
Dost yet complain that Time too fast did run,
Return unt' Oxford, and distinguish better.
Thy Sermon long, short time was not thy debtor.

div.head: 151. Of the same.
div.l: Learn'd Tullies long Orations seem not long,
Nor would thy Sermons couldst thou clip thy Tongue.

div.head: 152. Of Polytheans.
div.l: O foolish folk, what madness doth y' insnare
To think there be more Gods than worlds there are!

div.head: 153. Of Wit and Study.
div.l: Wit, if not whet with Study, waxeth null,
As Knives without the Whetstones help are dull;
Wit is by Study cherish'd, perish'd there,
As Whetstones make Knives sharp, and sharpning tear.

div.head: 154. Know thy Self.
div.l: None knows himself aright: yet mind he can
Himself a Child, when old, a younger man.

div.head: 155. Long Art, short Life.
div.l: An Age to make one wise doth not suffice:
Death's at our backs before we can be wise.

div.head: 156. Of Moranus an old man.
div.l: Not to be learn'd, but to be unlearn'd by thee,
Are many things if thou wilt better be:
But how thou wilt unlearn, or learn wilt thou
To be made good, thus old, is hopeless now.

div.head: 157. To D. T.
div.l: Twice wretched thou, because once fortunate,
Twice happy's he, who wretched was of late.

div.head: 158. All seek their own.
div.l: The Laick Gain, not Christ seeks, uncontroll'd,
And thou, O Clerick, seek'st not God, but Gold.

div.head: 159. Of Brunonius.
div.l: Why doth the Pest, as is suppos'd, attest
God's wrath, sith thee the Pest doth not infest?
The reason's ready, and a solid one,
Thou to thy Country art a Pest alone.

div.head: 160. Respect thine End.
div.l: Look back on thy beginning, and thine End
Foresee, scorn Earth, in Soul unt' Heav'n ascend.

div.head: 161. Sense, Reason, Faith, Charity, God.
div.l: Sense without Reason, Reason faithless, (Dull)
Faith without love, love without God is null.

div.head: 162. Of Prudence.
div.l: Prudence is useful matters to dispence,
And of three Vertues is the Quintessence:
For what is Good in Life she doth impart,
As Logick teacheth what is Truth in Art.

div.head: 163. To his Parents.
div.l: Dear Parents I am of your Flesh and Bone:
You both are in my Flesh, yet Flesh but one.

div.head: 164. Prudence and Fortitude.
div.l: Wise men must ills beware, Strong must them bear,
That those may suffer none, these none may fear.

div.head: 165. In the sweat of thy Brows, &c.
div.l: He that injoyn'd thee t' eat thy bread in sweat
Will not to th' idle give th' eternal Meat.

div.head: 166. Of Faith and Charity.
div.l: As Trees first planted are e're Fruit they bear,
So where are vertues faith must first appear;
Life lives by Faith, not without Love: as poor
Do live in hope, yet labour more and more.
Faith's first, Love's chief; for 'tis a vertue great
God to believe, to love God's more compleat.

div.head: 167. If thy right Eye, &c. Mat. 5.29.
div.l: If the Right Eye, by sinning oft, must out,
The world would suddenly be blind no doubt.

div.head: 168. Christian Adverbs.
div.l: Adverbs all Adjectives do far excel:
God less rewards good Deeds, than Deeds done well.

div.head: 169. Lifes Brevity.
div.l: T' an unborn Infant, and an old man dead
Time's all alike, that's future, this is fled:
Abate time past, abate the time to come
From both, how little then's Lifes total Summ.

div.head: 170. Like for like.
To Aulus.
div.l: Thy Predecessors Facts thou dost not read:
Strange if Posterity read thine, when dead.

div.head: 171. Time.
div.l: Time, things Devourer, us and all out-wears:
We wear out Time: and thus are we compeers.

div.head: 172. Abundant Caution.
div.l: Not temerous, nor timerous, nor late,
Art quickly wary, not precipitate:
Is nature fearful? Prudence strength prepares,
None danger fears, of danger that bewares.

div.head: 173. John opposing.
div.l: Though all Antiquities oppose thy sense,
Thou canst them all with one word (No) convince.

div.head: 174. Justification.
div.l: Do Faith or Facts sole justifie? declare
Facts Faith by God sole justified are.

div.head: 175. Doomsday.
div.l: When all for all their works shall t' answer come,
Sufficeth one day, for so great a Doom?

div.head: 176. To Marianus.
div.l: The Good hate sin, because they vertue love:
Few therefore now on Earth good men do prove:
Vice is so priz'd; Vertue so vile reputed,
That 'tis almost a sin to b' unpolluted.

div.head: 177. Mary Magdalens Tears.
div.l: Two fluent Fountains from two Mountains rise,
Whence flows a double River from mine Eyes.

div.head: 178. Of the Soul.
div.l: The Soul's from God, not drawn from mortal Line,
For with the Body then it would decline.

div.head: 179. To Marcus.
div.l: In Bed thou prayest with thy Face erect:
No wonder slothful Prayers want effect:
Such praying, as vain words of one not praying
God hears, as if he heard not, by gainsaying.

div.head: 180. Hell.
div.l: As Art black colours cannot turn to white,
So from dark Hell none can return to Light.

div.head: 181. To a poor Friend.
div.l: Is't bad? I would 'twere worse: for at the worst
Oft better things succeed than came at first.

div.head: 182. The Parts of the World.
div.l: The world though round is parted int' a Square,
Whereas four Parts, so Jews, Christians, Mahumetans, Pagans. four Religions are.

div.head: 183. The Causes of Discord.
div.l: Self-sense, Self-reason each man regulates;
Each his own will, his own Faith estimates:
Each wilful is: hence Brethren strive: the while
Will only wants all strifes to reconcile.

div.head: 184. The Liberal.
div.l: The just man gives unt' each his own; but thou
To Rich men theirs, to poor must thine allow.

div.head: 185. The Temperate.
div.l: He that things causes knows, with Times complies,
Calms his affects, orders his acts, is wise.

div.head: 186. The Wise.
div.l: Fate governs Fools, the wise more sublimate,
Themselves by wisdom govern not by Fate.

div.head: 187. Anonymus, an Infant dead before Baptiz'd.
div.l: What dead? Al is, unnam'd, and unbaptiz'd,
O Christ, I nameless must by thee b' agniz'd:
I' th' Book of Life without a Name me write,
For in thy name alone mine hope is scire.

div.head: 188. The Flatterer and Carper.
div.l: These differ not in Nature but in Name,
This Good, that Bad maligneth: Both to blame.

div.head: 189. Love and Friendship.
div.l: The knot of Friendship's to be broke for Love:
But Love for Friendship must not once remove.

div.head: 190. Peter and Paul.
div.l: The Sword keeps Kingdoms, Coyn the Keys, by which
Peter than Paul reputed is more rich.
Saint Paul in an Epistle saith he's poor:
Saint Peter no where doth his wants deplore.

div.head: 191. Socrates.
div.l: Thou nothing knowst, this one thing knowst, and this
One thing is something, something, nothing is.

div.head: 192. Man.
div.l: Born weeping, being born at first didst cry:
Thou then not pleas'd, why now displeas'd to die?

div.head: 193. To Paul inhum'd.
div.l: Thou naked cam'st to th' world from mothers womb,
With Shirt and Shroud returnst unto thy Tomb:
More than thou broughtst thou tak'st hence to thy Grave,
Thou giv'st thy mother more than she thee gave.

div.head: 194. To the Courtly Reader.
div.l: If much for School, for Court here's little, note
That this for Court, that for the School we wrote.

div.head: 195. Wise Simplicity.
div.l: That thou do wrong to none be like a Dove:
That none thee wrong, wise like a Serpent prove.

div.head: 196. The Common-Wealths Eyes.
div.l: Religion and Law conjoin, combine,
That curbs mens hearts, their hands this doth confine.

div.head: 197. To Doctor John Gifford a Learned Physician.
div.l: That in Apollo's Art thou skilful art,
No wonder, for thy parts thou knowst apart:
If Galen saith not this, yet wise Apollo
Saith, Know thy Self: his dictates thou dost follow.

div.head: 198. The Daw.
div.l: No Birds more loquent-eloquent than I:

div.head: The Goose.
div.l: But I write more than thou canst Crake, or Cry.

div.head: 199. Jobs Miseries.
div.l: Satan (the Lord permitting) did disrobe
Of Children, Wealth, and Health poor-poorest Job:
When all was gone, his wife did yet remain
Who vex'd him more than all his loss and pain.

div.head:
200. The Temples of
St. Paul in London.
St. Peter in Westminster.
div.l: At Peter's West th' Exchequer Law Courts are,
White-Hall the Princes Palace thence not far.
At Paul's the Preacher things divine declares,
And Stationers there vend their sacred Wares.
All things convene, here Paul, and Peter there:
Peter more rich, more learn'd doth Paul appear.

div.head: 201. Of the Conspirators in the Gun-Powder Treason upon Tuesday the Fifth of November 1605.
div.l: Heav'n to provoke from Earth, and from below
Upon the Gods above our threats to throw,
What is if this be not t' accumulate
On Ossa Pelion? to fabricate
The Tower Babel, old Troy new to burn,
And int' a Chaos all things to return.

div.head: 202. Of the same.
div.l: And would you Troynovant to Cinders turn
By the same Fate which Phrygian Troy did burn?
Unfit was Tuesday for such fatal Flashes,
Ash wednesday is the day design'd for Ashes.

div.head: 203. The King to Britain.
div.l: Fame brought a Rumour of my death to thee:
O do not credit Fame, but credit Me.

div.head: 204. To England of the uniting of Britain.
div.l: Concord intern-etern Crowns Britains Brow,
For her three Nations are united now:
Scotland with Shield, Wales doth like Walls immure
Thy Land, O England: thou maist rest secure.

div.head: 205. To Thomas Nevill, an hopeful Child.
div.l: Extract from Nevil's Noble Blood, the Grace
Of both thy Parents shines in thy sweet Face.
Their Natures, not sole Features thou shewst forth,
Thy Mothers Vertues, and thy Fathers worth.

div.head: 206. Upon the Death of Charles Blount, Earl of Devonshire 1606.
div.l: Whether with Eulogies, or Elegies,
With Praise, or Tears thy Death to solemnize
'Tis doubtful: divers men speak divers things:
Good speak the best, malignants wound with Stings.

div.head: 207. To the Reader.
div.l: Reader these Epigrams are short, and few:
For many if, though short, they long would shew:
Reader, these Epigrams are few, and short,
For few, if long, a many would import.

div.head: 208. Of speaking and writing:
div.l: Though words be living voices, writings dead,
Yet these survive, when those are vanished.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Books

div.p: EPIGRAMS OF John Owen AN OXONIAN AND CAMBROBRITAN.
A Single Book.
Dedicated To the most Learned Heroine the Lady ARBELLA STUART.
LONDON, Printed by R. White, for Nevil Simmons at the Sign of the Prince's Arms in St. Paul's Church-yard, and for Thomas Sawbridge at the three Flower-de-Luces in Little-Britain. 1677.

div.head: 1. To the Lady Arbella-Stuart.
div.l: ILlustrious Virgin, sprung from Regal Race,
Whose Real worth thy Royal Birth doth Grace.
He that his wits First-fruits thee gave, ev'n He
Doth tender render now new Fruits to Thee,

Upon thine A fair Altar.
Ara-Bella (as most fit)
I consecrate, I sacrifice my wit.

div.head: 2. To the same.
div.l: Thy constant Life doth from thy youth express
The Genius of thine Ingeniousness:
Adverse things quell thee not, nor prosp'rous swell
Thy Sails; thy front and mind are parallel:
And thy rare signal vertues are the cause
That none will think I flatter for applause.

div.head: 3. To his Book.
div.l: Before innum'rous Judges thou must plead,
Not one or two will censure when they read.
Perhaps unread thou shalt not censures flee:
And more Reprovers will than Readers be.

div.head: 4. Union, to the Britains, 1606.
div.l: Who, unless mad, will off'red Gold refuse?
Here's Union: This Pearl who will not choose?

div.head: 5. Vacuity.
div.l: The Ethicks of vacuities complain,
But Physicks shew that nothing's made in vain.

div.head: 6. On Zoilus.
div.l: Zoilus is torn with an eternal Verse,
Though e're two thousand years he lies on's Hearse.
Is it because his heirs do never die,
He's punish'd for his whole Posterity?

div.head: 7. From the Center to the Circumference.
div.l: Not from the Center to th' Circumference
Sole one Line's, yet but one way t' Heaven's hence.

div.head: 8. Cock-Crowing, to the Prince.
div.l: France felt and did our English Forces see,
No Gallick sound could make our Lion flee.

div.head: 9. Of Quintus.
div.l: Money's a Noun, a Verb, to promise: he
Promis'd a Noun, but gave a Verb to me.

div.head: 10. Three Dimensions on Battologus.
div.l: Of three Dimensions thou but one dost sound,
That's broad enough, too long, but not profound.

div.head: 11. To the Reader.
div.l: As after sev'ral Births a womans womb,
Past Fifty, fruitless, childless doth become:
So my three former Books of better strain
Have stupifi'd, and arifi'd my brain.

div.head: 12. To Simon Waterson, Stationer.
div.l: Kind Waterson, who first my Book didst take,
And undertake it publick for to make:
Though Monopolies Laws against arise,
Yet thou shalt all my wit Monopolize.

div.head: 13. The Sea.
div.l: Salt Meats cause thirst: what's salter than the Seas?
Fresh waters therefore are drank up by these.

div.head: 14. The Solstice, of Ponticus an Atheist.
div.l: Death is Life's Solstice: the Sun seems t' our Eyes
To stand, but stands not: man to die, not dies.

div.head: 15. To his Book.
div.l: My little Book by me forewarn'd, forearm'd,
Observe at Court to keep thy self unharm'd.
Perhaps thou there maist find some one thy friend,
And some perchance that thee will reprehend;
If any be too rigid, too severe,
Say thus, My Master blame, but me forbear.

div.head: 16. Courtship, to his Friend a Courtier.
div.l: Loves thee the King? his Page will then thee love,
As Shadows when the Bodies move, do move:
Frowns but the King? his Page will on thee frown,
As Shadows Bodies when the Sun's gone down.

div.head: 17. On Corbulo.
div.l: Why's Corbulo so bald upon his Pate
For want of hair? was it his fault or fate?

div.head: 18. To Pontilian.
div.l: Pontilian, thee Christ'pher sues at Law •
Not thee, but money 'tis from thee to draw.

div.head: 19. To Sir Edward Herbert, Knight,
div.l: Fame whisper'd that thou didst commend my Layes:
O that I could but equalize this praise?
Thou who dost praise this slender Muse of mine,
Dost merit to be prais'd by th' Muses Nine.

div.head: 20. Envies Genealogie, to J. H.
div.l: Vertue brings Envy forth, brought forth defends:
From vertue this one-only Vice descends:
Know'st why to thee this Epigram I write?
Thou maist of right expect pale Envyes spight.

div.head: 21. Of Vertue, a Paradox.
div.l: Each vertue 'twixt two vices hath its place:
If vice were plac'd there, better were the case.

div.head: 22. The Seven Planets, to Paula.
div.l: Among th' Erratick Stars thou well didst mark
Five Males, two Females wandring in the dark.

div.head: 23. To Marcus.
div.l: More than thy Promise thou must keep, not less:
Hence but one Tongue, two Hands thou dost possess:
But thou dost promise much, performest none,
As if thou two Tongues hadst, and Hands not one.

div.head: 24. A Roman Priest.
div.l: Would'st have Adultery not punished
By death? no wonder: th' art unmarried.

div.head: 25. A Minister of Geneva.
div.l: Would'st have Adultery have loss of Life?
No wonder: for thou hast a buxom Wife.

div.head: 26. Self-loving Poet.
div.l: The Moon because of her vicinity,
Though least, seems greatest Planet in our Eye:
So, sith I'm next my self, my self the best
I think of Poets, though I am the least.

div.head: 27. Of a penurious Client.
div.l: Wonder'st the Judges Ears are shut to thee,
When unto them thine hands not open be?

div.head: 28. Of a certain Ass.
div.l: That I thee call, not name an Ass, dost grieve?
We Names unt' Horse, not unt' Asses give.

div.head: 29. Of the Picture in the Looking-glass.
div.l: Thou smiling, there thine Image seems to smile,
And while thou weep'st, it seems to weep the while.
It winks, thee winking, it thee moving moves:
But though thou speak'st, thine Image speechless proves.

div.head: 30. Glaucus Change.
div.l: His Birth-right Esau unt' his brother sold:
Jacob his Pottage for it gave, not gold.

div.head: 31. Of Asellus a Dreamer.
div.l: Thou sleeping art inspir'd with Mysteries,
Which waking are concealed from thine Eyes:
O how would Death inform thee, sith that sleep,
Deaths Image, prompteth thee with things so deep?

div.head: 32. Wales and Kent.
div.l: Wales keeps, though not its name, its ancient Nation:
Kent keeps its name, but not its first Plantation.

div.head: 33. Heauton-timoroumenos, Self-vexing.
div.l: Angels not having Bodies happy are.
And the brute Beasts which Reason want, want care;
Sole man, who soul and body doth possess,
Is wretched, knows and feels his wretchedness:
Yea ev'ry man hath Menedemus Fates,
Whom Reason ruinates, not regulates.

div.head: 34. Of Linus.
div.l: Thou bound wert to me, when I did thee lend▪
Wilt have me bound to thee? my Coyn repend.

div.head: 35. Single Life.
div.l: If Heaven to Good works be ascrib'd as Merit,
Thy Single Life hath wherewith Heav'n t' inherit.

div.head: 36. The Creation.
div.l: In the beginning God made Heaven, Earth, Man.
Why? 'cause not to be sole he then began.

div.head: 37. Of Marcus.
div.l: Promise, thou sayst, makes rich: but I by thee.
Thy Promises shall never richer be.

div.head: 38. Of Aulus an Atheist.
div.l: When we with thee discourse of God and Heaven,
With thee who prizest God, at six and seven:
Thou sayst, what's us above concerns us not:
True: for the lowest hole in Hell's thy lot.

div.head: 39. Man a Stage-Player.
div.l: Hope is Lifes Argument (for Life's a Fable)
World, Scene: Faith, Prologue: Acts are Love unstable

div.head: 40. To the Reader.
div.l: Why am I in mine Epigrams so brief?
It is, O Reader, for thy sake in chief:
As Gold than Silver is more light to carry,
So than long Epigrams short make less weary.

div.head: 41. New Stile.
div.l: Wherefore doth Rome, which new things so detests,
So dotes on old, ordain new Fasts, new Feasts?

div.head: 42. To Marinus.
div.l: Motion's the praise of th' Heavens constant Station.
Earths glory fix'd upon a firm Foundation:
Whence to thee Phillis seems of heav'nly birth,
Still moveable, she nothing hath of Earth.

div.head: 43. Eves Fall.
div.l: The Sun's not oft: the Moon's oft in th' Eclipse:
So women are than men more prone to slips.

div.head: 44. Neither in this nor in the World to come, of Damianus.
div.l: Whether I present things, or future mind,
I none more wretched than thy self do find
Th' art wicked, future times will thee condemn,
A Fool th' art: present times do thee contemn.

div.head: 45. By wanting rather than having, to Ponticus.
div.l: Thou knowst what wit, what valour is, if by
Their want, one their true value may descry.

div.head: 46. Manslaughter.
div.l: One man himself may kill a thousand men:
But two can scarce beget one man agen.

div.head: 47. Friendship to his Friend.
div.l: Why seeks Likes like Friends friend? because that none
Can long stand stedfast on one foot alone.

div.head: 48. To Sir John Harington, son of the Lord Harington.
div.l: If vertue may be guess'd at by the front,
Thy Face hath wit and vertue stamp'd upon't:
And herein is thy Fathers wisdom seen,
That learned Tovey hath thy Tutor been:
Sith all this Isle of Britain, but a few
Tutors like him, Pupils like thee can shew.

div.head: 49. Polydore Virgil.
div.l: Two Virgils were; one Maro (soaring higher)
A Poet; next thou Polydore a Lyar.

div.head: 50. Upon Momus an unjust Censurer of the former Epigrams.
div.l: Among so many wicked then alive,
Had but Gomorrha found of just men five
It yet had stood.—
And thou, malignant Reader, for a few
Loose Lines, wouldst all the Structure overthrow?

div.head: 51. On the same.
div.l: One, whom I know not, infamous by Fame
Diana's Temple burn'd to get a Name:
So with black Teeth thou dost my Verses bite,
Hoping to have thy name in what I write:
But bite, backbite thy fill, I will deceive
Thine hopes, and thee without a name will leave.

div.head: 52. Upon a domestick Carper.
div.l: And me thy Brother, thou my Brother dear
Woundst with thy tongue, and with thy teeth dost tear.
Why dost maligne my Verse, if praise it merit?
If blame, to spare it 'twere a brothers spirit.

div.head: 53. A Cuckold.
div.l: Why for my Wives close Thefts am I (alas)
Traduc'd? men call me Cuckold as they pass,
And point at me: For what I did not sign
(But you, I know not who) I call not mine.

div.head: 54. A Self-Lover.
div.l: Love, like thy self, thy Neighbour, saith the Text:
I do, thou say'st, I to my self am next.

div.head: 55. Fortune assists the Bold.
div.l: Fair women are like Fortune: Neither she,
Nor they love men that slothful-bashful be.

div.head: 56. Love blind.
div.l: Love not too fierce at first hath large extent:
For slow things longer last than violent.
Lovers in hast, are like that breeding kind,
which like blind love, bring forth their younglings blind.

div.head: 57. Love not blind, to Firmicus.
div.l: Love is not blind: Argus to love is prone,
But Polyphemus, blinded loveth none:
Love's bred by Seeing: therefore Love's not blind,
Which through th' Eyes windows doth inflame the mind.

div.head: 58. To Quintus, a Courtier.
div.l: Ulysses fear, hast (Quintus) but one Eye?
An hundred hast? beware of Mercury.

div.head: 59. Epitaph of Justice.
div.l: E're since Astraea, last of heav'nly Race,
Abandon'd Earth, and took in Heav'n her place,
Laws Altars, Justice Temples are forsook,

And t' each his Jus signifies
Right.
Pottage.
Jus to give, sole knows the Cook.

div.head: 60. Of Marcus, skulking.
div.l: Wisely th' art hid, if hid thine hiding were:
But open thy close hiding doth appear.

div.head: 61. Jesus Colledge, and Christ Church Colledge in Oxford not fully Finished 1607.
div.l: Jesus, one House unfinish'd bears thy Name,
And Christ, thou hast another like the same:
Among so many Noble Structures, those-
Thy two, thy former Poverty disclose.

div.head: 62. Merchants Trust.
div.l: Poor Irus paid rich Croesus all: now which
Is of the greater credit, Poor or Rich?

div.head: 63. Muses most sad.
div.l: Shorne is Apollo now, unshorne e're while:
Scarce in a year doth our Apollo smile.
O he mistook who call'd the Muses merry:
Phoebus his Harp's untun'd, his hand is weary.

div.head: 64. Incredulity.
div.l: Credulity's an errour, not a fault;
Too much an errour is too little, naught.

div.head: 65. Credulity.
div.l: Him I distrust, who trusteth all by guess:
The more thou me, I credit thee the less.

div.head: 66. Faiths Obsequiousness, to young men.
div.l: I like Pythagoras his Discipline
Which seven years Tryal did for Trust assign:
Wilt have th' unlearn'd thee trust? th' learn'd trust rather:
Wilt have thy son thee trust? trust then thy Father.

div.head: 67. Better to give than receive.
div.l: God giveth, man receiveth (and doth bow)
Never, I think, were fewer Gods than now.

div.head: 68. Of Ponticus, a Client.
div.l: Thy Gout's i' th' hand, thy Lawyer dost not Fee,
His is in's Feet, he moves no Foot for thee.

div.head: 69. Tho. Wolsey, I, and my King.
div.l: I, and my King with Grammer Rules comply:
Good Manners teacheth thus, My King and I.
This is the way to live, that to discourse,
This in the Court, that in the School's of force.

div.head: 70. To the Gauls.
div.l: Each drinks in his own Glass, I like it well:
But who's content with his own wife to dwell?

div.head: 71. Philautus to Philaristus, Calend. January.
div.l: Thou lookst I should a Gift to thee commend,
I but my self have nothing else to send.

div.head: 72. Philaristus to Philautus.
div.l: Thou nothing sent'st, thy nothing I repell:
Thou gav'st thy self, I give thee back. Farewell.

div.head: 73. To Henry Fanshaw, Knight, 1606.
div.l: Augustus Empire had it been thy Fate
T' have had, or else Mecaenas his Estate,
In these our times had many Maro's been,
Now no Mecaenas, nor no Maro's seen.

div.head: 74. To Henry Good-yeer, Knight, upon his Wifes Decease, 1606.
div.l: Men to command, women t' obey, to bear
Nature injoynes: thy Wife did both, while here
Sh' obey'd, she bare sweet Pledges, hopeful Sons,
Which props support the Ports of greatest Dons.
O happy Good-yeer thrice, four times and more,
If one as good succeed as went before.

div.head: 75. Ulysses and Penelope.
div.l: Death's t' us Ulysses-like when snatch'd from's Wife:
As she her Thread, so we spin out our Life.

div.head: 76. Of Mancinus an Artless Master.
div.l: Thou the whole day from Street to Street dost walk,
Yet lest thou shouldst be thought thy Book to baulk,
Thou sleep'st at night by Candle-light: thine Oyl
Mancinus thou wilt lose, but not thy Toyl.

div.head: 77. Upon a certain woman.
div.l: Though thy two sons be both unlike to thee,
Each yet with's Fathers likeness doth agree.

div.head: 78. The Celestial Archer, to William Ravenscroft, J. C.
div.l: Thine Arrow, Faith: Bow, Love: thy Bow-string, Hope:
Let Heaven be thy Mark, and God the scope.

div.head: 79. Ponderous things descend.
div.l: No Creature in the World is more sublime
Than Man, why must he slabber in the slime?
Of th' Elements, of what's the World within
The solid Earth most pond'rous is, save sin.
What wonder then that man is downward prest?
Sith man is nothing else but sin at best.

div.head: 80. Of a litigious Debtor.
div.l: Thou dost not pay me, dost the Lawyer pay:
Thy Folly this, that doth thy Fault display.

div.head: 81. Of the same.
div.l: Thy care is not to pay thy Debts: thy care
Is not to pay thy Debts what e're they are.

div.head: 82. Of the Church Derivative.
div.l: Sith that there's but one Faith, one Church that's true,
Sprung from the Fount of Life; within the new
Jerusalem, what Church doth not derive
It self from thence, erres from the Primitive.

div.head: 83. Four Seas.
div.l: Britain's Trine-like, Triangular: why be
Four Seas therein, and yet but Kingdoms three?

div.head: 84. To a Rich Friend.
div.l: If by the want of things their worth is known,
I know the worth of Wealth, for none's mine own.

div.head: 85. The Generation of one is the corruption of two.
div.l: The male and female, in the course of nature,
Corrupt two bodies to produce one Creature.

div.head: 86. The Wedding Ring.
div.l: A Ring at Nuptials the Bridegroom gave
The Bride in sign of Love: a custom grave.
The wife should rather give the Ring to th' man:
Let him reach out his Finger for it than.

div.head: 87. The Worlds of Democritus.
div.l: If Worlds so many were, as doth attest
Democritus, this were the worst o' th' rest.

div.head: 88. Of Epigrams to the Reader.
div.l: An Epigram is like a fair-fac'd woman,
Which is, because more beautiful, more common:
But common once her beauty's out of date,
And then Adulterers it nauseate.

div.head: 89. The Earth.
div.l: The Heavens, though in motion, constant prove,
For with the self-same motion still they move:
But th' Earth is most inconstant, though fast fixt,
Each Angle of it is with Errors mixt.

div.head: 90. The Moon.
div.l: Cynthia th'art call'd the Star that rules the Seas,
Thou rather rulest now the Land than these.

div.head: 91. Covetous Liberality, to Acerra.
div.l: Thou giv'st to take, not tak'st to give Acerra:
Thy mark's Receiving, Giving is thine Arrow.

div.head: 92. Of Paula, a false Catholick.
div.l: If any ask of Paula, what's her Faith,
'Tis Catholick, Apostolick she saith.
I think her love is Catholick unt' all;
But I would have her Faith Catholical.

div.head: 93. A Prodigy.
div.l: Penelope's chast trust a Proverb was:
But for a Prodigy it now may pass.

div.head: 94. Of Annetta, a Franck.
div.l: Nature with very little is content:
But of thy Nature this I think's not meant.

div.head: 95. Of Marcus a Souldier, blind and blear-cy'd.
div.l: One of thine Eyes doth, Marcus, yet remain,
Which with continual drops thy Face doth slain:
Why is that Eye with Tears so much im • ost?
Because his Brother in the Wars was lost.

div.head: 96. Peace in Europe, to Divines.
div.l: Kings war; and Kings in peaceful Leagues combine:
'Tis something yet t' enjoy sweet peace in Fine:
The Priests with an immortal strife contend;
And their contests nor measure have, nor End.
Hence by Tongues virulence it doth appear
That than the Sword, the Pen is more severe.

div.head: 97. To Carolina.
div.l: As oft as in the Glass thou view'st thy face,
Lest that thy beauty make thee proud, abase-
Abate thy Pride: think though th'art fair (alas)
Th' art fraile, though beautiful yet like thy Glass.

div.head: 98. Florals.
div.l: As in the Scene obscene came Cato, thence
To go: so man comes here, to pass from hence:
And never to come hither from his Urne,
As Ca • o to the Scene did not return.

div.head: 99. Man's Epitaph.
div.l: Who lies here? no man: no man here doth lie:
A liveless Corps doth not a man imply.

div.head: 100. The Souls Horizon.
div.l: Th' high Elements we see not, Fire and Air:
Water and Earth we see, the lower pair:
So we know men and beasts with us below:
But God and th' Angels (ah) we do not know.

div.head: 101. The Souls Eclipse.
div.l: As th' Earth 'twixt Sun and Moon doth stand we see
In her Eclipse: so sin 'twixt God and me.

div.head: 102. A Merchant.
div.l: Plautus a Tale, the Merchant call'd, compil'd:
The next, like it, is the Deceiver stil'd.

div.head: 103. Worshipper: of Images.
div.l: Who Grandees honour, Idolize: 'tis clear:
Sith woman mans, man doth Gods Image bear.

div.head: 104. Erasmus his desire.
div.l: Erasmus Desiderius I could
Desire; who sole might write what e're he would?

div.head: 105. A Neuter.
div.l: Pompey and I, if Pompey win the Field:
If Caesar, then to Caesar I will yield.

div.head: 106. Scandalizing Grandees, to the Servants of Servants.
div.l: The Master saith, I will my Servant have
To be still faithful: how? my Goods to save.
Stand, watch, go, come: perform the most th' art able,
Th' art yet a Servant, but unprofitable.

div.head: 107. Mars and Venus.
div.l: Venus and Mars themselves alike extend,
Mars common Foe, Venus a common Friend.

div.head: 108. February.
div.l: Thou sole of many Brothers, not one other,
Hast eight and twenty daies, most like thy mother.

div.head: 109. To E. J.
div.l: Thy modesty thee (vertue like) doth praise,
I to thy wit, with leave, would Tropheys raise:
But O thy modest Face, and candid spirit
Cause me to praise thee less than is thy Merit.

div.head: 110. A Circles Square.
div.l: What is a Circles Square? but this alone,
Th'Earth parted in four parts, at first but One.

div.head: 111. Whether an Arithmetical unite answereth to a Geometrical Point.
div.l: God than a Point is more, yet is but One:

Like as a Point doth differ from a Unity.
Mone.

div.head: 112. From the Womb to the Tomb.
div.l: Man's born to death most certain, which comes on,
As a lean Ox feeds to be fed upon.

div.head: 113. To the King.
div.l: O of what Force Example's in a King?
Actest? thou bidst: forbearst? forbidst the thing.
A Prince moves principal; a King doth steer.
As Skyes the Stars, so Kings the People bear.

div.head: 114. The Head and Body, to the same.
div.l: Reason's i' th' Head, there its five Agents • bide:
Little's Divine in the whole Man beside.

div.head: 115. Report of the Death of Henry 4. the French King: To the French King.
div.l: What Kings to hear, and Servants fear to tell,
Fame sounds i' th' Ear, To die remember well.

div.head: 116. Light and Air.
div.l: Air, though a Body, is unseen with th' Eye:
Light hath no body, yet is seen on high.

div.head: 117. One God, many Friends.
div.l: Though no man can two Masters serve as slave,
What hinders but two Patrons one may have?
One God forbids not to seek many friends,
As one Faith many Arts not discommends.

div.head: 118. Donna, Danno.
div.l: Adam a Rib lost for the womans sake:
And for her sake he laid his Soul at stake.

div.head: 119. Womens Tire.
div.l: This is more like an house than cov'ring: this
Is not to deck, t' erect the Head it is.

div.head: 120. All things Nothing.
div.l: All things who made of Nothing, He's sole All:
What God of Nothing made, we Nothing call.

div.head: 121. The East and Western Church.
div.l: The right-true Faith i' th' Worlds left Part resounds:
Faith sinister i' th' Worlds right Part abounds.

div.head: 122. Anger, Patience.
div.l: Ire minds inflames, and Patience cools that Ire:
As Fire doth temper water, water fire.

div.head: 123. Ruine of Heaven and Earth.
div.l: Th' Earth lowest is, Heav'n highest is of all:
Yet that hath whither, this no where to fall.

div.head: 124. To Henry Howard, Earl of Northampton.
div.l: Ally'd unt' one, Uncle to two great Counts,
Of great Account, thy Fame thy Name surmounts:
Of many Noble Dukes sprung from the Stemm,
Ones Brother; Nephew unto three of them;
An Earls son, who (but Fates did not so please)
Had been the fourth Duke in this Series:
An Earl thy self: None wonders at thy Fates,
Whom wit conducts, Fortune concomitates!

div.head: 125. To Pontia.
div.l: I from thy sight, which wounds mine Heart, remove,
Not that I love thee not, but that I love.

div.head: 126. To an Adulterer.
div.l: Adam in Eden was forbid to taste
One Fruit, the rest were all for his Repast.
I wonder, having so much at command,
That He from One could not withhold his hand.
Thou contrary, art All forbid but One,
That thou may'st use, the rest must let alone.
Less strange, than Adam, that thou didst decline,
Whose Liberty was greater far than thine.

div.head: 127. To the Reader.
div.l: Salt meats cause thirst: O that my verses might
The Reader cause to thirst with Appetite.

div.head: 128. To an Uxorious Man.
div.l: Let not thy Wife command, give if she crave;
Make not thy Wife thy Master, nor thy Slave.

div.head: 129. To Ponticus.
div.l: Thy Life's a Comick, Death a Tragick Story;
Unlike thy Death will be to thy Life's Glory.

div.head: 130. Of a certain married Priest.
div.l: A Levite born, a Levite made, thy Wife
Of Levi's Tribe, Levitical's thy Life.

div.head: 131. Of Innovators.
div.l: You pull down All Things, No Thing you rebuild,
Are you with Zeal, or fiery fury fill'd?
The Spirit, you pretend, doth you compell;

What Spirit is't? Apoc. 9.11. A bad one.
Abaddon, One from Hell.

div.head: 132. Of Cotta.
div.l: God out of Nothing, All things did Create,
Thou Chymist All things dost Annihilate.

div.head: 133. Tho. Egerton Chancellour of England, and Francis Leigh his Son-in-law.
div.l: • any Vertue loves, and Honours Arts,
• hat Father, and this Son act both these parts:
• ave Egerton, Brave Leigh the Muses love,
• he Son would not unlike the Father prove.

div.head: 134. Consubstantiation.
To the same Francis, and Mary his Wife.
div.l: You have not both one Soul, but both one Mind,
Nor both one Body, but one flesh conjoyn'd:
Man, Wife, in name are two, but one in Troth,
They diff'rent are in Sex, but humane both.

div.head: 135. Funeral Sermons.
div.l: Good men are wrong'd while living, prais'd when dead;
O black Life, O Death candid-honoured.

div.head: 136. Paul's Cross, and the Cross in Cheap, in the Parish of St. Peter.
div.l: Why's Peter's Golden, Paul's a Leaden Cross?
Why, because Golden words Paul's Cross ingross.

div.head: 137. Loves Chronicle.
div.l: A Moment multipli'd amounts t' an Hour,
A Day's made up with Hours twenty four:
Days many make a Month, twelve Months a year:
So, with more Times, my Love doth more appear.

div.head: 138. Twins.
div.l: Nothing's unlike in us, all's like; sole we
Differ in number, we two Bodies be.

div.head: 139. Friends.
div.l: We scarce in number differ: Two we be,
Yet One: You Twins in Body, In Mind we.

div.head: 140. Of the Art of Love.
div.l: Though Naso's Art of Love some prove-approve,
Yet men unexpert know not what is Love:
Love is by Nature taught, not learn'd by Art,
By th' Eyes, not Ears, Love enters int' our Heart.

div.head: 140. Seneca the Philosopher.
div.l: Thy Dictates seem like Epigrams almost,
But that in Numbers they be not ingrost.

div.head: 141. To Attalus.
div.l: Thou saidst once at thy Table (as I take it,)
Thou didst not relish Salt, but didst forsake it:
For Salt thou needst not care, nor is't a fault,
All, almost, that thy Tongue doth speak, is Salt.

div.head: 142. Sir Philip Sidney's Life.
div.l: Who while they liv'd writ Books deserving Fame,
Their Lives need not he writ, there lives their Name:
The Corps, not Life of Sidney's in the Tomb,
His short Lifes longer Glory keeps more room.

div.head: 143. The Bodies Valediction to the Soul.
div.l: I for thy sake did Mother Earth forsake.

div.head: The Soul departing.
div.l: Fool, I left God my Father, to betake
My self to Thee: Now call'd, I t' him return;
And leave thee to thy Mother in thine Urn.
Till when (For we till then shall meet no more)
Th' Earth Thee to Me, God Me to Thee restore.

div.head: 144. A Kingdom divided.
div.l: Two Kingdoms undivided are, Heaven, Hell,
As in themselves: There Good, here Bad do dwell:
On Earth alone (oh shame) Division raigns,
Which Good and Bad promiscuously sustains.
But time will come when th' Earth shall lie divast,
When Heav'n and Hell shall both be fill'd at last.

div.head: 145. How Waters.
div.l: Tears prest-exprest do tacite Love declare,
Love Tears begets, Fire Water: Strange and Rare.

div.head: 146. Of Wit and Memory.
To Ponticus.
div.l: 'Tis ask'd, Why wit is called sharpness? Why?
Because what's sharp doth pierce more inwardly:
The Memory is to retain, not pierce,
Thus Vessels are made round, and with reverse.
Whence I supect that or thy Wit is round,
Or sharp thy Memory: Both unprofound.

div.head: 147. Comfort for the Poor.
To the Rich.
div.l: Inconstant Fortune various appears:
Whence Hopes arise to Me, to The • but Fears.

div.head: 148. Of Titius and Gellia.
div.l: One in disgrace did Titius upbraid
That's Wife, when first he took her, was no Maid.
What's that to Me, thus Titius repli'd,
She then was Semprones Daughter, not my Bride.

div.head: 149. The Heart.
div.l: Why in the left side rather than the right
Is Mans Heart plac'd? to Good 'cause opposite.

div.head: 150. The Flesh and Spirit.
div.l: God made mans Body first, and when created,
He with a living Soul it animated.
Hence the dull Body, doth, I think, deny
T' obey the Soul; pleads Seniority.

div.head: 151. The Innocents, Proto-Martyrs.
div.l: For Christ the Children suff'red death, before
Christ for the Children shed his precious Blood. Gore.

div.head: 152. To his Friend.
div.l: The Dual Number oft doth Friendship bound:
Scarce in the Plural Number Love is found.

div.head: 153. To a friend growing old. 1607.
div.l: Thou wert a youth, when I a Child: And now
Thou art grown old, while I a youth do grow:
Thee therefore Death expects, and Old Age Me;
Certain's thy lot, though mine uncertain be.

div.head: 154. Of A. G.
div.l: Thy Name and Face is Mans, Wit, Animals,
A Fool in Specie, learn'd in Generals.

div.head: 155. Harmony. To Divines.
div.l: Of Gospels Harmony have divers writ:
But who that Harmony? Great Labour's it.

div.head: 156. Dissonancy.
div.l: So great discordance doth abound with Men,
That what Souls Peace is, scarce knows One of Ten:
Here's Base, depress'd, There Elah too much rear'd,
That scarce the Tenor, or the Mean is heard.

div.head: 157. To Pontilianus.
div.l: Art jealous of thy Wife? Th' art wise in part:
But art not jealous? Then thou wiser art.
To watch thy Wife is vain: That wife loves best
That though can, will not raise her husbands Crest.

div.head: 158. To Porcia.
div.l: Art thou the Daughter of the Night, or Light,
Born in the Day, begotten in the Night?

div.head: 159. An Epitome of the Histories of his Time.
To Marianus.
div.l: We worse are than our Fathers, worser they
Than their Fore-fathers, apt to run astray:
If our Posterity prove worse than we,
Nothing can worse than our Poster'ty be.

div.head: 160. London.
To J. W. A London Gold-smith.
div.l: As Thames the Rivulets drinks up and drowns,
So London swalloweth the poorer Towns:
Though Thames with Flux, re-flux, Send and resend,
Its Floods to Sea, Th' art still a constant Friend.

div.head: 161. Debtor and Creditor.
To Will. Cawley, A London Merchant.
div.l: Though in my Book, thou find, if there thou look,
Thy Name, My Name, yet, is not in thy Book:
I owe thee nought but Love: Of this to thee
A Creditor and Debtor still will be.

div.head: 162. Fools and Dwarfs.
div.l: Though we be not accounted men of might.
Yet are we great mens sport, and their delight.

div.head: 163. To Pontilian.
div.l: Poor Irus still was careful, why? 'Cause poor.
Croesus was careful, why? For's wealth was more.
One's vex'd, because he wants a Wife, and thou,
Because thou hast a wife, art vexed now.

div.head: 164. Union.
To Married Britains.
div.l: One God and Union, the World supply,
Wedlock on Earth was the first Unity.

div.head: 165. The Elements War.
div.l: Though God created all things for mans sake,
Yet th' Elements against us Wars do make:
How many have (alas) been swept from hence
With the contagious Air, by Pestilence?
How near hath London felt the Trojan Flames?
How many have been drench'd and drown'd in Thames?
Earth stops her Fruits: Yet no man doth repent;
Though Heav'n with Tears, and Earth our sins lament:
Though th' Earth be mollifi'd with moistning showers,
Yet sin our stubborn hearts more-more obdures.

div.head: 166. An Epithalamy, To Tullia.
div.l: By day, Thou, the sole Object of my Sight,
Shalt be the Subject of my Love at Night.

div.head: 167. To Sextus, an Academian.
div.l: That thou mayst mind thy Grave before th' art dead,
'Tis said, by day thou mak'st for Night thy Bed.
That in Remembrance thou thy Death mayst keep,
Why dost not oftner go to Bed and Sleep?

div.head: 168. To his Beloved.
div.l: Thee known I love, I lov'd thee when unknown,
Fame then, thy Face hath made me now thine own:
I now know Love; I love, not lov'd: Yea, now
I know not to be lov'd, to love I know.

div.head: 169. The Younger Brother.
div.l: I m poor: My Parents Fault (not mine, nor other,)
Who did not me beget before my Brother.

div.head: 170. The Firmament.
div.l: Th' Earth stands unmov'd, standing there moves the Creature:
Heav'n moves, yet the fix'd Stars move not by Nature.

div.head: 171. The blessed Virgin.
div.l: Although the blessed Virgin we thee call,
Thou among women blessed art withal:
I profit nothing by thy Virgin vest,
But as a Mother, Me Thou profitest.

div.head: 172. Hope and Faith.
div.l: Faith is no Faith, unless but One, firm fixt:
Nor Hope is Hope, if not with doubts commixt.

div.head: 173. Novelty.
div.l: Reviv'd are many things which heretofore
Fell, and shall fall, though now they flourish more.
New things now please, but will not still, because
What's now new will wax old, and full of Flaws.

div.head: 174. Marcus his Looking-glass.
div.l: Why is thy Fool before thee still? (All-Ass,)
Thou view'st thy self in him, as in a Glass.

div.head: 175. To one Uxorious.
div.l: The Field's not alway plough'd: Thy Wife's a Field,
Yet she loves dayly to be duly till'd.

div.head: 176. To a Friend.
div.l: Four years, and more, praeter-plu-perfect past,
First sprung thy love, and then was rooted fast:
In vain thou now dost seek it to remove,
No new young Plant, an old grown Tree's thy Love.

div.head: 177. To Porphyrius.
div.l: We read that Christ wept twice, not laugh'd at all:
Why dost mans Nature Risible then call?

div.head: 178. To Pontilianus.
div.l: As a Blind Man, by Boy or Woman led,
Ways t' him unseen-unknown doth often tread:
So Venus or her Boy, thee blind in Love,
Hither and Thither lead, move and remove.

div.head: 179. Love is beyond all Exception.
To a certain Friend.
div.l: Though some new cause old Love may (chance) suspend,
I, by the Laws of Friendship, am thy Friend:
My Love's beyond Exception unto thee,
Except, thou lov'st not, as thou shouldst love me.

div.head: 180. Of Ponticus aged sixty years.
div.l: In all thy Life thou good hast done to none:
When wilt thou now begin? Thou sayst upon
My death, I all will to the poor bequeath:
Too late he's wise, that is not wise till death.

div.head: 181. Of Nigella, Candidated.
div.l: Rare Bird on Earth thou art, and Swan-like white,
White are thy Cloaths, thy Skin as black as night.

div.head: 182. Le Carneval de la vit.
div.l: Why doth the Soul abhor the Bodies death?
Fears that to die, when this hath lost its Breath?
Or doth it fear that after death remains
Unt' it short Judgement, but long lasting pains?
I doubt, this doth the Soul in death dismay,
That to the Flesh it cannot farewel say.

div.head: 183. Quintina's Praise.
div.l: Should I thee praise, thou then wouldst prouder be:
I praise thee not: Th'art proud enough I see.

div.head: 184. Earth's Son.
div.l: Heaven looks on us, and we must look on Heaven,
For Stars in Skies, God Eyes to thee hath given:
Thou scarce the thousandth part of Earth canst see:
Half Heaven yet is visible to thee.
Fool, why dost Earth prefer unt' Heaven rather,
But as some love their Mother more than Father.

div.head: 185. The lowest Species.
div.l: Though Mankind is the chief, yet him we call-
We account the lowest Species of all:
Heav'n hath but few: More men in Hell do lie,
Who mens unhappiness can then deny?

div.head: 186. Of Envy, a Paradox.
div.l: If Vertue did, Envy would less abound:
For where's more Vertue, there less Vice is found.

div.head: 187. James, of that Name, The sixth King of Scotland, The first of England, Happiness to Britain.
div.l: What hath been often wish'd, scarce hop'd for, came
'Twixt Hope and Fear unto thy royal Name:
King James, the first, the sixth of Regal Line,
Sice Ace, the best chance of the Dice was thine.

div.head: 188. To James the First, King of Great Britain, &c.
div.l: Thine Hand four Crowns, four Scepters doth command,
Four Languages are spoken in thy Land;
The Britains Language, though not one, their Heart
Is One, of thy three Kingdoms being part.
At first the Devil did mens hearts divide:
But God their Languages: And all for Pride.

div.head: 189. Kings and Prophets.
div.l: Out of his Countrey, no King rules in chief,
No Prophet in his Countrey gains Belief.

div.head: 190. Vertue.
div.l: A double Genius, (while transitory,)
Attends on Vertue, Good, Bad, Envy, Glory.

div.head: 191. Envy.
div.l: Envy corrodes mens praises (like a Slave)
As Worms corrode their Bodies in the Grave.

div.head: 192. Of Battus.
div.l: Thy many Queries I in brief respond,
Not 'cause so many, but 'cause foolish, fond.

div.head: 193. Sleep. Death.
div.l: Though in my sleep I seem as dead in sort,
Yet no part of my Life's the sweeter for't:
'Tis strange what should in Death so bitter be;
Sith Sleep, Deaths Image, is so sweet to me.

div.head: 194. The Triumvirs.
div.l: Clients unto the Lawyer go, because
Wealth, their chief Good's secured by the Laws:
In Sickness the Physician comes; next Wealth,
The second thing to be secur'd, is Health:
Divines, who first to have been sent for ought,
Come last unto the sick •• sent-unsought.

div.head: 195. Lovers Patience.
div.l: Lover, wouldst have thy wish? Be patient:
He that will live in Peace, must be content.

div.head: 196. Of a certain Grammaticaster.
div.l: Thou Letters knowst, a good Grammarian:
And nothing knowst but them; A learned man.

div.head: 197. To a pompous Dame.
div.l: Be like Men'laus, or Ulysses Wife,
If thou wouldst famous live beyond thy Life:
For Vice, not only Vertue doth survive:
Helen's, Penelope's Names are yet alive.

div.head: 198. Of Aulus, a Grandee.
div.l: Truth-telling Fools speak things to be concea • 'd,
But wise men see what's sit to be reveal'd:
Aulus to trust his Servants wits afraid,
Keeps four fools still about him, for their Aid.

div.head: 199. Gold from Dung.
div.l: Virgil from Ennius Dung did Gold extract:
What Virgils was, is now Physicians act.

div.head: 200. Loves Secret.
div.l: A Lover's seldom lov'd: Be loveless, if
Thou wilt not be belov'd, love then in chief.

div.head: 201. Mon Tout, To Marcia.
div.l: Oft thou me call'st all thine: That I deny,
All thine I am not; But thine, all am I.

div.head: 202. Of Quintus and Orus.
div.l: Quintus and Orus have of late declar'd
Themselves Papistical: On what regard?
That for their Faiths Antiquity: And this
For Novelty thereof a Papist is.

div.head: 203. Ariadne's Thread.
div.l: As Theseus by Ariadne's Thread▪
Was Led, so Men, One Faith to Truth doth lead.

div.head: 204. Of Wills and Vows.
div.l: In Testaments or Wills the Last must stand:
In Vows, if good, the first hath chief command.
When God created all things with one vote,
Two Wills or Testaments he made-he wrote.

div.head: 205. To a Covetous Friend.
div.l: The Covetous hath all himself, not giving:
He nothing hath Himself, but wants while living.

div.head: 206. To Ponticus, A Lawyer.
div.l: Part of thy Life thou to thy wife dost give,
Part to thy Client: When to th' self wilt live?

div.head: 207. Of Preachers and Players.
div.l: Preachers and Players check our crimes: With Tears▪
The Preachers, and the Players with their Jeers:
To that I wretched, foolish seem to this.
This numbers, and that ponders mine amiss.

div.head: 208. The Births of Christ, and J. Baptist.
div.l: John in the Summer, Christ in Winter came:
That did Baptize with Water; This with Flame:
Well did those Contraries, The two Baptisms of Christ and John. Floods, Flames convene:
Our Sins Fire purgeth, Water washeth clean.

div.head: 209. No Man is hurt but from himself.
div.l: None's free from Crimes, nor Discords: For most times
Our Discords are procur'd by our own Crimes.

div.head: 210. Upon a bawling Ass.
div.l: I do not call thee Momus, ev'ry Ass,
But that which the false Prophet Balaams was.
Not that which into Salem Christ did carry,
For this was mild and mute, but that contrary.

div.head: 211. Of his Heirs.
To the Lawyers.
div.l: None of his wife, but Adam, was secure,
And none but Eve, was of her husband sure:
In Wedlock the poor husbands sole defence,
And comfort is, in's Wife t' have confidence.

div.head: 212. An hollow Tooth.
div.l: The Fire, Me cast therein doth not consume,
But I am hollow made by Watrish Rheume.

div.head: 213. Vertues Praise.
div.l: As the Suns constancy consists in Motion,
So Vertue's force in Action hath best Notion.

div.head: 214. Aesop's Tongue.
div.l: No Member is, that doth to man belong
More Noble, or Ignoble, than the Tongue.

div.head: 215. To the Children of Winchester Colledge.
div.l: I am not what I was, once all for Plays;
A Child of Festivals and Holy-days.

div.head: 216. Wisdome leading, Fortune following.
Of Ancus.
div.l: If ill advice chance well, in vulgar Eyes;
Ancus the Fool, shall be reputed wise:
If good advice come by mischance to nought,
Wise Cato shall himself a Fool be thought.

div.head: 217. Grief.
div.l: Loss present's to be griev'd for We bemoan;
Past, ah, too late, and future loss too soon.

div.head: 218. Vicissitude.
div.l: Mirth, Mourning ends, and Mourning Mirth concludes,
Hope, Fear, w'are various by Vicissitudes.

div.head: 219. To Germanicus.
div.l: Thy Wife hath rais'd the Number of thy Friends,
This her fertility in part commends:
This Benefit in Wedlock doth accrew,
A new Wife gains new Friends, and Friendship new.

div.head: 220. Armed Wickedness.
Of Linus.
div.l: As the best Wine makes Vinegar most tart,
So the more witty, thou more wicked art.

div.head: 221. Opinionist.
div.l: How, ah, Opinion reigns the World thoughout:
The Truth I know not, yet I must not doubt.
Who doubteth errs not: Yet for both prepar'd:
Error b' Opinion, not by doubt's declar'd.

div.head: 222. Alma Mater Academia Oxonia.
Fair Mother Oxford University.
div.l: Nature was Mother of my Brain, Thou Now:
She dura Mater, pia Mater Thou.

div.head: 223. The Poet.
The Grandee.
div.l: What more than words can I from Poets have?

div.head: 224. Man is to Man a God.
div.l: A Man's a Man, though he but sparing lives:
A Wolf that spoils, a God who freely gives.

div.head: 225. Homer.
div.l: If that be true, which some of thee do write,
Thou never sawst, thy Books yet see the Light.

div.head: 226. Three Secretaries.
div.l: Thou must to th' Lawyer thy whole case untwist,
To th' Doctor thy Disease, thy Sins to th' Priest.
If thou respect'st thy Soul's and Body's weal,
Nothing from this Triumvirate conceal.

div.head: 227. To D. C. G.
div.l: The Gout thee vexeth, and a pest contrary:
Thy Wife makes thee to run, the Gout to tarry.

div.head: 228. Ubiquitaries.
div.l: All th' Earth's before the poor, where e're he roam
He's never exil'd, ever is at home.

div.head: 229. Lovers.
div.l: Love is in us, as in the Wood is Fire;
As Fire the Wood, Love burns us with desire:
But Fire in Air, Wood t' Ashes doth consume:
We Ashes are; And what's our Love but fume?

div.head: 230. Speech.
div.l: A Speech is like to Grief, is like to sport:
If long, 'tis trivial, if grave, 'tis short.

div.head: 231. On an esseminate old man.
div.l: Bacchus old age, Venus doth youth ingage,
This therefore fit for youth, and that for age.

div.head: 232. On Harpalus, a covetous Youth.
div.l: The World thy Friendess is, wretch thou t' adore it.
That's old, thou youthful, 'tis enough t' abhorr it.

div.head: 233. To the Reader.
div.l: Who writes, is fam'd of these, is blam'd of those;
Himself to censure still he doth expose:
He daily pleads his cause, desisteth Never,
And, Reader, unto Thee, the Judge is ever.

div.head: 234. Of a Looking-glass.
div.l: Thou gav'st m'a Glass my Face to represent:
One to present thy Face would more content.

div.head: 235. Of Quintia, a Hypocrite.
div.l: Learn'd, Comely, youthful, fair, Benign and Chast
Thou, if not proud of these, some Goodness hast.

div.head: 236. A Probleme.
div.l: The Prodigal the Miser doth detest.
Why then do Misers Prodigals love best?

div.head: 237. Sleep. Venus.
div.l: Shall I you call Death's Sisters, or Allies,
Thou pleasing Venus, Thou Sleep, easing Eyes?
You both indulge your Selves on Beds to lie:
And Feds are made your Pleasures to supply.
Dull Sleep, lewd Venus hate the light: And this
Is the Souls Death, the Senses Death that is.

div.head: 238. Lifes length and shortness.
div.l: To sloathful men the Day, Night, Month and Year
Seem long, though posting on with swift career.
We trifle out our long-thought time in vain,
Why of Life's shortness do we then complain?

div.head: 239. The Treasury.
div.l: Birds are with Bird-lime caught, both young and old:
So Treasuries like Lime-twigs catch our Gold.

div.head: 240. To self-loving Ponticus.
div.l: Thy mind and Eye, themselves did never see.
That thou so lov'st thy self, how can it be?

div.head: 241. Scrutiny.
div.l: O, that what Christ unt' his Disciples spake,
Prince, Priest and people would their Query make;
What do men say of me? This askd, in th' end
Men would their Errors see, and them amend.

div.head: 242. Light of Grace.
div.l: The Moon enlight'ned by the Sun doth shine.
So shines the Soul inspir'd with Grace divine.

div.head: 243. Fame. Error.
div.l: Rumours and Errors further going; grow
Greater and greater like a Ball of Snow.

div.head: 244. Historical Tradition of King Brutus, To William Camden.
div.l: Books may be burn'd, and Monuments may lie
Demolished; thy works and mine may die:
But a Tradition National, alive
While is that Nation, will in force survive.

div.head: 245. To Roger Owen, A Learned Knight.
div.l: Thou knowst the Britains Laws, their old, new Rites,
And all that their whole History recites:
In thy Discourse, Th' art so profoundly read,
A living Library seems in thine Head.

div.head: 246. On a Covetous Man.
div.l: Thou wretched man, why for a thousand year
Provid'st, and canst not live one hundred here?
Why such vast sums of Moneys up dost heap,
And seek'st long Joys in this short life to reap?
Thou sayst; I one day shall be rich, if I
Live close? Why sayst not, I shall one day die?

div.head: 247. One Foot in the Grave.
div.l: We live upon Deaths shore, our life's as near
To death, as Seas unto the Shores appear:
Life, Death; are almost one thing in repute,
As Earth and Water one Globe constitute.

div.head: 248. Britains Mercury. To J. H.
div.l: Of mundane things Moore wrote the best, and good:
Thou writ'st the worst, but Truth, if understood.

div.head: 249. Of Himself.
div.l: Some say I am no Poet, 'tis no lye:
For I write nothing else but verity.

div.head: 250. To William Butler Physician at Cambridge.
div.l: Some to desired Health preferr their Wealth;
Thou sleightest Wealth, thy care's for cure, for Health.
Thee the Physician, let none despair
Of Health, that's sick: Physick, as Phoebus Heir,
Thou giv'st: I flatter not, the truth I speak;
Nor comes this Praise from one that's Sick, or weak.

div.head: 251. To Paulus, A Lawyer.
div.l: Why calls the common Law a Relict, her
Whose husband's dead? to th' wedded that referr:
No need, a Wife her husbands death expect,
To lodge in mournful Bed with Face erect.

div.head: 252. The last Divorce.
div.l: If man to Bliss, to Dis wife pass away,
Or contrary; No more one flesh are they.

div.head: 253. The World.
div.l: The Earth is like a Gaol, like Walls the Skies,
The Gaoler's Sin, the Fetters Womens Eyes.

div.head: 254. Laws Nullity.
div.l: We many Laws have made, almost not any:
For if not any kept, what good's so many?
That Laws be kept, this one Law more ordain,
Which if soon marr'd will soon be made again.

div.head: 255. The state of man.
