div.l: If one Foot down, Then th' other is above:
Thus one mans Fall, anothers Rise doth prove.

div.head: 256. To a certain Man.
div.l: Doctor beginning, O begin to be
Now Ductior: more learn'd for thy degree.

div.head: 257. Beside Women and Children.
div.l: Read through the sacred writ, though they surmount,
Mat. 14.21. Women and Children pass not in account:
Women and Children are not Officers,
Nor are they trained up, or arm'd for wars:
Women and Children for their Garments have
Long Coats, they beardless are, and never shave:
Women and Children will Tears quickly shed,
And are by Flatterers soon led-misled.
O with what Arts do you man-kind destroy
Thou woman Venus, Cupid thou, her Boy?

div.head: 258. A Nose of Wax.
div.l: Do sacred Scriptures promise good unt' us?
Our Faith believes it, soon is credulous.
Do they require our duty? Then, O then
'Tis durus sermo, difficult for men.

div.head:
259. Heavens Ladder. 1 Cor. 13.8.13.
y
t
h i
t r e
i a p
a h o
F C H
div.l: Three Vertues, as by steps, ascend int' Heaven,
Good Hope by four, by five Faith, Love by seven.
Hope to the Moon, Faith doth to th' Sun aspire,
But Charity to th' highest Heav'n, and higher.

div.head: 260. Of Battus.
div.l: Thy Tongue thine Heart interprets, let thine Heart
Be silent, e're thy Tongue thy Mind impart.
Th' interpreter must silent stand, as long
As the Embassadour doth use his tongue.

div.head: 261. The Praise of the Ass.
Be ye not like an Horse or Mule which have no understanding.
div.l: With Horse and Mule, why was not th' Ass brought on?
Because he was to carry David's Son.

div.head: 262. A pair of impair Courtiers. The Carper, the Parasite.
div.l: They well agree not, nor keep equal ways,
This all things praiseth, that doth nothing praise.

div.head: 263. Four causes of man.
div.l: What is Mans form, but a bad mind, vain will?
What Principle Material? But Nily.
Suspect not matter with the form, respect
Th' Efficient and End: On these reflect.

div.head: 264. The last Line.
div.l: Sad Death is of a merry Life last Act;
A serious Life doth Joys in Death attract.

div.head: 265. Upon the Death of Rich. Vaughan Bishop of London, 1607.
div.l: I who thee living did most justly praise,
Well knowing that thy worth deserv'd the Bays,
Ah, thee now dead, why praise I not more full?
Joys did my wit make brisk, Grief makes it dull.
While with more Tears, than Verse, I found thy knell,
My Tears confound my Verse, my words: farewel.

div.head: 266. Of Life and Death.
div.l: One way to Life, to Death a thousand's had;
'Tis well Death is a good thing, Life a bad.

div.head: 267. Of decrepit Paul, A Builder.
div.l: Thou build'st an House, wherein to die, not dwell:
Whether thine House, or Tomb, thou canst not tell.

div.head: 268. Of Sextus, a Prodigal Robber.
div.l: We thee confess Munificent, who thine
Not only giv'st, but tak'st from me, what's mine.

div.head: 269. On Zoilus.
div.l: Thou spar'st the Dead, the Living dost envy:
I will not therefore wish my self to die.

div.head:
270. A Pair Royal of Friends. To the
English-Scots, Britains.
Scots-Welsh, Britains.
Welsh-English Britains.
div.l: In friendship this doth seem a royal pair,
When three between, one love commands the Chair:
To make a pair in Love; if there be three,
Each of the three must then twice numbred be.

div.head: 271. A Kingdom divided.
div.l: This world hath nothing pertinent: And this-
World cannot stand, because divided 'tis.

div.head: 272. The Ring of Concord, To the Britains in Parliament, 1607.
div.l: Scotland the Jewel brings, to make the Ring,
England the Gold, the Goldsmith is the King:
Speed Europes Peace, lest else the Ring-like year,
Before the Ring be finish'd, disappear.

div.head: 273. Britain.
div.l: As thou wert i' th' Beginning, now as then,
So, O so be, World without End: Amen.

div.head: 274. Steganography. To the curious Reader.
div.l: Why, that my Verses are obscure, dost say,
Not well to b' understood without a Key?
An Epigrammatist must not dilate:
'Tis therefore fit he should abbreviate.

div.head: 275. One God.
div.l: One Adam was the Father of all Men:
Nor can there be more Gods than Fathers then.

div.head: 276. To the Lady Arbella Stuart.
div.l: If in bare words were honour, I could raise-
Could write a thousand Verses in thy Praise:
My Muse may by thy worth ennobled be,
But my poor Muse can nothing add to thee.

div.head: An Anagram of the Authors Name, Invented by D. Du. Tr. of Paris. JOANNES AUDOENUS, Ad Annos Noe Vives.

lg.head: Of the same, A Distich.
lg.l: This Anagram is false concerning thee;
But of thy Book it verifi'd may be.

lg.head: Of the same.
lg.l: Of Thee, thy Book, this Anagram is right:
Thou brought'st thy Book, thy Book brings thee to light.

closer.signed: John Rosse, J. C. A Temples.

div.p: EPIGRAMS OF John Owen AN OXONIAN AND CAMBRO-BRITAN.
Three Books, Two Dedicated unto Henry Prince of Wales. One unto Charles Duke of York.
Englished by Thomas Harvey.
LONDON, Printed by R. White, for Nevil Simmons at the Sign of the Prince's Arms in St. Paul's Church-yard, and for Thomas Sawbridge at the three Flower-de-Luces in Little-Britain. 1677.

lg.head: The Author to the Reader.
lg.l: IN th' Authors Praise, according to the Mode;
Dost wonder thou canst find nor Verse, nor Ode?
No Patronage can to my Verses add;
For if they'r good, they'r good: if bad, they'r bad.

lg.head: The same, to the same.
lg.l: MIne Epigrams are not like strifes, nor are
They like a Lawyers Client at the Bar:
None can our Verses (nor have Kings such power)
If low, make lofty, lofty if, make lower.

div.head: EPIGRAMS OF John Owen A CAMBRO-BRITAN. To Henry Prince of Wales. The First Book.
1. To Prince Henry.
div.l: IN Love, for Custome Books we Dedicate,
And I the Prince choose for my Principate.

div.head: 2. To Mecaenas.
div.l: I for my Verses no Mecaenas look,
I want one for my self, not for my Book.

div.head: 3. To Marcellus, A Lawyer.
div.l: Thou wert Paulinus Patient; for it
Let him thy Client be; Then are you quit.

div.head: 4. To Henry, Prince of Wales.
div.l: Thy Breast, Brain, Reason, Head, Affections, Heart,
In thee with good Effects perform their Part:
Thy Wit thy Courage, Reason rules thy Sense;
Thine Head compleats thine Heart with Eminence.
Wales had three noble Princes, Three Princes of Wales, surnamed Great. Great surnam'd,
And Thou, Great Prince, shalt be the fourth proclaim'd.

div.head: 5. Mercury Gallo-Belgick.
div.l: Not ev'ry Tree will make a Mercury,
This Artist yet doth to't all Woods apply.

div.head: 6. Orpheus.
div.l: Orpheus did fetch his Wife from Hell: But when
Fetch'd any Wife her Husband from that Den?

div.head: 7. Academical Vests. To the Students of Oxford and Cambridge.
div.l: Why are you Students, and our Clergy clad
In black, their Vestments wearing fable, sad?
Is't that our Muses for Apollo mourn?
Or for Mecaenas closed in his Urn?
Mecaenas yet left Heirs: 'Tis true, some one
Heir of his Goods, but of his Goodness, none.

div.head: 8. Wheter Peter were at Rome.
div.l: Whether at Rome Saint Peter ever were,
'Tis doubtful: doubtless Simon was, is there.

div.head: 9. To Be and Have.
div.l: 'Tis good to Be and Have, A Greek, I think,
Once said, an Alman added, and to drink.

div.head: 10. To Ligurinus.
div.l: Arr'us thy Wife doth till, doth fill: The seed
He sow'd, but thine's what Harvest it doth breed.

div.head: 11. Thou shalt not kill, thou shalt not steal.
div.l: Thou shalt not steal, this Law's for Lawyers writ:
Thou shalt not kill, this for Physician's fit.

div.head: 12. Of Alanus, A decocting Chymist.
div.l: This Chymist Gold to Not-Gold brought, in Fact:
But he from not-Gold could not Gold extract.

div.head: 13. To the Prince.
div.l: Ones own be first: If not, let none decline
Anothers to be, while he may be thine.

div.head: 14. To Richard Earl of Dorset returned from France.
div.l: The change of Air hath chang'd (which is most rare)
Thy Qualities and wit: both better'd arc.
More learn'd, more good thou now return'st: thy Fate
In both, great Earl, I do congratulate.

div.head:
15. Nine
Muses,
Mutes.
div.l: When mute the Muses be, what odds (in fine)
Whether thou sayst nine Mutes, or Muses nine?
If th' Idiome the diff'rence constitutes,
What diff'rence 'twixt the Muses and the Mutes?

div.head:
16. Honours
Etymologie.
Genealogie.
div.l: In Hebrew wealth's call'd Hon, in French, Gold, Or:
Hence Hon-or hath its name and Metaphor.

div.head: 17. To Cornutus.
div.l: Pythagoras his Letter hath upon't
A Bipartite; That Letter's on thy front.

div.head: 18. To Dindimus.
div.l: Of Salt a Bushel thou with me must eat
Thou sayst, to make our Amity compleat:
Thou never eatst, as I remember, Salt:
What, shall thy friendship then for ever halt?

div.head: 119. A Cannical Woman.
div.l: A Woman's like a Rule that's general:
Which many times deceives, so women all.

div.head: 20. Solomons wish.
div.l: Why did the wise King wisdome wish, not Health?

Had Solomo •
been wise h' had wish'd for wealth?
But Solomon wish'd wiser, He did prize
Wisdome 'fore Wrath, 〈…〉 was not 〈◊〉 .

div.head: 21. What News?
div.l: Here's nothing, new saith Solomon; yet, bold
Columbus found a new World in our old.

div.head: 22. A Trine of British women from whom came the British union.
div.l:
Henry the seventh.
Henry's wife, Mother Roses red and white
Margaret, the Wife to James the fourth King of Scots; Mother of the Union. Conjoyn'd, his Daughter did the Crowns Unite:
Happy, O Son, happy O Husband rather,
James the First, Britains Monarch. Thrice happy Henry seventh as a Father.

div.head: 23. Doron Basilicon. A Kingly Gift.
div.l: To thee the Wisdome's wish'd of Solomon:
Thy wish thou hast Doron Basilicon.

div.head:
24. Blessed are
Munisicents.
Pacisicents.
div.l: King James the Britains state munites, unites:
Munificent, unificent he writes.

div.head: 25. Of Gaurus, a Church-Canon.
div.l: Wisdome is read in Texts Apocryphal,
Thou, though unwise, art yet Canonical.

div.head: 26. A Snayl: Emblematical.
div.l: Like Snayls are disagreeing Man and Wife:
One House will not contain them in their strife.

div.head: 27. Christopher Columbus.
div.l: The Dove. Columba was the first which did relate
That Land appear'd, and waters did abate:
And thou Columbus was the first, whose hand
Discover'd to the World the America. New-found-Land.
This Gold, an Olive Branch that did produce,
That Pleasures, and this Treasures for mans use.

div.head: 28. Against Regicides.
div.l: Cut off thy Mat. 9.43. Right Hand, if it make thee sin:
Thy v. 45. Foot likewise, if errours it walk in:
If that thy v. 47. right Eye cause thee to transgress,
Then pull it out, what Member more or less
Is peccant in the Body, strike it dead:
Except, Divines and Physicians. Doctors say, the Head.

div.head: 29. A Gratulation. To George Arch-bishop of Canterbury, 1511.
div.l: At Oxford Rector, thence thou didst arise
A Dean, two Cities didst Episcopize:
Thou Londons Bishoprick soon hadst; and thee
The Metropolitan we soon did see:
Thou in the Triple Senate fitt'st on high:
What more remains for thee to doe? To die.Litchueld and Coventry.

div.head: 30. To Decianus, a Judge.
div.l: I would not have thee deaf, nor dumb, but blind:
Not lame, but maim'd; not cruel, nor too kind.

div.head: 31. To Caesar, Caesars, to God, Gods.
div.l: All Pow'r on Earth, beginning hath and end:
God solely doth beyond them both extend:
Indefinite not infinite are Powers:
On Earth God's Infinite, but finite Ours.

div.head: 32. Three Sabbaths.
div.l: Saturn, The Sun, and Venus in a Trine,
To th' Jews, Turks, Christians Sabbaths three design:
The Jews their Sabbath have: And they the same
From pale-fac'd-leaden colour'd Saturn name:
The Turk, whose Law permitteth many Wives,
His Sabbaths Name from Venus Name derives:
But Christians their Sabbath, on the Day
The Sun of Righteousness arose, display.

div.head: 33. To David Murray, Knight, one of the Bed-chamber unto Prince Henry.
div.l: Kings Favours to their Favourites impart;
Wise Kings to those alone of best desert:
Our King in this excels: For, Favours he
Daigns sole to worthy men, to Thee, like Thee.

div.head: 34. I can, will, will not.
Anomals.
div.l: I will, but cannot, what I can, I nill.
Mans total Life is only Nill, and will.

div.head: 35. Patience.
div.l: The man that suffers, overcomes: But then
The suff'ring woman's overcome by men.

div.head: 236. Of Genu-flexion, A Probleme.
div.l: When Honour is conferr'd, or Friend to Friend;
Why man but one Knee, Woman both doth bend?
Man once, but Woman twice must serve in Life:
While Maid, her Father: Husband, when a Wife.

div.head: 37. To William Earl of Pembroke, one of the Kings privy Council.
div.l: Not old in years, nor young in Judgement sound,
The King, thee fit for him, -thy Countrey found;
Shall I for this thine Honour, praise thy Fate?
Or thy Desert? I both congratulate.

div.head: 38. To the Bishop of London.
div.l: The learned King, of the Metropolis
Thee Pastor made: The City wish'd for this:
The See-seat vacant, many sought for it,
As their Reward for Learning and for Wit:
The King, th' Arch-bishop; thee the City call'd:
And thou the See-seat vocant art install'd.

div.head: 39. Of rising and setting.
div.l: Remember at Sun-setting Death, thine Urn:
And at Sun-rising mind thy thence return.

div.head: 40. To Peter Junius, a Scot-Britain, formerly Tutor to King James.
div.l: He's born unworthy, from whom none is born,
But thou thy birth, thy being dost adorn:
For seven from thy Loyns are issu'd forth,
Th' Idea's of thy Body, Wit and worth.
So many learn'd from thee their Father sprung
As Wise men did to learned Greece belong.

div.head: 41. Of Gaurus.
div.l: Thou wise, and foolish art: Who credits it?
Wise in conceit, Foolish, for want of Wit.

div.head: 42. S. T.
div.l: S T. though a note of silence, doth expound,
Without a Vowels help, a vocal sound.

div.head: 43. The saying of Henry Earl of Northampton, Uni & Univoce.
One and Onely.
div.l: We Britans are univocal, serve one.
Only King James, uniting us alone.

div.head: 44. Of Quintus a Dreamer.
div.l: Oft in the Morn I thee complaining heard
That in thy Dreams by Night no Truth appear'd:
What wonder? while by day thou speakst but lye • ,
That all thy Dreams by Night are falsities?

div.head: 45. To Robert Carre of the Kings Council, &c.
div.l: The vulgar seldome love whom Kings prefer,
The King as seldom loves the popular:
'Tis difficult to purchase both their Loves;
Thy Motion's double, for with both it moves.

div.head: 46. Of a certain Hypocrite.
div.l: Thy left hand knows not what thy right hand gives:
True: For it gives to none, nor one relieves.

div.head: 47. The death of Justus Lipsius, 1606.
div.l: The seventi'th and sixth year of thine Age
Finish'd (oh Grief) thine Earthly Pilgrimage:
That Day brought first mine Epigrams to Light,
When thon didst die, my morning was thy night.

div.head: 48. Sir Thomas Overbury's ingenious Poeme of a Compleat Wife.
div.l: Thou dost describe a Wife in such a dress
As Tully doth an Orator express:
And if to such a wife thou wedded wert,
She would be far too short of thy desert.

div.head: 49. Conferring Benefits.
div.l: Good done t' a Child is lost, at least forgot:
Good done t' an old man, is as good as not.

div.head: 50. Ambiguous Right.
div.l: Physicians and Lawyers expert are,
These for our wealth, those for our Health take care.
These to the Clients their just Portion give,
With just proportion those the sick relieve:
Dost ask what difference is between their Notions?
These arid Portions give, those liquid Potions.

div.head: 51. To Prince Henry, born the nineteenth of February, 1594. The Numbers of the Figure 1549. by Arithmetical Addition are reduced to the Golden Number (viz.) 19. v. g. 1.5.9. and 4. put together make 19. (good or) Golden luck, 1612. 19. Jun.
div.l: Thou hast attain'd thy Nineteenth year of Age,
The 19. Golden Number doth much good presage:
And this a Golden year (if I not err)
A Golden verse. Will Honour, Gold, and Good on thee conferr.

div.head: 52. To the King.
div.l: Noah, who liv'd before the Flood, and since,
Di'd in his Nineteenth Jubily: Great Prince,
Might my Vote pass, thou shalt our A King before and after the Union of Britain. Noah be:
Likes ages, as he Jubilies, to see.

div.head: 53. On a Certain Miser.
div.l: I praise thy Tongue, but not thine Hand: None knows
To promise more than thou, none less bestows.

div.head: 54. Of Thomas More formerly Chancellour of England.
To Thomas Baron of Elesmere Chancellour of England.
div.l: Integrity of Life, sweet Eloquence,
Rare Wit advanc'd More to more Eminence.
And thee, thy Wisdome, Candor, grave Aspect
Makes Eminent, sublim'd from Vulgar Sect.
Thy Life with such Integrity, so led,
Proves thee to More more like; but that he's dead.
And thou to More shalt be more like in all,
Except his fatal end, and final fall.

div.head: 55. Natura Brevium.
Praise of Brevity.
To the Reader.
div.l: Some praise prolixe Polysticks, I affect
Short Disticks, Dwarf-like, a short dialect:
Not sole in Epigrams, but in what sort
Of Things soe're, What's Neat, Good, Sweet, is short.

q.p: Thou shalt marry a Wife, and another shall sleep with her.

div.l: This Scripture is in these our Days compleat,
One weds a wife, another doth her treat.

div.head: 57. The Original of Britains union.
div.l: British Ile Mona, Monads Owen Theodore, Grand-father to Henry the seventh-by the Father. Author bare:

Rare Daughter Monas,
In English call'd Anglesley, in British Mon. Mona Parent rare.

div.head: 58. To the learned King James.
div.l: To b' a good Poet's rare, if understood:
As rare a thing, a man to be that's good:
But a good King is a transcendent thing:
Yet thou good Poet art, good man, good King.

div.head: 59. Of Cotta.
div.l: Saint Paul's Rule Cotta keeps t' his wife: He's one▪
That hath a Wife, and is as if h' had none.

div.head: 60. As well to Mars, as Mercury.
div.l: Neptune to Bacchus, Mars t' Apollo joyn,
Art calmeth Rage as Water cooleth Wine.

div.head: 61. To John Harington, Knight.
div.l: Nobility, Wit, Vertue, these in thee
Strive for Precedence: Honourable three.
These noting to speak Truth why should I fear:
Of youths in Court thy Peer doth scarce appear.

div.head: 62. The Lottery: in French, Every thing is to be nam'd from the major Part. the Blank.
div.l: Here mourn the White, the Black rejoyce; Yet this
Black colour proper more for mourning is.
Why gains the Black? the White the while doth lack?
Is't for that Dis give Wealth? And Dis is black.

div.head: 63. To G. R. A Batchelour.
div.l: A Wife is good, a good Wife better; best
No Wife; I wish thee this; me that, at least.

div.head: 64. On trifling Cotta.
div.l: In serious things thou trislest seriously;
Thy folly's serious, thy Wit's laid by.

div.head: 65. On Paetus.
div.l: Thy Front hath Horns: 'Tis ask'd who fix'd them there?
An Author gave them, write; what-ere he were.
Write, Authors gave them; On the Moon-like front,
There must be two that fix'd those Horns upon't.

div.head: 66. Deltoton, Or the Letter D.
div.l: Rocks to mans Life three Deltaes are; these be
Riches. Dives, Delights and Devils: Deltaes three.

div.head: 67. The Gallows: To P. L.
div.l: A Robber's End's a Rope; Death circles it.
And Ropes for Thieves I think are Robes most sit:
But many scape: 'Tis true: some have some scope:
Yet commonly a Robber's End's a Rope.

div.head: 68. Of Womens Wit. A Probleme.
div.l: Why is a woman, than a Man, less wise?
Because Eve from mans Rib, not Head did rise.

div.head: 69. Minerva, Evah.
div.l: Minerva, Joves Brains issue, wedded none:
But Eve was wedded, born from Adams Bone.

div.head: 70. Of Helius.
div.l: Lawyers grow rich by Clients, at Debate:
Thus Helius hath gain'd a vast Estate.

div.head: 71. The State of Britains Union.
To the King.
div.l: This Ile, Elisa raigning, was like Wool,
By thee spun, Henry will make't Cloth in full.

div.head: 72. Whether Bacchus be a God? To Germanus.
div.l: Seest not when drunk with Wine, that Bacchus shakes
Thine Head above, thy low Feet lofty makes?
He raising humble Feet, Heads list on high
Dejecting, proves himself a Deity.

div.head: 73. To Sir Thomas Chaloner Chamberlain to Prince Henry.
div.l: Thee from thy youth endow'd with noble Arts,
Advanc'd by Caesar for thine able Parts,
Thee who to thy poor friends a friend dost prove,
Not, as so great, but, as so good, I love.

div.head: 74. I love, a Passive; I am loved, an Active Voyce.
div.l: Who loves, doth serve: Who's lov'd doth bear the sway;
This Active is, that Passive; must obey.

div.head: 75. On Julius, a pretended Monk.
div.l: Not in the World is Julius; but rather
The World's in him: This from his Life I gather.

div.head: 76. Priest and People.
div.l: Priests pray for People, for Priests People toil:
Those praying, these are ploughing all the while.

div.head: 77. On Pope Julius 2.
div.l: Behold two Swords said Peter, arm'd with Sword:
Behold two Keys O Peter, said his Lord.
Peter left Sword, and did the Keys receive,
But thou dost take the Sword, the Keys dost leave.

div.head: 78. Like to like.
div.l: Females deformed though, find Males by kind.
And knavish Dav • s will a Master find.

div.head: 79. Know thy Self.
div.l: Wouldst know thy Self? Then Nature joyn to Grace,
This shews the Souls, and that the Bodies Face.

div.head: 80. Death's Equity.
div.l: Rivers from Rivers differ; Man from Man:
While Men in Life, Rivers in Channels ran.
Ingulph'd in Seas, all Rivers have like Tast:
So Death doth all men equal make at last.

div.head: To Thomas Button, 1612.
div.l: From Britain, almost all the World apart;
I wish fair Gales, thou sailing Westward art.
Seek, thou shalt find the great Seas Mysteries;
Prince Henry's way's found by the Destinies.

div.head: 82. On Gellia, painted.
div.l: Thy Picture is not like thee: But 'tis plain
Thou like thy picture art, as vile, as vain.

div.head: 83. Conjurers contest.
div.l: In Magick Art the Conjurers contest,
Scottus Parmensis did excel the rest:
He with the Devil had a contract made,
Who knew most, could do most in that black trade:
Like as chief servants in the Courts of Kings,
Under great Masters can perform great things.

div.head: 84. Of Ruffus, An Hypocrite.
div.l: Thou sayst that Ignorance makes men devout:
Thou then shalt be the chief of all that Rout.

div.head: 85. To the English. A Probleme.
div.l: Wherefore do Spanish, French, Italian
Sleight Wives? They reckon Women not Hommes, Femmes: Hombres, Mugeres: Huomini, Donne. Humane.

div.head: 86. To Cinna, A Physician.
div.l: Thou cur'st Diseases, How? Thou kill'st the Sick:
And what thou dost (like Judas) thou dost quick:
Thy Patient is blest: Thou wilt not wrong
His Patience, to let him languish long.

div.head: 87. We have one Advocate in Heaven.
div.l: One Advocate we have in Heav'n, saith Paul;
Are no more Advocates within that Hall?

div.head: 88. To one young in years, old in manners.
div.l: Why doth the Gout, which doth unt' age belong,
Thee vex, A Souldier, Scholar, and so young?
The Gout mistook, it saw thee grave and sage,
And took thee for an old man, ful • of age.

div.head: 89. Anger is a short fury.
div.l: Though wrath be short, 'tis not for fury sit:
If furious, 'tis fit to shorten it.

div.head: 90. To Henry Good-yeer, Knight, Kal. Jan. 1610.
div.l: What new-years Gift shall I present to thee?
I wish, A good year. thy Name thou many years mayst see.

div.head: 91. Love Active and Passive. To Pontia.
div.l: Wilt know what differs I'm lov'd, from I love?
That, I suppose: My knowledge this doth prove.

div.head: 92. To the Prince.
div.l: My dreams by night are much of Royal Gold,
But in the morning there's no Gold, all's cold.
If thou, O Prince, wilt with thine Hand assist,
I shall have Real Gold, not in a Mist.

div.head: 93. Arithmetical Division. To J. S. Merchant. 1607.
div.l: Though living thou give nothing to thy Friends,
The total Sum at Death in nothing Ends.

div.head: 94. The Court Louse.
div.l: The pratling Parasite, through all the court,
To Grandees Chambers make their most resort:
So this vile Beast the Louse doth ost infest
Mens Bodies, but their Heads above the rest.

div.head: 95. Aesculapius Three-fac'd.
div.l: The Physick Doctor seems three-fac'd to be
Unto the Sick; God, Man, and Devil's he:
In giving Physick, he doth seem a Man:
If the disease be cur'd a God he's than.
If Health's restor'd, and the disease destroy'd:
When Doctor comes for Fees, Satan avoid.

div.head: 96. Of Galatea.
div.l: The Stag, 'tis said, his Horns doth yearly mew:
Thine Husband daily doth his Horns renew.

div.head: 97. Waters and Earths Epithalamy.
div.l: All generated are in Earth and Water:
Both these God hath united, former, later:
That nothing to Man-kind unkind should prove,
Th' Earth lieth under, Water flows above.
Earth's waters Wife, Both one Globe constitute,
And well concurr, Humor doth The Ground. Hume salute.

div.head: 98. Of the same.
div.l: Why Water, which flows round, doth slow from th' Earth?
'Cause Thirst this should not suffer, nor that Dearth.

div.head: 99. Death's in the Pot. To Court Criticks.
div.l: Is Death i' th' Pot, or Port (that is) in With the antient Latines Olla and Aula signifie the same. Court?
For Plautus saith, Pot, Court the same import.

div.head: 100. The Deluge. A double Probleme.
div.l: Why saith the So sound as a Fish. Proverb, As a Fish so sound?
Fish sole was sav'd when all the World was drown'd.
All drown'd, why were the Fish from drowning freed?
Because the Mother would preserve her breed.

div.head: 101. A Cole of Wood.
div.l: Born in the Fire, and perishing thereby:
Woods spoiling, I deserve by Fire to die.

div.head: 102. Of Gellia.
div.l: Thou from thy youth a Papist wert: But now
Worse Papist art; How? Catholick art thou.

div.head: 103. Of Aulus.
div.l: As ost as Sickness casts thee on thy Bed,
Or hollow Tooth doth ake; or stupid Head:
O would I were in Heaven from this smart,
Thou sayst: Thine Heir saith, O would thou wert.

div.head: 104. A Woman, what Creature.
div.l: Virgins untouch'd want sense, and Husbands grant
To them their sense, but then they Reason want.

div.head: 105. Reason and Oratory.
div.l: Rhet'rick's the Palm, and Dialect's the fist:
This Combats, that Triumphs within the List.

div.head: 106. Testicles.
div.l: To signifie the Sex? or is our Name
Call'd Testicles, t' attest thy Sin-thy Shame?

div.head: 107. Upon the Death of Hen. Cuff, 1600.
div.l: Learn'd well in Greek, happy thine Alpha was,
But thine Omega hapless prov'd; Alas.

div.head: 108. Of Festus.
div.l: Wilt marry now th' art old? If thou b •• wise
With Lillies learned Grammer first advise:
There indeclinable the Horn thou'lt find;
Old men have seldome that hard Rock declin'd.

div.head: 109. Sir Thomas Moore.
div.l: Imprison'd Moore, to guess what would befall,
Inspects his Urne in an Urinall:
He saw no signs of Death: But had he seen
The Kings, the signs there of his death had been.

div.head: 110. Of Cornelius.
div.l: Thou knowst Th' art Horn'd, tacite Cornelius:
Now thou shalt be Cornelius Tacitus.

div.head: 111. On Tullus.
div.l: Carvers invent, the painters paint a Lie,
Who vents it? Thou. Thou dost adventure high.

div.trailer: The End of the First Book.

div.head: THE SECOND BOOK OF JOH. OWENS Epigrams. To Prince Henry.
1. To Henry Prince of Wales.
div.l: GOD grant thee will the best, the Truth to know:
Who gave these gifts can It is good to be Great, better to be Learned, best to be Good. greatest Gifts bestow.

div.head: 2. To James of Great Britain, &c.
King, the Best-Greatest.
div.l: Tyrants are fear'd of all, fear all: Nor wants
Their fearing force, fearful concomitants:
No need for thee (O thou great King of Kings,
Best King) to fear such formidable things.

div.head: 3. Hysteron Proteron.
In English • The Cart before the Horse.
div.l: Cambridge and Oxford, words so plac'd in force
Are like to these, The Cart before the Horse.

div.head: 4. On a decrepit Husband of a third Wife.
div.l: First Clotho, Lachesis thy second wife,
Thy third wife Atropos cuts off thy life.

div.head: 5. Love.
div.l: Imprison'd-Liberty, Peace-war, sweet-sowre,
Hope-fear, Gall-honey, Love doth laugh and lowre.

div.head: 6. Minos.
div.l: A Judge, who to be Just, on Bribes doth look,
Is like a Fish, which while it takes, is took.

div.head: 7. Doubtfulness.
div.l: Both I suspect, know neither, ready either
To credit: Phoebus he can tell me whether.

div.head: 8. To the Princes Secretary.
div.l: Honours mens former Manners' change in Fine;
'Tis the worlds course, but 'tis no course of thine:
Thou changed dost not change: 'Tis strange to see
Some follow fortune, but she follows thee.

div.head: 9. To Thomas Puckeringe, Knight and Baronet.
div.l: Dear Thomas, if to speak such things be fit,
I first did exercise thy noble Wit:
I thy first Tutor was, thou Pupil mine:
I am not what I was, but still am thine.

div.head: 10. Three Draughts.
div.l: First draught thirst past, present the next abates.
And the third future thirst anticipates.

div.head: 11. A double Riddle.
div.l: Tell me t' her Mother that was spous'd what Eve. woma •

Her Adam. Mother being Man: Her Go •
Father no Man?

div.head: 12. Of Faith.
A five-fold Anagram.
div.l: True Faith is sure, no Schismatick, nor Greek,
Nor Creete, whose Faith is fleeting, or to seek,

div.head: 13. To Sir Edward Cooke, Knight, a learned Lawyer, Judge, &c.
div.l: The Laws of Nature, Nature of the Laws
Thou knowst, thou judgest Clients and their cause:
Thine Answers, (our Apollo) are more clear
Than th' Oracles, that were at Delphos, were.
Thou cutt'st off present strifes, dost countermand
The future: Those with Tongue, and these with hand.

div.head: 14. A Mathematical Instrument vulgarly call'd a Jacobs Staff.
To the Mathematician.
div.l: Take Jacob's Staff, his Jacob's Ladder, Gen. 28.13. Ladder give to me,
I more by this, than thou by that, shall see.

div.head: 15. Earth's Scituation.
div.l: Th' Earth ever stands, if Solomon we credit:
If Naso, then it sits, for Naso said it.
Sitting, it weary would be quaking found,
If standing fall'n: What then? it lieth round.

div.head: 16. To Henry Davers, Baron of Dantesay.
div.l: Thy Valour, Fortune; Prudence conquers Chance:
Thine Hopes above vile-servile fear advance:
Thee Fortune follows, fellows; Prudence leads;
None but th' Almighties Arm, thine Armour dreads:
March on, where e're the King thee calls; Thee guide
Leading, or serving conquest's on thy side.

div.head: 17. Death's Epitaph.
To the Death of Death.
div.l: The cross flew Death, no more from Death to rise:
Thy Death was Death's, thy Cross his Obsequies.

div.head: 18. Of the Pope, and Luther.
div.l: The Pope, indulgent Father, frees, for fees,
Mens Souls, with indulgencies, from the Lees
Of Purgatory: But more Indulgence
Luther doth grant; He Souls exempts from thence.

div.head: 19. Of God and Man.
div.l: God is the Word, and with his Word made all,
We Men make Words, and like our Words do fall.

div.head: 20. To Sir George Carew, Knight, Master of the Pupills, 1612. Jun. 13.
div.l: The King Commending Pupills to thy care,
He doth his care of thy deserts declare.

div.head: 21. Of fasting.
div.l: Why keeps the Pope so many fasts i' th' year?
'Cause Peters successor he might appear.

div.head: 22. A New Metamorphosis.
div.l: A loving Man and Wife make up one Man.
Which four feet hath, that with two Feet began.

div.head: 23. Of Anonyma.
div.l: Thou Fabians nerve inflamed hast: Now he
May truly say, I • urn with love of thee.

div.head: 24. Good from the Dung.
div.l: The Scavenger from Dung doth Gold extract:
The like Physicians and Rusticks act.

div.head: 25. To Face no Trust.
div.l: The Wives offence i' th' Husbands front is writ;
Yet Man for Pen, Woman for Paper's fit.

div.head: 26. To Will. Ravenscroft, J. C.
A Batchelor.
div.l: In single Life leading a Life divine,
What few can be thou canst be, solely thine:
Thy Friends and kindred are as Sons to thee:
While I thy Kinsman or thy Friend may be.

div.head: 27. History of this time.
div.l: Th' old Law for History was this, none might-
Nor dar'd untruth, nor fear'd the truth to write:
But Hist'ries now-new Law doth th' old oppose,
None fears untruth, nor dares the truth disclose,

div.head: 28. A fair Dowry.
div.l: I like a naked Beauty, but not bare:
I would, that matter, with the form should square.

div.head: 29. A Gallick Virgin.
div.l: Gallick virginity belongs t' a Child,
For in their Speech Pucelle, that is a little one, the Fre • call Virgin. a Child's a Virgin stil'd.

div.head: An English Virgin.
div.l: • est English with French words should near assent,
• latonick men are by our Virgins meant.

div.head: 30. Upon a new Noble-man.
div.l: Thy Mother spun, thy Father fish'd with nets:
• hence thy Descent from a long Line thou get'st.

div.head: 31. Penelope's Riddle to her Suitors.
div.l: • here is Osculum, a Kiss, Os, the Mouth, Culus, the Posteriors. a thing, my Verse dares scarcely name,
Thou would'st I should on thee bestow the same;
The former Syllable's mine husbands due;
Take thou, I am not hard, those other two.

div.head: 32. Bias.
div.l: Who said, that all that's mine, with me I carry,
• ias, the wise, It seems did never marry.

div.head: 33. Chrysostome in Greek by H. S. exactly set forth at Eaton.
To H. S. 1612.
div.l: Good-godly Chrysostome liv'd in the flesh;
• n Spirit, now deceas'd, he lives afresh.
He lives in's Books: First life was Natures Fee,
The next to God, the third is due to thee.

div.head: 34. The Philosophers Wife.
div.l: Vulcan fair Venus, Jove did Juno wed,
But chast Minerva was not married;
Why so? She, wisest of the Deities,
Would wed no man, why? because no Man's wise.

div.head: 35. Omni homini soli et semper. Propria quarto modo.
div.l: He falsly spake, who said that Thais was common;
Each, every man hath singly Thais, as Woman.

div.head: 36. A pair of Fools.
div.l: Claud'us like Mule comes from a He-Ass and a Mare. Mule, Gorgon like A little Mule comes from an Horse and a Shee-Ass. Hin, is slow,
Both for their dulness to their Parents owe.

div.head: 37. To Edward Sack-ville, the Earl of Dorsets only Brother returned from France.
div.l: Nature thy prudent Mother gave thee Wit,
Experience abroad improved it.
From Sirens Songs, and Circes charms th' art come
More sage, though with more age, unto thine Home.

div.head: 38. Of Jealousie. English-French-Italian.
div.l: Why do th' Italians, in more grievous sort
Than French or English, take their Wives stoln sport?
Beast's worse than Bird; Th' Italians wife's loose smile.
Him Becco Cornuto, an He Goat: bestiates: French-English Un cocu in French, in English a Cuckold; Cuculus. Birds the while.
English and French are Birds: th' Italian
Sole horn'd Beast, of these three must lead the Van.

div.head: 39. Socratical Wisdoms.
div.l: All things I thought I knew; But now confess
The more I know, I know, I know the less.

div.head: 40. King Arthur's round Table.
div.l: The Delphick Oracle will'd write (no Fable)
The seven wise mens Names in a round Table.
So thy Knights Names wise Arthur, first and last
On the round Table were in order plac't.

div.head: 41. Subsidie.
div.l: Clergy, Purse-Prayers; People Bodies bring,
The Nobles Courage-Coyn, t' assist the King.

div.head: 42. A new World.
div.l: The Cabalists of many Worlds assure us:
Innumerous they be, saith Epicurus.
But count aright, sole two th' account affords,
That old of Deeds, our now-new World of Words.

div.head: 43. Two-fac'd Janus.
div.l: Thy force of Wit, and strength of Memory
Before, behind, to see thou dost apply.

div.head: 44. Earth's Body.
div.l: Th' Earth's Bones are Stones, Skin, Surface, Metalls, Nerves,
The Grass for Hair, for Blood the Water serves.

div.head: 45. To Pannicus, of Maurus.
div.l: What Maurus hath, between thy Wife and Thee
• e doth divide, thou Words, and Deeds hath she.

div.head: 46. Of Paula, an English Dissimulatrix.
div.l: With painted Face, with counterfeit Address
• hy Custome is, to dress thy wickedness.
• hou driv'st the Drones, dull Cattle, from thy Stall:
• nd what's thy Love, but Honey mix'd with Gall?

div.head: 47. A Physician, and Lawyers.
div.l: • ost'nan gives Honours, Galen Wealth, so be
• his be no Patient, nor Client he.

div.head: 48. To Edward Wotton, Baron, &c.
One of his Majesties privy Council.
div.l: He's dead who did his place to thee resign,
Which was before, in Pallas Judgement, thine.
None worthier than thou this place t' inherit;
And thy great worth a greater place doth merit.

div.head: 49. Galen; Anagram, Angel.
div.l: Galen, art Angel good or bad? A good-
Angel, preserving Health, if understood.

div.head: 50. Blind Love is Deaf.
div.l: Their Wives defaults kind Husbands will not see.
Who truly love, by love all-blinded be.
Against their Dears they trust nor Eyes, nor Ears:
Thus Love not only Blind, but Deaf appears.

div.head: 51. Of Dind • mus, amerchant.
div.l: Arithmeticks three first parts learn'd thou hast;
Learn but the fourth, thou shalt be bless'd at last.

div.head: 52. Anagramma Uxoris, The Anagram of a Wife.
Orcus and Uxor: But the English words will not compleat it.
div.l: Prov. 30.13. The Womb and Tomb insatiable are,
Saith the wise King: He did them both compare:
Who falls on Wife, descends into the Pit:
A Wife in sense, not sound is like unt' it.

div.head: 53. The Answer.
div.l: A Wife I'm nam'd, not that I vex the man,
But that mine Housewifes care's Quotidian:
Is Man in Woman as Belzeb's in Hell?
Man's Satan then, if Woman be that Cell.

div.head: 54. The Religious.
div.l: What's well done's ill done, if in publick done:

div.head: The Politician.
div.l: What's ill done's well done, if reveal'd to none.

div.head: 55. Three Goddesses.
div.l: Chast Juno, wanton Venus, Pallas learn'd-
Pure Virgin, 's rare between those two discern'd.

div.head: 56. English Proteus.
div.l: New-fashions in Apparel 'states do wast:
Sole Pleasure pleaseth us, though lost at last.

div.head: 57. One protects two.
The saying of H. 4. The French King.
div.l: One King protects two Kingdoms, yet both fail'd
Thee to protect but one when Death th' assail'd.

div.head: 58. The Birth and Scite of the Sun.
div.l: The Sun, fourth, midst is of the Planets seven:
The Sun was created the fourth day, Gen. 1. The fourth day made, plac'd in the midst of Heaven.

div.head: 59. The Sepulchers of Caesar, Pompey and Crassus.
div.l: Africk for Pompey, Asia doth mourn
For Crassus, Europe hath great Caesars Urn.

div.head: 60. City Buildings most City-like, of Henry Earl of Northampton.
div.l: The Structure of an House, Beneath, Above
The Builders Ingenuity doth prove.
Who raise rude Piles of Buildings (to thy Praise)
By thine Example may their Buildings raise.

div.head: 61. To Oranus.
div.l: Thy Wifes rich Sire oft said, This Daughter mine
In stable Wedlock I to thee will joyn:
Too stable Wedlock hath you joyn'd, sith she
So much unstable is in love to thee.

div.head: 62. Of Faelix.
div.l: Faelix through all the City walks per deiu,
Who scarce two Cities in the World did view.
Who many Men and Cities saw, the Poor
In his own City beggeth at the door.

div.head: 63. Francis Drake.
div.l: No time shall Drake forget; He cross'd the Seas
And Drake-like swam unto th' Antipodes.

div.head: Or This.
div.l: Drakes Name and Fame no time shall ravel out,
He sail'd, amid the Seas, the World about.

div.head: 64. Man.
div.l: Before thy Birth (which thou remembrest not)
Thou nothing wert; Dead, something is thy lot.

div.head: 65. Of Phoebus and Neptune.
div.l: The Sun's of swift, the Sea's of swister force;
That runs but once, this twice a day its course.

div.head: 66. Uxor Vi(n)cta, that is, A Wife bound, Conquer'd.
div.l: The Brides Tongue brid'led, th' Husband's Conquerer:
He sole o'recomes his Wife, that quiets her.

div.head: 67. Naked Truth, Of Alethus.
div.l: If (as saith Plato) Vertue, naked might
Be seen, 'twould fill mens hearts with rare Delight.
Alethus (as 'tis said) saw Four Curtizans, call'd by the names of the four Vertues. Vertues four
Naked, at Venice, and did them deflour.

div.head: 68. Of Bacchus and Byrrhia, Wine and Beer.
div.l: Wine simple-single's prais'd, but double Beer:
Double is good, but single best doth cheer.

div.head: 69. Of Gellia.
div.l: To the first Matter Gellia inclines,
That all forms fancies, this sole Masculines.

div.head: 70. Of Papilus, pulling off his hoar Hairs.
div.l: Thou need'st not pull thine hoar hairs from thine head,
Proceed in Riot. Greek, they of themselves will shed.

div.head: 71. Be not many Masters.
div.l: While none would Scholars be, but Masters all;
All Scholars, none we can a Master call.

div.head: 72. Hen. 8. Defender of the Faith.
div.l: This Title, Leo the tenth, a Florentine by Nation, 1521. Leo Pope, a Florentine,
To th' King of Flow'rs and Lions did assign.

div.head: 73. To Pope Leo.
div.l: That Title, with the Sword thou gav'st the King:
He thee denies; the Sword thy Death did bring.

div.head: 74. The Pride of Life.
div.l: Man, though of vile Earth made, with Pride doth swell,
Th' Earth made of nothing swells with man as well.
So man like th' Earth aspires above his kind,
Th' Earth mounts in Mountains, Man mounts up in Mind.

div.head: 75. To Guarene Tounsend, J. C.
div.l: Thy Tongue no Law-court courts, nor avaricious
Is prostitute t' excuse the guilty, vicious:
Thou dost contemplate Natures Mysteries,
Scripture, Laws, History thou dost revise:
Three Graces, seven Arts, Sisters thrice three
Causes to know, but not to plead, teach thee.

div.head: 76. Genesis and Saint Matthew's Gospel.
div.l: Christ's Birth in this, Adam's that Book is in;
Gospel and Law from Genesis begin.

div.head: 77. Some Body, No Body.
div.l: The sacred Hebrew Text Men, Souls doth stile,
As if that Man were solely Soul the while.
None, no body, one, some body we call
In English, as if we were Bodies-All.

div.head: 78. A Love Fancy.
div.l: If Lesbia, thou wert the Zodiack,
I would I were the Sun, for thy sweet sake:
The Sun compleats the Zodiack once a year,
But once a Night I would compleat thy Sphear.

div.head: 79. To Book-gelders.
div.l: If wise, then gild my Book, but geld it not
That other Books by this may be begot.

div.head: 80. To Gellia.
div.l: In earnest speak; Why dost thou so profuse
Give that to many promis'd for ones use;
'Tis an old custome, common as a Clock,
That many Keys should be t' a single Lock.

div.head: 81. Eve's and the Serpents Conventicle.
div.l: By Eves and Satans Parley, sin did come;
O would she had been deaf, or he been dumb.

div.head: 82. To Robert Johnson, a Scottish-Britain.
div.l:
Reading thy British
Of the affairs of great Britain and Ireland, In his Time. History, I love
Thy self, I like thy Method, both approve:
No such Book's extant, that's more genuine,
More genial, than that same Book of thine;
Excepting Sir Tho. Moore. Moore: Who wrote the Life-the fate

Of Richard the third.
Richard: Thee, next him, I emulate.

div.head: 83. Of Himself.
div.l: I, of the Minor Brothers orders am:
My Fathers Lands to th' Major Brother came.

div.head: 84. Sell all that thou hast, and give to the Poor. To Paetus.
div.l: Of this Advice thou kept'st the former part,
But not the latter: There remiss thou wert.
Th' hast sold, and given all; Part to thy Whore,
Part to thy Riot; nothing to the Poor.

div.head:
85. Nor
Of Evils the least.
Of Good the greatest.
div.l: Though she were best, I would not have my Bride
A Giant, nor a Dwarf, though worst beside.

div.head: 86. Sirens Songs.
div.l: Flee Sirens Songs, thou shalt be safe, and sane.

div.head: 87. A Love Letter.
div.l: Love wants not Hope, in hope the Lover lives:
But Hope without thee,- thine, me nothing gives.

div.head: 88. Blind Love.
div.l: Love and Ebriety are like: They blind
Mens Eyes, of Body this, that of the Mind.

div.head: 89. The Will of rich T. S.
div.l: Thou givest all, no longer here to live,
Nor hence to take it: Couldst? Th' would'st nothing give.

div.head: 90. Air, Water, Earth, Hell.
div.l: The fordid Earth receives the dross of th' Air:
Earth's dregs unto th' infernal Caves repair.
What Evil's in the World shall t' Hell descend:
As pond'rous things unto the Center tend.

div.head: 91. The Christian Zodiack.
div.l: The twelve Apostles, their Stars, four times three,
My Zodiack, Faith, and Christ my Sun shall be.

div.head: 92. Erasmus Praise of Folly.
div.l: Thou didst not folly praise, Erasmus, solely:
Thee many praise, and many praise thy folly.

div.head: 93. Of Gymnicus, A Pastor.
div.l: Thou feed'st thy flock with words, they thee with weeds;
Thy care's for Tythes, no care to cure misdeeds.

div.head: 94. Of Dardanus.
div.l: Paleness in Face, Leanness in Corps doth sit,
Thou nothing hast that's fat, but thy gross Wit.

div.head: 95. Pleas in the year 1609. between Rob. Calvin, Plaintiff; and John Bingley, and Richard Gryffin, Defendants.
div.l: When the Post-nati were in Law of late,
Robert the Son of James o'recame; blest fate:
Th' one English, th' other Welsh, the Victor Scot
O'recame them, guilty both: A lucky lot.
I love good luck: Britains, Hearts-Hands unite;
This Island shall no more be bipartite.
Their Sons Sons Sons shall see, there shall be then
One Kingdom under but one King, Amen.

div.head: 96. Of our times Discords.
div.l: Logick doth things define, divide beside:
But we no things define, all things divide.

div.head: 97. Evil Manners produce good Laws.
div.l: God t' Adam gave a Law before his Sin,
Ill manners therefore all Laws brought not in.

div.head: 98. Four Articles of Faith, 1, 2, 3, 4.
div.l: One God believe, two The two Testaments. Bibles, Symbols The Apostles, Athanasius, and Nicene Creed. three,
Let Faith the fourth, with the four Councils be.

div.head: 99. To the Prince.
div.l: As a great Bear a little Lion flees,
So flees great Hope, when small things come it sees:
Most happy Prince, mine hope depends on thee;
From me take Hope, and I shall happy be.

div.head: 100. To the Reader.
div.l:
Self-love.
Narcissus I leave off, when Verse I write,
Do thou the same, when thou my Verse dost cite.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Book.

div.head: EPIGRAMS OF John Owen A CAMBRO-BRITAN To Charles Duke of York, Brother to the Prince the Kings Son. The Third Book.
1. A Jove Principium, Begin in God.
div.l: GOd's the beginning, i' th' beginning's God,
Before and after, without Period,
Without beginning the beginning: From
This sole beginning all beginnings come.

div.head: 2. To the Reader.
div.l: I publish'd former Books with Verses clad,
I, to the former this, not naked add.
If more remain, they better will appear,
Kind Reader thou dost hope, but I do fear.

div.head: 3. To Charles, Duke of York.
div.l: The Kings, the Kingdoms next Hope-Happiness,
Great Charles, yet then the Prince of Camb'ra less:
Thy Tutors Counsel use, thee which instruct:
Sage-sane advice, a Duke will safe conduct.
Be like thy Father, Second to thy Brother;
Thy Second, or thy like will be none other.

div.head: 4. The Art of Memory.
div.l: Simonides invented Mem'ries Art,
But th' Art of Wit none yet, in whole or part.

div.head: 5. Things, Names and Words.
div.l: God all things did Create, Man gave them Names,
Woman gave words: But word for word inflames.

div.head: 6. Redemption and Regeneration.
div.l: Satan from Eve bought Man, Christ man re-bought:
Adam did death procure, the cure Christ wrought.

div.head: 7. The Praise of Liberality.
div.l: A Gift's eternal, follows him that gives;
The Giver and Receiver It relieves.

div.head: 8. Oxford's new Library. To the Readers, 1610.
div.l: Authors seek ye? Ready, before your Eyes,
Each Classick Author in his Classis crys:
Of this great Work, scarce parallell'd on Earth,
Seek ye the Founder? Bodley gave It birth.

div.head: 9. To the University of Oxford.
div.l: No Library there is with thine that dare
Compare, nor with thy Wits that can compare.

div.head: 10. To Queen Anne.
div.l: Sister, Wife, Mother, Daughter of a King,
Queen Anne: What greater Titles can we bring?
Four Vertues thou with these four Titles hast;
What canst thou to thy Vertues add at last?

div.head: 11. To Elizabeth the Kings Daughter.
div.l: Born of a Kingly,-long continu'd Line,
A King, a Caesar meriting for thine:
Shouldst for an Husband stay, who could out-vie
Thy worth, thou mightst a Virgin live and die.

div.head: 12. Speech and Writing.
div.l: Mute Hand's the speaking Tongues Interpreter,
As speaking Tongue's the mute Hearts messenger.

div.head: 13. A new Man.
div.l: Depel, Dispel that old-grown Man of Sin,
And, with the new Man, a new life begin.

div.head: 14. An healthful Anagram, Opto, I wish, Poto, I drink.
div.l: I wish much Health, but drink no Health to thee:
Better's a dry, than drunken Health for me.

div.head: 15. The forbidden Fruit.
div.l: It was not sole an Apple, It was worse,
Adam brought Sins Original, the Curse.

div.head: 16. Cal. January.
div.l: Greeks and Gift-givers, Tros thus saith, I fear:
Who's Greek? The Poor: Who Tros? The Usurer.

div.head: 17. Of Alcon.
div.l: Alcon wants credit, he will credit none;
All credit him; His credit then's not gone.

div.head: 18. To Robert Carey, Knight, Governour of Charles Duke of York.
div.l: Great Queen Elisa, in Alliance nigh
Unto thy Parent, grac'd thy family:
The King of Britains Son thy Pupil is;
That's th' Honour of thy Kind, of thy Mind, this,

div.head: 19. Example.
div.l: Vertue by good Example's taught and learn'd:
In teaching me, my Teacher is concern'd.

div.head: 20. A double Medium.
div.l: Th' Earth in the middle stands, yet low doth lie:
And Vertue's in the midst, yet soareth high.

div.head: 21. N. O.
div.l: N leads, O follows: Nothing's more Old than All:
For God of Nothing made what th' Orb we call.

div.head: 22. To James Fullerton, Knight, Governour of Charles Duke of York.
div.l: Learn'd Fullerton, the credit of thy Nation,
Thou the Kings Son hast in thine Education:
And that the Son may like his Father move,
Thy Labour that, thine Honour this will prove.

div.head: 23. Holiness, Healthfulness.
div.l: All wish long Life, few to live well endeavour:
Wouldst thou live long? live well, and live for ever.

div.head: 24. Sheep and Goats.
div.l: The Goats climb Rocks, and Promontories steep,
The lower Ground depasture flocks of Sheep:
'Tis so now, but it will not still be so,
The Sheep on high, the Goats below shall go.

div.head: 25. A Ship.
div.l: The Stern's the Train, Bulk, Belly, Bill the Prore;
The Sayls are Wings; Ships sayl, as Birds do soar.

div.head: 26. To Thomas Murrey, Tutor to Charles Duke of York.
div.l: If Jacobines be the Kings Friends, I will
My self a Jacobine acknowledge still:
If Scotists be the Regal favourites,
I will a Scotist be by days, by nights:
Learn'd Thomas, thou me Thomist mak'st to be;
And Scotist, thou Scotch-Britain makest me.

div.head: 27. Blood not Vertue.
div.l: Vertue, than Blood, 'twas said, is more preclare:
But Blood is better than all Vertues are:
Blood better is than Vertue: Not by Merits,
But by thy Blood, O Christ, man Heaven inherits.

div.head: 28. The Sun, and time.
div.l: The Sun is swift, but th' Hour's more swift: Josh. 10.12 The Sun
Sometime stood still, but th' Hour that time did run.

div.head: 29. The Blood.
div.l: I'm Crude, call'd Blood: A circled course I keep,
And Snake-like through the bodies Veins I creep.

div.head: 30. Of Pannicus, a rich Fool.
div.l: Forture doth favour Fools: Or credit me,
Or else believe thy Self, thou then shalt see.

div.head: 31. Brevity.
div.l: Perspicuous Brevity doth please in chief:
In words, which things concern'd contain, be brief.

div.head: 32. The Tomb of John Puckeringe, Keeper of the Great Seal.
div.l: This Tomb presents three Brothers, Sisters five,
One Sister's dead, one Brother's yet alive.

div.head: 33. Homer.
div.l: No wonder, Homer, former was of Lyes;
His Ears were his Informers, not his Eyes.

div.head: 34. Erasmus.
div.l: 'Tis ask'd, why men Erasmus thee do call?

div.head: Answer.
div.l: If Mouse, I was the best, or none at all.

div.head: 35. A little, nothing; too much, enough.
div.l: The Poor have little, Beggars that are common,
Have nothing, rich too much, enough hath no man.

div.head: 36. To Henry Wotton, Knight, the Kings Embassadour, &c. 1612.
div.l: In dubious things thou didst remember me,
In serious, though late, I think on thee:
At Venice, at A Town between France and Germany. Sabbaudies for our King
Thou Legate wert, fair Winds thee back did bring.
The King must pay thee what he thee doth owe,
'Tis secret when: But that he will I know.

div.head: 37. Foresee thine End.
div.l: Mans death, not birth declares his bane, or bliss:
None bless'd before his death, nor wretched is.

div.head: 38. The Polar Sabbath.
To the Polars.
div.l: One day, one Night, doth your whole year display:
So that your Seventh year, 's your seven • h day.

div.head: 39. To the Desirers of the Salick Law.
div.l: In France the Virile Law sets men at th' Helm,
The female Distaff must not rule the Realm.
Would ye the Salick Law should here come in,
O Britains? Be robust: At home begin.

div.head: 46. To G. Gwyn.
div.l: That I no Disticks in thy praise design,
It is because thine better are than mine.

div.head: 41. Irus and Croesus Epitaph.
div.l: Croesus and Irus thus are different,
Both dead, that hath, this hath no Monument.

div.head: 42. The Inter-Calar Month, 1612.
div.l: Why February sole each fourth year grows?
'Cause 'tis the least month from the Moon that flows.

div.head: 43. Of Faelix.
div.l: Rich, while alive, thou wert, now dead, poor art:
Wishing with Lazarus a place, a part.

div.head: 44. Ten Principles.
div.l:
One Substance doth nine Predicaments in Logick.
Categors confine,
As one Apollo doth the Muses nine.

div.head: 45. Logick.
div.l: A Creature horn i' th' dark, Rude, Infant, Child;
Unt' Oxford sent, will soon a man be stil'd.

div.head: 46. To Samuel Daniel, Poet.
div.l: A. Pen thy right Hand, Sword thy left doth follow:
Mars is Sinister, Dexter's thine Apollo.

div.head: 47. Lover of Truth. To Paulus.
div.l: Fond Novelties, sottish Antiquities
Me please not, truth is all I praise-I prize:
I follow neither new, nor old: 'Tis true:
But Truth I love, whether 'tis old, or new.

div.head: 48. Humility.
div.l: Long Grass in valleys, short on Mountains grows:
Low minds more Wisdome have, than lofty Brows:
A Mind's a Mount, whose Top's a Type of Wit,
Each Top is bare, and Type is like unt' it.

div.head: 49. Three Self-Lovers.
div.l: I next my self, and thou, thy self art next;
What hinders, but that he should be context?

div.head: 50. Saint Marks Festival.
To Marianus, a Shepheard.
div.l: Why marks Saint Mark's day Sheep, not Goats? Tell why?
Sheep Shall hereafter live, when Goats shall die.

div.head: 51. To Dindimus.
div.l: Devouring time devoureth all that's our:
But thou mispending time, dost time devour.

div.head: 52. Of Heaven and Earth, a double Paradox.
div.l: Heav'ns Motion errs not, erring is th' Earth's Station,
Fast, stedfast though, yet full of Variation.
Trod under foot, Plough'd, Harrow'd ev'ry Morn,
Poor Earth, while I am Earth, I shall be torn.

div.head: 53. The Year.
div.l: Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter, make the year:
Autumn doth Summer, Spring doth Winter chear.

div.head: 54. A Client.
div.l: Hast care to cure, and to secure thy Cause?
Incline then, Client, to thy Lawyers Laws.

div.head: 55. Of the Covetous.
div.l: Shooes wider than thy Feet thou wilt not have;
Why then more Wealth than's fit, or needs, dost crave?

div.head: 56. Patience.
div.l: I will, or must be patient, hoping still:
All things by this I suffer can, or will.

div.head: 57. The Serpent, Eve, Adam.
div.l: The Serpent, not deceiv'd, deceiv'd poor Eve;
Adam deceiv'd not, but he did believe
His Wise, and was deceiv'd: The Womans fault
Was Active, Passive: Catch'd her self, she caught.

div.head: 58. The Swan.
div.l: When Fates me call, the Rivers Bank close by,
I sweetly sing my Requiem, and die.

div.head: 59. To Polydore.
div.l: The Dative case than Ablative is better;
The Taker to the Giver is a Debtor.
Ah, th' Ablative doth here too long remain,
When will the Dative case return again?

div.head: 60. To N. N.
div.l: Unhappy Servant of two Masters thou,
This Nothing doth, that Nothing hath t' allow.

div.head: 61. A Three-fold Continency of the Eyes, Ears, and Tongue.
div.l: Lest ill thou seest, or hear'st, thy Windows close:
Lest ill thou speak'st Locks on thy Lips impose.

div.head: 62. Saturns three Sons.
div.l: Nummipotent is one, Hells President:
Next Amnipotent, third Omnipotent.

div.head: 63. The old man speaks to the young Man.
div.l: My Life is short, nor can long time import;
Thy Life seems long; but shortly will be short.

div.head: 64. Of my Book.
div.l: Salted at Oxon (youth then) 'tis the Mode;
Pepper'd at Winton (then Child) I abode:
If this my Book of Salt, or Pepper tast,
First, Winton Pepper gave, Salt Oxon last.

div.head: 65. To Theo-dore, Gods Gift, A Physician.
div.l: In Greek and Latine Theodore's thy Name;
Thy skill in The most high created the Physician, The most High created Physick out of the Earth, Ecclesiasticus 38.1.4. Physick makes it thrice the same.

div.head: 66. Of Quintus.
div.l: At School, a Boy, thou learn'dst four Swearing Adverbs,
Now grown a Man, thou swear'st four thousand Mad Verbs.

div.head: 67. To an Angry man.
div.l: Let Anger set; but not rise with the Sun;
Still let it with the Sun t' Antipo • es run.

div.head: 68. Of a Cloak and Coal.
div.l: Blew Coats, with Sleeves and Badges, yearly new
Here Serving Men did wear, a lazy crew:
Now Cloaks they wear: Why Cloaks? Because they may
Flagens or Capons, under Cloaks convey.

div.head: 69. Death.
div.l: Nothing's here humane, but inhum'd must be;
Earth swallows Earth, but Souls from Earth flee free.

div.head: 70. Of Pontius, A Poet.
div.l: Pont'us on one Foot halts, with th' other stumbles;
Hexameters, Pentameters he rumbles.

div.head: 71. Of Fabian.
div.l: Do what thou say'st, or say what thou do'st do,
But Fabian doth neither of the two.

div.head: 72. Edition of Books.
div.l: It happens, that when Verses I have penn'd,
Fasting or full, Edition is their end.

div.head: 73. God loves a chearful Giver.
div.l: Regard not what Reward thou giv'st the poor:
God will Regard, and it Reward with more.

div.head: 74. Of Quintus Ramista his Fathers third Son.
div.l: So thou dost all things in two Parts divide.
If all thing else should bipartited be,
What of thy Fathers Goods would come to thee?

div.head: 75. Cupid's Arms, Bow and Arrows.
div.l: Offensive not Defensive weapons, why
Doth Cupid use? He conquers all thereby.

div.head: 76. Of Prose and Verse.
A Probleme.
div.l: Why runs a Speech in Verse than Prose more fleet?
Because that wanteth not, this wanteth Feet.

div.head: 77. Heaven.
div.l: Heaven's the specious-spatious House of God;
All-potent Lord, House patent all abroad.

div.head: 78. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
div.l: Water's made holy for Regeneration:
But 'tis but simply water in Creation.

div.head:
79. A Nest of Boxes
Suscipio Pyxidum Trias.
Scipio Pyxidum Trias.
Pio Pyxidum Trias.
The English cannot reach the conceit.
div.l: I for my Countrey, Fathers, People, I
Adventure dare, said Scipio, to die.

div.head: 80. Of Pontilian.
div.l: The fawning Dog with wagging Tail doth flatter:
Pontill for want of Tail with's Tongue doth chatter.

div.head: 81. We are Dust and Ashes. Horace.
div.l: Let none, though clad with Earth, of Heaven despair;
Nor any, though a Shadow, thin as Air:
Dust is our Flesh, Christs Body's of like clod:
Our Soul's a shadow, shadow yet of God.

div.head: 82. An Aenigma.
div.l: Tell what Felicitas. whole world in Heaven doth abound,
Gall. First Syllable of which on Earth's sole found.

div.head: 83. A Rich Man.
div.l: While I wish Wealth, I worse am, and in fine
Greatness to gain, I Goodness do decline.

div.head: 84. Conversion of Paul.
div.l: Thou, lately Saul, art now Saint Paul; Thou late
Didst persecute, but now dost predicate.

div.head: 85. Right Reason.
div.l: That in our times Reason's o're-rul'd 'tis grief.
'Twere Joy, if Reason might command in chief.

div.head: 86. To Thomas Morrey, Tutor unto Charles Duke of York.
div.l: I thee, thy Genius, ingenious head;
Know, read thy Writings worthy to be read:
Thou Doctor-ductor to the Duke, than thee
None fitter, by thy Rules while rul'd is he,
Not forc'd, but by Propensity; What Praise
Hast gain'd, to lead thy Leader in his ways?

div.head: 87. To the Hebrews.
div.l: Your Law is your Religion, Faith is ours,
Our want's to do well, to believe well's yours.

div.head: 88. Irus, a Beggar.
div.l: By this word Hospes Host, and Guest's exprest:
I am to many, none to me's a Guest.

div.head: 89. God.
div.l: Though God's Infinitie's dispers'd most clear' •
Through the whole World, God yet is sought for there.

div.head: 90. An Eagle.
div.l: In Temples th' Eagle sacred Scripture bears,
Now great Jehovah's Bird, once Jupiter's.

div.head: 91. Toby Mathew.
div.l: Thy first Name from th' old Testament, thy Next
Is from the new: Both Names from sacred Text.
Strange, that a Gentiles name Canonical
Should he, which in the Fount's Apocryphal.

div.head: 92. On a Paraphrase.
div.l: This Paraphrase is circle-like wrought round,
From Center to circumference 'tis found;
It toucheth the Diameter's both ends,
But to the Center in no part extends.

div.head: 93. Of Corbulo.
div.l: Thou ruinest, and raisest, Corbulo;
Thy Wealth thou ruin'st, raisest nothing: No.

div.head: 94. Of Gellia, a Grammaticastrix.
div.l: Grammer was th' Art of speaking call'd of old;
Thou needst not learn it, thou canst speak, and scold.

div.head: 95. On a certain Grammaticaster.
div.l: A Shred, an Hair, a Nut-shell, half a Groat,
Thou me dost prize at: What I thee? for nought.

div.head: 96. Warr.
div.l: War, sole to Souldiers seems pleasant: Why?
Because sole Souldiers gain, • live thereby.

div.head: 97. Riches.
div.l: Sole Gold's a God: Goods, Gods: Coyn, Queen •• some
Pluto speaks with applause, but Plato's dumb.

div.head: 98. Three Genders.
div.l: Wives (though most chast) o' th' Doubtful are, o' t •• commo •
Are Whores, o' th' feminine is ev'ry Woman.

div.head: 99. S T. a note of Silence.
div.l: What mean this Roman S T? What? Express:
S, stands for Silence, T, for Taciteness.

div.head:
100. Patria est ubicun
que est bene.
Where I do well, there I dwell.
div.l: I count my Countrey, not where born, or bred;
But that, where known, where with mine own I' • fe ••
My Countrey, that I count, where I do well;
Where I have my subsistence, there I dwell.
That Wife is for a Duke, and King unfit,
Which will not be led, ruled, nor submit.

div.head: 102. Rhetorick and Dialect.
div.l: Rhet'rick to speak, Logick to teach is th' Art:
This Wisdome, that to th' Wise doth strength impart
That neater, this compleater couch'd than it;
That seasoned, this seasoneth the Wit.
Rhet'rick doth veil, Logick doth Truth reveal;
This warns, that moves, that woundeth, this doth heal.

div.head: 103. Actaeon.
div.l: Actaeons Doggs devour'd his Flesh, Bones, Skin;
But yet his Horns some Cities are within.

div.head: 104. Arithmetical Multiplication and Division.
div.l: Division Right, left Hand Multiplication
Respects, why? Vertue's that, this a Privation:
Why upward that, why downward this aspects?
This unto man, that unto God directs.

div.head: 105. A Tree.
div.l: Spring makes me green, me Summers heat doth scald;
Autumn hoar-headed, Winter makes me bald.

div.head: 106. To Theodore Prise, an Oxonian Divine.
div.l: One Verse my love to thee cannot declare;
• f two will serve, lo, here two Verses are.

div.head: 107. One God.
div.l:
Heaven.
Coelum's an Hetroclite, as Lily notes;
And Deus with the Plural Number quotes:
O, what Blasphemers our Grammarians are,

Who, that we Go ••
Deus may decline, declare.

div.head: 108. Dei genus.
div.l:
The God-head.
Numen to th' Neuter gender doth incline;
• Tis neither Masculine, nor Feminine.

div.head: 109. Government of the body.
div.l: • ools strain, but prudent men restrain their voice:
Which hath least labour, silence, or a noyse?

div.head:
110. Malorum signifies Apples or Evils.
Malorum, the least and greatest, To Maximus.
div.l: • t Table sitting chuse of ills the least,
• he great'st of Apples, if the great'st be best.

div.head: 111. Unda.
div.l:
• bate a Letter Water.
Unda's Moist.
Uda, add

• Tis Clean.
Munda,
Naked.
Nuda, 'tis transpos'd, unclad.

div.head: 112. Of Dreams. A Paradox.
div.l: •• d Dreams are good, good, bad: Why? when I wake
• f bad, I'm glad, if good, mine heart doth ake.

div.head: 113. Waters Original.
div.l: • sk'st, whence deriv'd? It hath no derivation:
The year and River circulating run,
Ending, without an End, where each begun.(a) w •••

div.head: 114. Covetousness.
div.l: To th' Ocean, Rivers run all places from:
It saith not whence d' ye come, but hither come.

div.head: 115. The Adamant.
div.l: To Lovers Adamants ought to be sent:
Cupid can make an Adamant relent.

div.head: 116. Dog and Hare.
div.l: Though light-foot Hare more swift than Grey-hou ••
They run in hope, she (light) doth hopeless flee.

div.head: 117. Speech and Writing.
div.l: The nimble Tongue th' Hearts secrets doth expound,
But writing hath a voice without a sound.

div.head: 118. The Lawrel.
div.l: I, Phoebus Tree, still frondent, flourishing,
Nor bald, nor grisled, verdant as the Spring.

div.head: 119. Dicacity and 〈◊〉 .
div.l: Wit without Wisdome's as without Meat, Salt:
Inurbane wit's what? Salt-less Meat, like fault.

div.head: 120. Something of nothing.
An Arithmetical Riddle.
div.l: 01. Add one to nothing, nothing's left, but then
1 • . Add to one nothing, thence ariseth ten.

div.head: 121. To William Sutton, an Oxonian Divine.
div.l: I owe thee more than can my Verse express;
Me thy perpet'al debtor I confess.

div.head: 122. Three Sons of Saturn and Ops, Co-heirs.
div.l: Saturns three Sons, all rich, Dis, Neptune, Jove;
Whose Mother Ops, Beneath, About, Above
Them plac'd; I should be richer than those three,

Would Mother Rich ••
123. O ••
Opes lend her help to me.

div.head: 123. Of a certain superfluous Orator.
div.l: When all th' hast said, Thou want'st to say, I've done;
• ut word would please me more than those fore-gone.

div.head: 124. To the Readers.
div.l: • Readers, Hearers all I will not please,
• r am I pleas'd with all of those, or these.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Book.

div.p: EPIGRAMS OF John Owen AN OXONIAN AND CAMBRO-BRITAN.
Three Books dedicated to three, Each a Mecaenas. To Edward Noel, Knight and Baronet, one. To William Sidley, Knight and Baronet, another. To Roger Owen, a Noble Knight the third.
LONDON, Printed by R. White, for Nevil Simmons at the Sign of the Prince's Arms in St. Paul's Church-yard, and for Thomas Sawbridge at the three Flower-de-Luces in Little-Britain. 1677.

div.head: EPIGRAMS OF John Owen AN OXONIAN AND CAMBRO-BRITAN. To Sir Edward Noel, Knight, and Baronet. The First Book.
1. To the Prince of Wales.
div.l: MEcaenas (gracious in Caesars Eyes)
Virgil and Horace daign'd to patronize.
And thou, great Prince, dost not disdain to lend
Thine Help unto mine Hope, for better end.
Three Knights me patronize; though each to me
Mecaenas is, thou shalt my Caesar be.

div.head: 2. To his three Patrons, E.N. G.S. R.O.
div.l: When old friends me forsook, as 'tis in use,
Unhop'd for Help you three did me produce:
Your three Names therefore, next the Prince his name
I joyn, Mecaenas sole deserves such fame.

div.head: 3. Lawyer and Physician.
div.l: Unless he subtile be, this rashly bold,
They both perhaps may beg their bread, when old.

div.head: 4. The Courtiers Ladder.
div.l: None, but by many steps doth rise at Court,
But falling, one's enough, too much, though short.

div.head: 5. To Edward Noel, &c.
div.l: Though I, Mecaenas, send this Book to thee;
Others may read it, if't worth reading be.
How is my Patron better by this sped
Than Readers? Thus, he readeth, and is read.

div.head: 6. On Tomasine.
div.l: Many, these times, in praise of Asses writ,
I read a Book, and read thy praise in it.

div.head: 7. To — A Courtier.
div.l: The bold by Fortune, th' eaters are by meat
Aided: Wilt something be? be bold and eat.

div.head: 8. Honour and Riches compared.
div.l: God gives men Riches, Honour claims as Donor.
Preferr'd before all Riches therefore's Honour.

div.head: 9. On fabulous Poets.
div.l: Poets of old, making small difference
'Twixt Truth and Lies, made something of each Ens:
Their proper name, from making, Poets gather,
From making something, making nothing rather.

div.head: 10. On Fabianus.
div.l: Some bald without, thou bald within, 'tis plain:
They want their Hair, thou want'st as much of Brain.

div.head: 11. Osculum, a Kiss.
div.l: Lovers affect three Syllables; this word
Is given by the Lovers that accord.
Is the first given? Doubtless, then, in fine
The rest will follow from the femi • i • e.

div.head: 12. Dalilah.
div.l: Strong Sampsons Wife, despoyl'd him of his hair,
Our times have many Dalilahs, as fair.

div.head: 13. Coventry and Warwick, Midland Cities.
div.l: Not the same Prelate, the same Judge you see;
Your Spirits differ, but one flesh you be.

div.head: 14. The Birth-day.
div.l: To present born, reborn to future things,
The present's first, the last more comfort brings.

div.head: 15. On the Art of Love.
div.l: I think 'twas rudeness th' Art of Love t' impart,
Love is the work of Nature, not of Art.

div.head: 16 On Gallio.
div.l: Rare Judge, who giftless doth his office; Why?
Because with gifts he did his office buy.

div.head: 17. On Phyllis.
div.l: The Love of Phyllis for a Solar year
Endures not; Lunar 'tis, like Phoebe's Sphear.
Her love is like her Body, monthly sick:
Lunar's her Love, her self is Lunatick.

div.head: 18. On Paetus. A Probleme.
div.l: Nor Father, Step-father, nor kin to those
Thy Wife brought forth: What shall we thee suppose?

div.head: 19. On Pontiliana.
div.l: Why wert thou wedded on bright Lucy's light?
Because 'twas shortest Day, and longest Night.

div.head: 20. To Fronto, a Lawyer.
div.l: I many Penal statutes, Fronto, saw
But not one Premial in all your Law:
Laws Penal, Premial support a State;
This age hath lost the last, the first's in date.

div.head: 21. To Edward Noel, &c.
div.l: Wise Nature did to thee much Wit impart
To Natures strength thou dost add helps of Art.
Good Fortune with thy Vertue doth combine,
Unto thine Art and Wit thou Wealth dost joyn.
Fortune enables thee to succour wants,
And Vertue makes thee willing: Both God grants.

div.head: 22. On Festus, an unjust Judge.
div.l: What Judas did, or Pilate, do the same:
Hang'd wouldst not be? Wash then thine hands from blame.

div.head: 23. Paronomasia, (i.) Gingling with words.
div.l: A Maid looks on her Lovers face, not mind:
If wedded, 'tis enough, her Husband's kind:
Venus had rather courted be than painted;
With Acts, than Complements she's more acquainted.

div.head: 24. To Martha, Of Quintus.
div.l: Quintus in Love is prodigal, recluse:
Of thy Love covetous, of's own profuse.

div.head: 25. Of
div.l: Mans Back-parts are in Latine Neuters stil'd:
But all his parts please Women, well compil'd.

div.head: 26. Of Colinus dying Intestate.
div.l: Dying Colinus nothing did bequeath,
Lest all: In Life a Dog, an Hog at's Death.

div.head: 27. Of Virginity and Wedlock.
div.l: Virginity's a narrow way; a broad
Is Wedlook: Hence most People ride this road.

div.head: 28. Of Pansa.
div.l: Great strife 'twixt Pansa and Eunomius
Arose about Church Rites, which they discuss:
Eunomius to prove his Period
The Scripture cites, th' undoubted word of God:
With Scripture what have I to do, replies
Pansa, my Bible in my Law books lies.

div.head: 29. To D. T.
div.l: Thou followest two Masters; strange to me
If, or thou pleasest both, or both please thee.

div.head: 30. Merchants Faith.
div.l: Where Debtors credit's less, less credit give
The Creditors; by trust how should they live?
Sole trust, these times hath many Merchants split:
To trust now therefore 'tis nor safe, nor fit.

div.head: 31. Gerunds and Supines.
div.l: Di-do-dum while Aeneas was away
Did want her Gerunds, and Un-supine lay.

div.head: 32. Give me an Angel, and I will give thee the Spirit.
div.l: The Spirit here, an Angel, Michael
Is promis'd there; here Gifts, there Hands excell.

div.head: 33. To a certain rich Man.
div.l: If now thou givest much, thy love's compleat:
If much thou creditest, thy Faith is great.

div.head: 34. To a servant of two most penurious Sisters.
div.l: Three Parce, fatal Sisters, once were known;
Thou now, poor wretch, two such dost serve and own.

div.head: 35. A Louse.
div.l: Thou me dost bite, I kill thee: True, but small
Thy Crime's, thy Punishment is Capital.

div.head: 36. From bad to worse.
div.l: He falls on Scylla that Charybdis shuns,
Who newly sick to the Physician runs:
Fools one extreme t' avoid act the contrary,
When trifles men to Law to Lawyers carry.

div.head: 37. Of the Prodigal and Covetous.
div.l: Both these are wretched: And it oft doth fall
That th' Heirs of Cov'tous men prove Prodigal.

div.head: 38. Divine Vengeance on G. R. 1603.
div.l: Thou kept'st the Prelates House against his mind;
Against thy mind th' art now t' an a Prison House confin'd.

div.head: 39. Of Damas.
div.l: As oft as I thy promise claim, and I
Claim it more oft, fith thou dost not comply;
Thou never sayst, I have, oft sayst I will;
No more I will, but say, I do fulfill.

div.head: 40. On unfortunate Linus.
div.l: What wonder, fortune is to thee contrary?
Thy front is bare and bald, her Front is hairy.

div.head: 41. To Gaurus.
div.l: Thy Whispers did of me some samll gift crave;
Wilt have a Culus gift? Thou shalt it have.

div.head: 42. Man all-eating.
div.l: Air, Water, Earth, with all the vast Extents
Of th' Elements, scarce serve Mans Aliments.
If all man eateth, int' his Substance ran,
As 'tis suppos'd, what Monster would be man?

div.head: 43. The broad way.
div.l: Broad is the way, much trod, unt' Hell that leads;
The Blind, himself the Guide, this broad way treads.

div.head: 44. To, In, Of.
div.l: Of, In, To, these three words my Book inhems:
Of, Teacheth, To, Commendeth, In, Condemns.

div.head: 45. On unmerciful Quintus.
div.l: When any Poor, or Naked, at thy door
Beg Alms, how canst deny, while such implore?
Thou sayst, none ought to Begg by th' English Laws,
But no Law barrs relief to th' poor, when cause.

div.head: 46. Error is humane.
div.l: I read a just man falls seven times a day:
How oft a Woman falls, I cannot say.

div.head: 47. On a certain foolish writer.
div.l: O, that all black had been thy Papers white;
Or tinctur'd with no black, when thou didst write.

div.head: 48. The usurers Apology.
div.l: What good doth me my Money without use?
Gold's bright with use, use doth me gain produce.

div.head: 49. On a Cuckold.
div.l: Hadst Horns by Nature, them thou might'st Cashier:
But th' Horns, thy Wife thee gave, thou needs must wear.

div.head: 50. Things adjudged.
div.l: Though Cicero call Law the sum of Reason,
And that Law's best which thence proceeds in season:
Few Lawyers are Logicians; Use, Example,
The Laws and Statutes are of either Temple.

div.head: 51. A Woman.
div.l: Fair women, famous: Youthful, sportful are:
If Witty, Wise: Buxome and Chast are rare.

div.head: 52. The four Terms at Law.
div.l: The first Term's from Saint Michael declar'd;
For now The form of the Arch-Angel in this English Piece of Gold. th' Arch-Angel doth the Lawyers guard:
The next is Hilary, this Term doth cause
The Lawyers Hilarity by th' Laws.
The third from Easter Feast its Title took,
The Lawyers Dockets are like The Parsons Easter Book. th' Easter Book.
The fourth Term's called Trinity: But why?
Because The Client, Lawyer, Judge , each cause hath a Triplicity.

div.head: 53. The Cross in the Poultrey.
To Christ.
div.l: The Crosses Image stands, thine's took from thence:
Than thee, the Cross hath greater Reverence.

div.head: 54. That the Lawyers two Colledges, the Middle and Inner Temple are the same.
div.l: One house both have, and both one Law apply,
No Middle-Inner sense i' th' Law doth lie.
What's Middle, is the great World's inner Cell;
For than the Center, what doth inner dwell?
The Middle Temple then, though Middle wrote,
From th' Inner Temple differs not one Jot.

div.head: 55. Of the same.
div.l: Two Parl'aments you have, one convocation;
Two Kitchens, but one Altar for oblation:
One Master calls to Supper, but the same.
One Horn doth not your Dinner time proclaim;
Nor the same winding both your Horns inflates,
Yet one mind both your bodies animates.

div.head: 56. A bountiful Mecaenas.
div.l: Thou liberal and free dost nourish many,
And me thou nourishest as well as any.

div.head: 57. To Faustinus.
div.l: Thou sayst my Book is good: O, if't be good,
I wish I were my Book, and understood.

div.head: 58. O the times!
div.l: The Times are Chang'd, and in them Chang'd are we:
How? Man as Times grow worse, grows worse we see.

div.head: 59. Stammering. To Balbinus.
div.l: Though thou dost stammer in thy Speech, yet none

Can The Pope , Pa-pa- Father.
pater say, but thou alone.

div.head: 60. Agna-Oxon.
div.l: Thou Bride to Benedict (not so well nam'd)
Suppos'd a Lamb, a Wolf art found, art fam'd.

div.head: 61. To Aulus, a Physician, a vernal Gratulation.
div.l: Sick persons purge their Bodies in the Spring:
I thee salute, Spring doth thine Harvest bring.

div.head: 62. A Poet Laureate.
div.l: In Fire the Bay-leaves crackle, Poets live
In Death; Hence to the Poet Bays we give.

div.head: 63. To a Citizen.
div.l: Sick of a Fever, thou dost make repair
From Town to Countrey, for exchange of Air,
And going thither, leaving Cities gain,
Thy former Health thou dost again attain:
Returning home to London healthful, poor
Thou dost increase in Wealth: But, as before
Thy Fever comes: Now which is better, try,
Sickness with Wealth, or Health with Poverty?

div.head: 64. Of Labienus, A Self-Lover.
div.l: He solely loves himself, beside loves none;
Loves sole himself, and loves himself alone.

div.head: 65. A Widow.
div.l: Who weds a Widow, buys (as't may be scann'd)
A Garment in Long-Lane, at second hand:
For all such Garments more or less were wore;
So more or less all Widows were before.

div.head: 66. Pyramus and Thisbe.
div.l: A fatal wall us parted: O how near
How far asunder we two lovers were.

div.head: 67. To Pollux, a Client.
div.l: Thy Suit depends in law: Better suspend
Than it should long depend: Pay, there's an end.

div.head: 68. Hot Cold.
div.l: Women, though cold, their lovers yet inflame;
So Lime in water cast, doth heat the same.

div.head: 69. By my Faith.
div.l: None swear by Love, too many by their Faith:
Yet Jo. Ep. 1. cap. 4. v. 16. that is God, but this no God-head hath.

div.head: 70. Astrology.
Physiology.
div.l: Sublime Astrology soars in the Sky;
And Natures secrets in the Center lie.
I neither of these Mysteries can sound;
That for me's too sublime, this too profound.

div.head: 71. Of Ponticus.
div.l: Thou nothing giv'st, but dying wilt: Then dy:
He giveth twice, who giveth speedily.

div.head: 72. Unequal Conflict.
div.l: His Sword at all Times Matho cannot wield,
But Pontia still ready hath her Shield.

div.head: 73. Of Lands and Money.
To Pontilian, a Merchant.
div.l: All Money with its Interest hath bounds;
But (doubtless) bottomless are Lands and Grounds
Founts better are than Cisterns, Ground than Chest:
Though Cisterns greatest are, and Fountains least.

div.head: 74. Of Fame.
div.l: Fame seldome praiseth good, bad oft proclaims
Freely; from thence, evil the name of Fame's.

div.head: 75. Of Galla.
div.l: Thine Eyes inflame me Galla; Touch me not:
If seeing burn, touching will be more hot.

div.head: 76. Of decrepit Linus.
div.l: Saturn from Saturate, or full of years
Was call'd; thine age now Saturn-like appears.

div.head: 77. A Dance.
div.l: Th' Heart dictates Love, Tongue's silent, Feet advance
Love's cunning meaning in a wanton Dance.

div.head: 78. The Meditations and Vows of Joseph Hall of Cambridge.
