div.l: Thou vowing vow'st, writ'st to be read, blest man,
Who reads thy Vows, if them perform he can.

div.head: 79. Anagram to Priscus, an old man.
div.l: Priscus, thine Hairs were Crisped; Why no more?
I Priscus am, who Crispus was before.

div.head: 80. The Britains Night.
div.l: The Britains with short Night are pleas'd, Juvenal. Sat. 3, 'tis said:
But British Maid no long Night hath dismay'd.

div.head: 81. To Naevia.
div.l: We wish for th' absent Sun, the present shun:
O how our Love in this is like the Sun?

div.head: 82. Of Festus, a Lyar.
div.l: All men are Lyars, Festus will confess:
Then call him man, he's Lyar call'd; no less.

div.head: 83. Of Carpophorus.
div.l: From home he laughs with Lasses which he keeps:
At home, with's weeping wife, dissembling weeps.

div.head: 84. The World.
div.l: Two Worlds are in the World; one undefil'd;
This most defil'd; yet each the World is stil'd.

div.head: 85. To an Usurer.
div.l: The more thou giv'st, the more thou gainst a Friend:
But get'st a Foe, where thou the more dost lend.

div.head: 86. Of Giving and Satisfying.
div.l: Give, crys Laws voice in the West-minster Hall;
Though satisfie saith Law Pontifical:
Lawyers take much, give little; much apply
Themselves to speak, little to satisfie.

div.head: 87. A Wichamite.
div.l: I no Pompeian, no Caesarian,
No Syllan I, I am a Of Winchester Colledge, and New Colledge in Oxon; both founded and indowed by William Wicham, Bishop of Winton, and dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary. Marian.

div.head: 88. Against that common Proverb, (viz.)
The younger Brother is the ancienter Gentleman.
div.l: Adam was first of generous Mankind,
For him his maker next himself design'd:
Then he that's nearest t' Adam's period,
More generous is, and nearer unto God.

div.head: 89. No man hath seen God.
div.l: Dark minds see not Gods might, nor Owls the Light;
These see not day, nor those the God of might.

div.head: 90. An old man is no man.
div.l: A young Man's laughing; weeping, Child and Woman;
An old man dry, both hath unlearn'd, he's no man.

div.head: 91. Of a Saracen Atheist.
div.l: Bless'd Abr'hams Bosome seems a tale to thee;
In Sara's bosome thou would'st rather be.

div.head: 92. Custome.
div.l: Custome and usage seems t' have force of Law:
Now wickedness the ballance down doth draw.

div.head: 93. Of Albinus.
div.l: Merchant Albinus is of all berest,
Goods, Credit; He to lose hath nothing left:
In Love he lost Faith, Hope; All ill did prove;
What's left him now to lose at last? sole Love.

div.head: 94. An Anagram, Gerere, Regere.
div.l: To bear Rule, and to bear, are proper, where
Is Man and Wife: Let Man Rule, Woman bear.

div.head: 95. A forsaken Lover.
div.l: As Tophets Fire is burning without light,
So me thy Love doth burn, though nothing bright:
My Love to thee's like Elementar fire,
It shines, but burns thee not with my desire.

div.head: 96. The punishment of Thais, A Probleme.
div.l: Sith in her former; not her hinder part
Thais did offend, why should her hinder smart?
Whether, because the sin before was sign'd,
The Punishment must therefore come behind.

div.head: 97. Irus his Obsequies.
div.l: The Poor is like a Quartan; not one Bell
For the Poor's tacite Fun'ral rings a knell.

div.head: 98. The Epitaph of Croesus and Irus.
div.l: Under a Marble Tomb lies Croesus, there;
But Irus where? The Poor lies ev'ry where.

div.head: 99. Of Momus.
div.l: That I might love, approve, or praise in thee,
Or that I envy might, I nothing see.

div.head: 100. Unite no number.
div.l: Of Forreign writers, and Britannicks Tone,
I of no number am; yet I am one.

div.trailer: The End of the First Book.

div.head: EPIGRAMS OF John Owen AN OXONIAN AND CAMBRO-BRITAN. To William Sidley, Knight and Baronet. The Second Book.

1. To a Critical Courtier.
Labor, Labos, Englished Labour
Arbor, Arbos, Englished A Tree
Honor, Honos, Englished Honour.
div.l: THese words, the same in sense, but not in sound:
He's wise that with the last of them is crown'd.

div.head: 2. Faith.
div.l: Reason demonstrates God, makes it our Creed;
And by this Reason, Faith is Reasons deed.

div.head: 3. God.
div.l: God all things sees, and yet is seen of none;
Sole in all places seen, unseen alone.

div.head: 4. To William Sidley, Knight, and Baronet, &c.
div.l: Thy sundry Languages, thy skill i' th' Laws,
Arts, Piety, sublime thee with applause.
Thy counsel many, poor thy money have;
Thus Vertue leads the Journey to the Grave.
Live so to Christ, thy Countrey, to thy King,
Thy self, till Angels thee to Glory bring.

div.head: 5. To John Sidley, only Son of the aforenamed William Sidley.
div.l: Thou Janus art, but sole in name, now young;
Thy Father emulate, in Deed ere long.
Thou shalt be Janus, hard 'tis to precel
Thy Father, if thou equal'st him, 'tis well.

div.head: 6. A perpetual Equinoctial, To a blind man.
div.l: Thy Days and Nights are equal; thou canst see
Nor Day, nor Night, Aequators all to thee.

div.head: 7. To Ponticus, an Anabaptist.
div.l: Wouldst keep good diet, for thy Souls Salvation?
Sup oft, wash once in thy Regeneration.

div.head: 8. The Gods of Inconstancy.
div.l: Romans, Vertumnus, Greeks, Proteus ador'd;
What people make not each of these their Lord?

div.head: 9. Wheel-grease.
div.l: Men grease their Axle-trees left Wheels should creak:
But Lawyers must be greas'd to make them speak.

div.head: 10. Of Harpalus, the reputed Father of two Sons.
div.l: The Son, that bears thy name, is not thine own:
But he that bears anothers, thine is known.

div.head: 11. The Creation of Woman.
div.l: When Paul the Gospel preach'd, his language then
Was us'd, Men, Fathers and Brethren. not unto Women, but to men:
O Brethren pray, (but not O Sisters pray)
The Priest in saying of the Mass doth say.
When Moses most exactly doth relate
The things, which God in order did create,
God solely good, who nothing made in vain
Or useless, God (saith Moses) did explain,
And call his Works all good, excepting one,
When he the Woman made of Adam's Bone.

div.head: 12. Of Papinianus and Ponticus.
div.l: He saith he cannot err, and yet doth err;
This that he may, but errs not doth averr.

div.head: 13. Of Tustonus.
div.l: Tuston is dead: Now dead, his Coyn doth come,
Rising out of his Chest, as from a Tomb.

div.head: 14. Of Sin and Punishment.
div.l: The Doctors place Sin with Non-Entities:
Why place they not its Punishment there likewise?

div.head: 15. Of the Moors who paint Angels Black, and Devils White.
div.l: Art cannot Metamorphose Black to White;
But Art roakes White take Black, though black as night.
Divines affirm no Devil can repent:
Satan's not White, then Black's his Element.

div.head: 16. L' Argent faict tout.
div.l: Whence comes it that after so many slain,
English and French each in their own Land raign?
The L' escu. Shield, O generous France, advanc'd thy Van:
L' Angelot. An Angel, England, was thy Guardian.

div.head: 17. Of a certain Drunkard.
div.l: Nothing's more thirsty than dry pratling: Bess-
Thy Wife prates more than thee; why drinks she less?

div.head: 18. Verona, Placentia, Beneventum, To an Italian.
div.l: Few pass Verona from, to Benevent;

Thou shalt be Placent, if Ben-venuto per tutto.
Bene-volent.

div.head: 19. Time, Truth, Hatred.
div.l: Truth is Times Daughter, Hatred's Mother is,
Then Hatred's Nephew unto Time by this.

div.head: 20. Daughter of Time.
div.l: I who Times Daughter was in times of yore,
Am I Times Daughter now, as heretofore?
Daughter of those, not of these Times am I:
Times Daughter's Christ, th' Eternal Deity.

div.head: 21. Wedlock Love.
div.l: No weddings, but much Love's in Heaven above:
On Earth are many Weddings, but no Love.

div.head: 22. The Decalogue, the Lords Prayer, and the Apostles Creed.
div.l: One Love, ten Precepts: One Hope, seven votes:
Twelve Articles, one Faith, Religion notes.

div.head: 23. To Calistratus.
div.l: Pain'd with the Spleen, said I, 's a painful thing?
The Spleen doth laughing cause, doth weeping bring.

div.head: 24. The Sun.
div.l: Three Planets higher, lower three there be;
Thy Vertue, Sol, 's amid the double three.

div.head: 25. A Metaphor.
div.l: Bare knowledge knows not Natures voice; no sound
Of Natures words in Dictionary's found.
Farmers by Figures do their Sense express,
Rusticks their talk with City language dress.
Mans as to words, t' his life doth figures give;
'Tis figur'd all, and, as we speak, we live.

div.head: 26. Christ a Divine, Physician, Lawyer.
div.l: Christ, here on Earth was a Physician,
A Preacher, is in Heaven, a Judge, God-Man.

div.head: 27. Of Law, English-Welsh-French.
div.l:
Di-rect Droit. the French doth say, Cys-raith.
Welsh say Cor-rect,
But Law's call'd Right. Right in th' English Dialect.
Erring's directed, Errors are by Law
Corrected, Laws Rule rules, keeps all in awe.

div.head: 28. Castor and Pollux.
div.l: In Heaven the two Brother-Stars agree;
In Earth, I doubt, scarce two such Brothers be.

div.head: 29. What is deferr'd is not auferr'd.
div.l: Long Life deferrs but takes not Death away;
What differs then, to die this, or next day?

div.head: 30. Venale Honours Apology.
To the Baronets.
div.l: Gold, Honour, Lands, are Goods which Fortune lends;
And what on mans Arbitrement depends:
Health, Beauty, Strength, the Bodies Goods: These three,
And the Minds Goods from Price- from sale are free.
'Tis madness to sell Bodies, sinful, Souls:
Fortune to sell, to buy, no Law controuls.

div.head: 31. Authority and Reason.
div.l: In humane words, not who, but what I weigh:
In words divine, not what, but who doth say.

div.head: 32. Luci-fer.
div.l: The splendid Planet Venus doth adorn
With her resplendent Ray the Night, the Morn;
In Heaven she still waits upon the Sun:
Why then, the light on Earth, should Venus shun?

div.head: 33. Of the end of the World.
div.l: The Worlds beginning, Genesis unt' us
Moses declar'd; could not its Exitus. Exodus.

div.head: 34. To Pontilian.
div.l: Whether two Wives, both good; or one, a bad
Were best to marry with, thy Querie's had?
If I must choose, I then would choose the least
Of both these Evils, one, though bad, is best.

div.head: 35. Love is the fulfilling of the Law.
div.l: Of the ten Precepts keep two, of the two
Keep one, that's Love; it will suffice: This do.

div.head: 36. Devotion.
div.l: The pious people caus'd the Clergy's weal;
Ungrateful off-spring of religious Zeal.

div.head: 37. Of Heaven and Earth.
div.l: Th' Earth's greatest part is hid, Heav'n spreads abroad:
I think that th' Earth's asham'd of Men, her load.

div.head: 38. To Aulus, On Sextus, Of Quintus.
div.l: Me Sextus envies, him I pity, I:
Quintus, who me not envies, I envy.

div.head: 39. Of Pollio.
div.l: Thy Wife thou dost forsake, but why? Before
Thou didst her wed, thou saidst, she was a Whore.
A Pre-contract doth Wedlock break, I know;
But why a Pre-contact should do't, me show?

div.head: 40. Meer trifles. To —
div.l: Thou truly saidst that Whores meer trifles are;
For Harlots skins are always base and bare.

div.head: 41. To banish'd Pannicus.
A Probleme.
div.l: In Exile, free thou liv'st as't were, the while
Thy native Soil did thee from it exile.
Which of these Fortunes gives thee best content?
Freedome abroad, or from home Banishment?
Rather I would (for I disclose my mind)
From home live free, than live at home confin'd.

div.head: 42. The Evening.
div.l: The Sun declin'd behind leaves little light,
So Gods sole back was shew'd to Moses sight.

div.head: The Morning.
div.l: Wee see bright Phoebus shine in th' Orient,
Th' Antipodes on's Back, look discontent.

div.head: 43. Baptism, to the Jew.
div.l: Baptism doth cure, but Circumcision wound;
The Laws wounds are by Baptism rendred sound.

div.head: 44. Heatuontimoroumenos.
Self-vexing.
div.l: While Death to shun, Life to preserve, poor Man
Doth vex himself the space of all his span.
• rute Beasts enjoy the present Life's supply,
Living they live, and when they die, they die.

div.head: 45. To William Sidley, Knight and Baronet.
div.l: Thy noble worth doth Gold, doth Honour merit;
Yet both flag far beneath thy gen'rous spirit.

div.head: 46. To J. P.
div.l: A brisk, wise Wife, that Latine speaks and Greek,
That can dispute in Logick, thou dost seek;
One, that the Major and the Minor takes,
And from bad Premisses worse sequence makes.
One that was vers'd in puny Naturals
While puny Maid, now Mistress of her Art in all's.
One that can render all Opponents mute,
And of all entities can well dispute.
• f such a Wife, so rational, were mine,
• would exchange with thee, though brute were thine.

div.head: 47. On Ramista, bipartite.
div.l: Thou first definest, then what was defin'd
Thou dost divide, defin'st-divid'st each kind;
The whole thou in so many parts dissect'st,
That now thy comment's longer than the Text's.

div.head: 48. To Saint Paul, Of the City of God.
div.l: Thou for thy self, when threatned with the Scourge,
A Citizen of Rome to be, didst urge:
But in the fatal day of final Doom
Wilt serve to plead that priviledge of Rome?

div.head: 49. Christ.
div.l: Christ came into this World, saw mortal men,
Death overcame, returned into Heaven.

div.head: 50. To W. Cambden, Of his Britannia.
div.l: Great Britains Isle, almost forgot, almost
In Lethe's Lake of black Oblivion lost,
In name, in fame by thee reduc'd alive,
Thou shalt in her, while she survives, survive.

div.head: 51. To Perpenna.
div.l: Like a Parenthesis thy fore-head is
Horn'd, Crescent-like: An hard Parenthesis.
An hard Metathesis; Thy Wife too free-
Of flesh, all flesh, doth make all Horn of thee.

div.head: 52. Of Vices and Riches.
div.l: No man doth crimeless live, or Coinless here,
A full fill'd Purse from crime is seldome clear.

div.head: 53. Apology of Death, and the Shambles.
div.l: If Death no Youths, Butchers no Bullocks kill'd,
The World with Fools and Calves would soon be fill'd.

div.head: 54. Eve and Proserpine compar'd.
div.l: The Serpent Eve seduc'd, and Proserpine
Was caught by Pluto's specious design:
Eve fell from Paradise to prejudice
For eating th' Apple which she thought no Vice.
And Proserpine might have escaped Dis,
Had she not been surpriz'd in that Abyss.
Death captiv'd Eve, and Pluto Proserpine,
This, of feign'd Jove, that, Child of Jove divine.
Both took forbidden things, this Flow'rs, that Fruit,
Like Punishments to their like Sins did suit.

div.head: 55. Astrologer and Geographer.
div.l: You two the total World divide: The Stars
Astrologers, th' Earth claim Geographers.

div.head: 56. To Fannia, Noble, Fair, Poor.
div.l: Fann'a, thou-fain wouldst with some rich man wed,
But for thy Poverty canst not be sped:
Though thou be nobly born, of fair aspect,
The sordid Lover Wealth doth more affect:
In Categoricks, substance sole we find
More prevalent in Love, than form or kind.

div.head: 57. Con-sci-ence.
div.l: Love's Verbal now, not regal as of yore;
Belief depends on sense, not reasons score.
Religion scars i' th' Head, not sinks i' th' Heart,
It in the Brain, not Breast doth act its part.

div.head: 58. An unspotted Sacrifice.
div.l: Gods Temple's th' Earth, Altar, the Cross, the Priest,
The Sacrifice, and Sacrificer's Christ.

div.head: 59. Of Mortal and Venial Sin, To Christ.
div.l: Thy Death hath clear'd the Sins men double call;
Thy Cross doth Mortal Sins make Venial.

div.head: 60. Upon in-hospitable persons.
div.l: 〈◊〉 to those houses am no Page, nor Guest,
Whose Gates are to the Thresholds fast, when Feast.

div.head: 61. Another, the same.
div.l: His own, none others let him be that's mine,
Let him be friendly that's my Friend, in fine.

div.head: 62. Suffer little Children to come unto me.
div.l: The wanton flesh doth youth to sin seduce;
Old age in wickedness is more profuse.
Hence I suspect that few (scarce one in seven)
Of old men, or of young men enter Heaven.

div.head: 63. Of Paracelsus.
div.l: She Salt of th' Earth Christ his Disciples nam'd:
Why then that th' Earth is salt have Paracelsians. Chymists fam'd?

div.head: 64. Of Eggs.
div.l: The second Person humane form assum'd,
The third like an Egg-breeding Dove was plum'd:
The great Creator Birds and Fishes blest,
Egg-breeders, not Life-breeders had his Test.

div.head: 65. Of Rome, and the World.
div.l: Old Rome was square, and then the World was round,
The World's now square, and new Rome Wheels hath found.

div.head: 66. Magical Generation.
div.l: If Satan man succumb in Womans stead,
No Child from such coition can proceed:
But if like man h' incumb a Woman, thence
Some monstrous birth may chance t' have Effluence.

div.head: 67. Of Bread and Butter.
div.l:
In Genesis, I Bara, the first Word in Genesis. Bara; Menin the first in Homers Iliads. Bara, in Welsh signifies Bread, Menin, Butter.
Menin find
In th' Iliads; two Welsh words, one by Scripture. divin'd.

div.head: 68. The Age of Moses and David.
div.l: Mans life is Gen. 6.3. six-score years, as Moses said,
And Deut. 34.7. he, so many years liv'd, undecay'd:
King David said, man in his Pilgrimage
Lives Psal. 90.10. This Psalm is called a Prayer of Moses the man of God. threescore years and ten, 2 Sam. 5.4. such was his age.
Each of them liv'd so long, before they di'd,
As each had said; his Death each propheci'd.
He who taught Moses, David, (the Divine)
Their days to number, wills thee Psal. 90.12. number thine.

div.head: 69. Even and uneven Number.
div.l: Each Number hath its mid, odd half doth want;
What's even hath its half, of mid is scant.

div.head: 70. Physicians and Lawyers compared.
To Galen.
div.l: Galen, the feared Tyrants fear thee; Why?
The Life and Death of Kings in thee doth lie.
Physicians next to God, are Arbiters
Of Life and Death; none can their Pow'r reverse.
A Judge may Sentence give of Death (though loth)
Not without Crime and witness, thousans both.

div.head: 71. Of King, People, Law.
div.l: Kings, Shepheards: People, Sheep: Laws, Fodder are:
For sick Sheep, Doctors, Kings, Laws cure prepare.

div.head: Orthography, and Orthodox Faith, To the Hebrews.
div.l: If the Right hand the Right side should decline,
And the left hand the left side: Both disjoyn.
But if the left incline to th' right, the right
Incline unto the left hand, Both unite.
You Jews right Writers, we right Teachers are,
The Spirit's ours, yours is the Letter bare.

div.head: 73. Few are chosen.
div.l: Each, and sole man adores the Pow'r divine;
Each and sole man offends against the trine:
Each, and sole man the Saviour came to save;
Sole man, yet not each man this Boon shall have.

div.head: 74. Of salt Pits. Ambiguous.
div.l: Though generous English have Ingeniousness,
Yet Salt they prize at little, Wit at less:
Though English Salt be white, and Gallick brown;
Yet that French Salt sells dearer than our own.

div.head: 75. Novelty.
div.l: What's new, will not continue new; nor will
A pleasing Novelty be pleasing still.
What new then solely pleaseth not, 'cause new,
But that best pleaseth whence good doth ensue.

div.head: 76. Man, no man.
div.l: Man's born by Nature, man did Arts invent;
Art is mans work, not man Arts instrument:
None follow Natures Rules, by Art all live:
And now mans work t' Himself a Work doth give.

div.head: 77. Authors of Sin.
To Grammarians, Authors of Errors.
div.l: Autor and Auctor you too much confound;
Pythagoras his (a) saying was renown'd.
Th' unhappy Tree produc'd Original Sin;
Whence Adam are; but did not first begin.
The Serpent Autor was, Eve did proceed:
Adam not Beginner, or Author. Autor, Increaser. Auctor was indeed.Ipse dixit; He hath said it.

div.head: 78. Anagram of Diabolus, The Devil.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
Vis, Fraus, Force, Fraud.
div.l: The Devil like a Lion seeks to find
Souls, to devour with force, more fierce than Wind:
He, Fox-like, spreads close frauds, and secret snares,
Surprizing, or by Force, or unawares.

div.head: 79. To Teach and Do, Acts 1.1.
div.l: Preachers good words teach people to believe;
But their good Works more lively Doctrine give.
He preacheth best, whose Words and Works do preach;
Their ill Works hurt more, than their good Words teach.

div.head: 80. Usury and Lot.
div.l: Be with thy Lot content, Usurious gain
Is sinful, with thy Lot content remain.

div.head: 81. Invention of Truth.
To the Dubious.
div.l: Pythagoras ('tis said) when Truth he found,
Lid sacrifice an Oxe, with Garlands crown'd:
Truth now's so rarely seen with mortal eyes,
A Calf's enough for thee to sacrifice.

div.head: 82. Circumcision and Baptism.
div.l: Thou, Christ, wast Circumcis'd, thou wast Baptiz'd,
Though neither thou did'st need; yet both were priz'd:
Sins, which both cannot purge, though joyn'd together,
Why may not I, O Christ, have one of either?

div.head: 83. The Wisdome of Solomon, and of Siracides.
div.l: Wisdomes two Books Apocryphal we call;
Wise men must then be still Apocryphal.

div.head: 84. On Covetous Persons.
Sell all that thou hast, and give to the Poor.
div.l: This killing Letter doth all misers kill;
What, say they, doth the Spirit herein will?
The Spirit wills, what you will not, your store
To give, but you give nothing to the poor.

div.head: 85. Of Sextus.
div.l: Is the Church visible? Thou ask'st: Why? Ours
Is visible, invisible is yours.

div.head: 86. An Exiles Comfort.
div.l: Not banish'd while I live, while Earth doth stand,
Nor exil'd shall I be while th' Earth's call'd Land:
When dead, exil'd from Earth I shall at rest
In Heaven be blessed among the blest.

div.head: 87. Man, an Hunter, Fisher, Fowler.
div.l: I hunt for Riches, Fowl for Praise and Honour,
I Fish for Mysteries: Would know their Donor.
While Fool, I strive to know, Proud, Honours crave,
Sordid seek Wealth, I travel to my Grave.

div.head: 88. Of the same.
div.l: The Dog hunts on the Ground, Fish swim in Seas,
The winged Birds poys'd are in th' Air at case,
A wise man Fish-like sounds things hid-profound;
Proud men soar Bird-like, covetous hunt like hound.

div.head: 89. Foot-mens Comfort.
div.l: An Horse int' Heaven did not Castor bear,
Nor rode Triptolemus in's Chariot there:
Heav'ns way's strait-narrow, Foot-men travel it;
The broad way's most for Horse and Chariot fit.

div.head: 90. Of Wax.
div.l: I trebly useful am, for Church, Laws, Health:
I bring Divines, Physicians, Lawyers, Wealth.

div.head: 91. Of a certain Fair Fickle Woman.
div.l: The King of Stars thee decks, the Queen directs
The Sun thy Face, the Moon thy Breast aspects.

div.head: 92. Of the Soul and Body.
A Probleme.
div.l: The Greeks their Slaves did Bodies call, because
The Soul's free from the servile Bodies Laws:
A Lord's the Bodies Lord, a King's its King,
But not the Souls: From God Souls solely spring.
Bodies begotten are; But Souls divin'd,
Deduce from God their unbegotten kind.

div.head: 93. Of Christs Miracles.
To one incredulous.
div.l: Thy Faith's not great, wonders thou canst do none;
Nor hast thou Faith to credit what are done.

div.head: 94. The old Testament.
div.l: A Testament, while the Testator lives,
Is of no force, invalid, nothing gives:
Yet Gods word's call'd th' old Testament: But why?
Sith God, who did ordain it, cannot die.

div.head: 95. The New Testament.
div.l: This was of Christ call'd the new Testament,
By few first, now by general consent:
Yet not a letter of this Book was writ,
While the Testator liv'd t' attestate it.

div.head: 96. All things are full of Errors. Cic.
div.l: Physicians are sick, Lawyers mistake,
Many Divines pass to th' infernal Lake.

div.head: 97. Against all Nations.
div.l: One only God, one man did make on Earth;
One man, once made, to many Gods gave Birth.

div.head: 98. On Atheists.
div.l: Fear first taught to fear God: But now, alas,
The fear of God without all fear doth pass.

div.head: 99. To his Mecaenas, William Sidley, &c.
div.l: Who to thee wisheth not old Nestors years,
Would wishes serve, before thou climb the Sphears?
I wish thee not more years, one year wish I,
I wish thee Plato's year, before thou die.

div.head: 100. On Cotta, a poor and foolish writer.
div.l: Thou sayst thou wantst new Clothes; That's true, I grant:
But I think, rather, thou new Wit dost want.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Book.

div.head: EPIGRAMS OF John Owen AN OXONIAN AND CAMBRO-BRITAIN. To his Mecaenas, Roger Owen, Knight. The Third Book.
1. To Roger Owen, his Mecaenas.
div.l: IT is thy Vertue, Vertue to propose
To be thy Study, this thy Judgement chose:
Where thou most Vertue find'st, thou lov'st it there,
While thou with the most vert'ous art Compeer.

div.head: 2. To Ponticus, Sound-unsound.
div.l: In health and wealth thou dost with Pride abound:
But, when thou shalt be sick, thou wilt be sound.

div.head: 3. What a Clock is't?
div.l: Death creeps on Life, and Age on youth: The while
'Tis ask'd, What is't a Clock? Hours us beguile.

div.head: 4. Bacchus his Deifying.
div.l: Wine Truth doth speak, doth secret things display;
Dry Souls are silent, moyst things open lay:
Wine hearts doth open; Rhenish Wine descries
The Reins; Who Bacchus then a God denies?

div.head: 5. Of silent Labienus.
div.l: If wise, th' art foolish not to speak; but if
A Fool (as th' art) it is thy Wisdome chief.

div.head: 6. Faith in Wax.
div.l: Without or Wax or Seal men once lent money;
But now without them both none will lend any.

div.head: 7. To Firmicus. Of the seven Planets.
div.l: The Sun's like Gold, the Moon shews Silvers smile;
Venus like Coppress (Cyprus was her Ile)
Quick-silver'd Mercury; stern Mars strikes dead
With fatal Steel; Jove's Time, and Saturn Lead.
The last five of the seven take to thee:
One Sun's enough, one Moon's enough for me.

div.head: 8. Of a certain Niggard.
div.l: Verses can from the Skies deduce the Moon,
As soon as from thy Purse produce one Boon.

div.head: 9. Wedlocks Primacy.
div.l: The man by day, by night the feminine
Bears rule: So Sun and Moon alternate shine.

div.head: 10. Of a certain Woman.
div.l: Thine Head wears Feathers, Corks thy Feet up rear:
From Head to foot thy lightness doth appear.

div.head: 11. Faith.
div.l: I see the Stars, the Pole's imaginary;
Eyes view the Skies, but Faith to God doth carry.

div.head: 12. To Thomas, Baron of Ellesmer, Chancellour of England, &c. 1612.
div.l: Thou late one Son, one-only Daughter late
Hast lost, yet hast one Son preserv'd from fate:
He of the three like John, sole Son to thee;
Summest of all, the Sum of all the three.

div.head: 13. Contempt of the World.
div.l: Wilt live an happy life? Thy Life contemn:
He wretched lives, whose life unt' him's a Jem.

div.head: 14. To Robert Cary, Viscount Rochester, and Henry Danvers, Baron of Dantesay, &c.
div.l: Five Jacobines you gave me, even then
When I five Distichs gave you from my pen.
I merit not your Love, nor Gifts; by which
(If so dear were the rest) I might be rich.

div.head: 15. To his Friend, A Batchelor.
div.l: Dost burn with lust? 'Tis sin: Espouse a Bride;
The flesh will be the better mortifi'd.

div.head: 16. Of Baldinus.
div.l: He Books unworthy light, to Light brought forth:
Yet Books deserving Fire, else nothing worth.

div.head: 17. The Decalogue and Creed.
div.l: Why's my Belief, than Life, bound more unto?
'Cause 'tis more easie to believe than do.

div.head: 18. Knowledge and Charity.
div.l: I must know two things, two things love must I,
God and my Self, God and my Neighbour by.

div.head: 19. Of Tythes. To the Laitie.
div.l: What Fruit comes hence, best fruit's beyond compute,
After the Ninth, before th' Eleventh Fruit:
How good is God? who takes not for his due
More than the tenth, but gives the tenth to you.

div.head: 20. Of God and the World.
div.l: This World in God exists, God is not here:
We are i' th' World, O would in God we were.

div.head: 21. The Right of Tythes and First-Fruits.
div.l: God is the First and Last; most justly then
The First-fruits and the Tythes he claims of men.

div.head: 22. Faith, Hope, and Charity.
div.l: Sole Love with us doth Heaven penetrate,
Faith, Hope are useless; Both within that Gate.
There's nothing to believe, all's in our Eine;
Nothing to Hope for, for w' injoy the Trine;
Love's ever there, Love after Death's alive,
While God himself in Heaven doth survive.

div.head: 23. Of Polydorus.
div.l: Clos'd in a Chest, as dead, he money keeps;
Quick-silver 'tis not, 'tis or dead, or sleeps.

div.head: 24. To my self.
div.l: Owen, the Printer sought thy Book to buy,
The price thou ask'st, he gave it readily.
The Book is printed, and thou buyest it;
Owretched man, thou sell'st and buy'st thy Wit.

div.head: 25. Of one Uxorious.
div.l: Thou sitt'st at Stern, but thee thy Boat doth guide;
Which Pinnace-like thee bears with Wind and Tide.

div.head: 26. Of Husband and Wife.
Two in one Flesh.
div.l: If Love unite not Hearts, espous'd together,
Both of them are not one, but two are either.

div.head: 27. Man Solar.
div.l: The Sun contrary to the Globe doth run:
Let then mans course of Life be like the Sun.

div.head: 28. Of Sylvanus.
div.l: The force of's wit is fi'ry, Sylvan says;
And thence concludes, that Fire doth nothing raise.

div.head: 29. London.
div.l: The barren City fruits converts to dung;
The fertile Fields turn Dung to fruits e're long:
Thou debtor art for Food and Life to th' Clown;
He debtor is for compost to thy Town.

div.head: 30. To his Friend and Kinsman Theodore Prise, Theologer.
div.l: In things uncertain thou my certain Friend
Hast been, and still to be so dost intend:
What words profess, thy Deeds express, I grant;
Thy life to th' vocal tongue is consonant.

div.head: 31. Of Atheists and (a) Polytheists.
div.l: The poor his wants, as many Gods doth fear;
Rich Averice doth wish no Gods there were.
Poor Penury sins less than Plenty doth;
That thinks on Gods, but this t' have God is loth. Many Gods.

div.head: 32. Solicitude. To Ponticus.
div.l: By day, by night thy Wife with clamours fills
Thine Ears, and with solicitude thee kills:
What cure is there from this thee to secure?
In Solitude thou mayst be safe and sure.

div.head: 33. Fides, Amor; Spes. F A S.
div.l: Faith, Hope, and Love's the way to scale the Sky,
Without these three no man can soar so high.
Hope on the left, Faith is on Love's right hand;
Love, the chief Vertue, in the midst doth stand.

div.head: 34. To the Learned and Judicious Knight, Roger Owen.
div.l: Thou mayst seem to be young (most learn'd) to some,
If either I were Deaf, or thou wert Dumb:
None will thee young, unless he's Deaf, suppose;
Nor old, unless he doth his Eye-lids close.

div.head: 35. Eight.
div.l: The Saviour of the world twice four did bless;
And Noah's saving Ark sav'd eight; no less.

div.head: 36. Of mans Primacy. A Probleme.
div.l: Why did the Lord from Adam, Eve create?
Because with him she should not b' adaequate.
Had she been made of Earth, she would have deem'd
Her self his Sister, and his equal seem'd.

div.head: 37. Conjux. Man and Wife.
div.l: Sith Wives their Husbands subjects are: Then why
Doth Conjux Wife and Husband signifie?
Why doth this Word Conjux conioyn them, when
Wives most perverse, are most averse to men?

div.head: 38. Epigram.
div.l: We, that have fancies t' Epigrammatize,
Can out of any Wood make Mercuries:
I'm vers'd in Words, as Galenist in Herbs;
He's master of his Herbs, I of my Verbs.

div.head: 39. Of Paula, a most lectick Woman.
div.l: Dost wonder, why th' art call'd most lect? 'Tis soon
Resolv'd, because thou sleep'st in Bed. Lect till Noon.

div.head: 40. Of a certain litigious Lawyer.
div.l: Wert not cause-maker thou, thy need to serve,
Thou, no cause-pleader, might'st for hunger starve.

div.head: 41. Scripture Reading.
div.l: The Thief, the Traveller are arm'd with Sword;
Phanaticks, Catholicks, all read Gods word.

div.head: 42. To John Williams, a Cambro-Britan, Dr. in Divinity, Principal of Jesus Colledge in Oxford.
div.l: Thou dost the Scriptures search, both old and new;
Thou Janus art, before-behind do'st view.

div.head: 43. To John Williams, a Cambro-Britan, a Divine, and fellow of St. Johns Colledge in Cambridge
div.l: Ingenious youth, do not thy Talent hide,
The Cambrians Honour shall by thee abide.

div.head: 44. To John Williams, a Cambro-Britan, the Kings Goldsmith in London.
div.l: Thy civil wit doth more than civil seem;
Thee wiser than a Citizen I deem.

div.head: 45. To all those three.
div.l: You three my Kinsmen are, and each my Friend,
Three Johns, and I your John am to mine end.

div.head: 46. To the Creditor.
div.l: Thy Debtor is thy Servant, he, that pays
Thy Friend, thy Master Payment that gainsays.

div.head: 47. Truth in the deep. To one painted.
div.l: False things appear, Truth's hid; 'Tis seen in thee;
Thy Face is painted, thy facts tainted be.

div.head: 48. Of Phyllis.
div.l: Thou tak'st, but wilt not Gratis give a kiss;
Thy Gift not grateful, but ingrateful is.

div.head: 49. Gravity and Levity.
div.l: Though light and pond'rous things are oppos • te,
I would not have mine head too grave, too light:
Ills opposite I hate: I would not have
My Wife to be too light, nor yet too grave.

div.head: 50. Of a Pratler, sick with the Cholick.
div.l: Thy Tongue is loose, thy Body close; Both ill:
With Silence this, with Loquence that doth kill.

div.head: 51. Of Theologaster, a Sophister.
div.l: What is thy knowledge without Goodness? Vain.
Cease then to know much; rather Goodness gain.

div.head: 52. Action and Passion.
div.l: Who doth much ill, shall suffer much for it;
But who much suffers, doth less ill commit.

div.head: 53. Repentance and Reminiscence.
div.l: I wretch am griev'd when I recount my sins;
But, when I count my suff'rings, Joy begins.

div.head: 54. The Damned.
div.l: Thy sad Fate's like Decembers 'leventh Ray;
A long night follows thy short-cloudy Day.

div.head: 55. The Blessed.
div.l: Like Junes eleventh Day thy Fate shines bright,
A long-long day succeeds thy short-short Night.

div.head: 56. Foelix and Festus.
div.l:
And Foelix was Unhappy.
infoelix, worst of all.

div.head: 57. Democritus and Heraclitus.
div.l: This wept for the then times Defaults, and Crimes;
That laughed at the Follies of the times.
Mortals will still be foolish, wretched, frail;
That this may laugh, that ever may bewail.

div.head: 58. Always the same.
div.l: Let Faith, Hope, Charity be still the same;
The same thy Wit, still kept within its frame.

div.head: 59. Of ignorant-arrogant Linus.
div.l: Thee, double ignorance doth captivate,
Thou nothing know'st, and know'st not that thy state.

div.head: 60. Of the Poet Maevius.
div.l: Non-Entities and Evil, like we call;
Thou mak'st, though many Verses, none at all.

div.head: 61. Helena and Penelope.
div.l: Fame hath fair Helen mounted to the Skyes;
Glory Penelope doth Eternize.
Penelop's-Helen's Names shall never die:
Because this would, that would not falsifie.

div.head: 62. Of Life.
div.l: Nature mans life, as Spiders Webs, doth weave;
Each Labour's long, apt to decay-deceive.

div.head: 63. Of Paula.
div.l: Thou with thy Bodies use, with usury
Thine Husband trades; He this, thou that, dost ply.

div.head: 64. Of a Covetous Miser.
div.l: To number, add, or multiply thy store,
'Tis nothing; but divide, thou shalt have more.

div.head: 65. Verity and Vertue.
div.l: Never so few, who now learn well to live;
Never so many, who good Doctrine give:
Many, these times, the ways of Faith display;
But they who taught the ways, taught not the way.

div.head: 66. Modern Writers.
div.l: We carp at former Works, and Words; yet we
Now writers, but the formers Echoes be.

div.head: 67. The Worlds three Rulers.
div.l: Let the Divine be sage, to b' all unt' all;
The Lawyer wise, Physician literal.

div.head: 68. The Authors Vote.
div.l: I wish not Poverty, nor riches great,
Too little, nor too much: Enough's compleat.

div.head: 69. Forbidden Books.
div.l: We covet things forbid, deni'd, desire;
A Wife cloggs youth, a Dams • l sets on Fire:
One, though deform'd, injoy'd, seems fair by night:
Forbidden Books are read witth most delight.

div.head: 70. On Festus.
div.l: I'm to thee trusty, trustless th' art to me;
But why? Thou say'st, th' art next thy self, so be.
Be next thy self; Thou shalt not me be next;
I love not by bad Neighbours to be vext.

div.head: 71. The false Church.
div.l: What Church doth not her self Christs Spouse declare?
How many yet of them but Harlots are?
If the false Church doth not her self deceive,
Christ shall, than Solomon, more Spouses have.

div.head: 72. To Decianus.
div.l: The World, thou sayst, is wicked: True; but thou
Art one of them that makes it wicked now.

div.head: 73. Of Dindymus.
div.l: A Batchelor in Venus Art thou art;
Thou shalt (when Pander) act a Masters part.

div.head: 74. To G. T. 1606.
div.l: Thy Servants Scholar, and his Lord to be,
An Honour is, a Misery to thee.

div.head: 75. Rule of State.
div.l: The common Wealth was once the Rule of Right:
But now new Rules of Right are brought to light.

div.head: 76. Of a certain Cross-wearing Hypocrite.
div.l: Belzebub's thought to th' Cross an Enemy,
Which seeing, he doth turn, return, and fly;
But not from ev'ry Cross: For though thy Breast
Thou cross, yet Satan in thine Heart dost rest.

div.head: 77. Christ's Life and Death.
div.l: For me Christ did, and suff'red many things:
God in his Deeds, Man in his Sufferings.

div.head: 78. The wise mens Star.
div.l: A Star t' Astronomers unknown, was lent
To light the Kings, to Christ, from th' Orient:
The wise men by that Star found Christ, the King:
O may my Star, my Faith, to Christ me bring.

div.head: 79. The Golden Calf broken by Moses. Exod. 32.20.
div.l: The Golden Calf which Aaron did calcine,
Moses destroy'd, made it less Belluine.

div.head:
80. The Triumvirs
Divines,
Lawyers,
Physicians.
div.l: These of the World the grand Triumvirs be:
What are Divines? Divinest of the three.

div.head: 81. To the Histor •• grapher.
div.l: In History speak'st free? That bad may be:
Speak'st nothing false? Silence may censure thee.
Dissimulate or simulate, who writes
An History, must serve all appetites.

div.head: 82. Of the Deluge, and end of the World.
div.l: The wicked World with sinful Lusts inflam'd,
Was drown'd by Water: So those Lusts were tam'd.
The now-new World, in Charity grown cold,
Shall be consum'd with Fire as was that old
With Water: Physick thus makes cures intire
By contraries; Fire Water, Water Fire.

div.head: 83. Debtor and Creditor.
div.l: I owe thee nought but Evangelick Love;
The with Apostolick Faith, I prove, approve.

div.head: 84. Of God and the Devil.
div.l: God would have all men sav'd; The Devil none:
These no mens persons do respect, not one.

div.head: 85. Of Good and Evil.
div.l: Thee Good, shall have Rewards, the Bad, severe
Torments hereafter: That hath hope, this fear.

div.head: 86. Do likewise. To Atta • us, J. C.
div.l: Thou practise must to Theory conjoyn;
Read the Saints lives; do likewise then in thine.

div.head: 87. The Redeemer.
div.l: To thee my Sight, my Tast hath sole relation;
Thou art my Sun, my Salt, my sole Salvation.

div.head: 88. Money's Method.
div.l: 'Tis vertue great, of Gold to get tuition;
Its good use greater, greatest its fruition.

div.head: 89. Of Writers in these times.
div.l: A fatal error causeth fools to write:
Enough they seem to gain, when seen in Light:
While they self-pleasing, rashly write, poor Elves;
They seldome others please, who please themselves.

div.head: 90. A Paradox.
div.l: Though Atheists all descend int' Hell, there roar:
None Atheist now's in Hell, there was before.

div.head: 91. Of Gaurus.
div.l: Thou praisest nothing, all reprovest; see
While thou none pleasest, no man pleaseth thee.

div.head: 92. To my self.
div.l: Owen, would'st know what friends thou canst procure?
By weight, not number count, thou shalt be sure:
The number, and the Finger oft beguile;
Though Love be Fire, it pond'rous is the while.

div.head: 93. Difference between Kings and Tyrants.
div.l: Good-Godly Kings what's Just and Right perpend:
But Tyrants, what they will, command-commend:
A good Kings Treats I prize Tore Tyrants Threats;
This, what he speaks, commands; that but intreats.

div.head: 94. Of a certain—
div.l: Bedlam for Fools, Bride-well for Knaves is best;
To which of these thou wilt thou mayst b' a Guest.

div.head: 95. The Mother Church.
div.l: You be Christs Brethren, I his Spouse; thereby
I am your Sister, call'd your Mother, why?

div.head: 96. Of Sects.
div.l: Five Senses in a man the Sophist finds,
Three Souls: But who can tell how many minds?

div.head: 97. Life in the Blood.
div.l: Moses, the Legislator, did confine
Life in the Blood; In Christ's Blood I do My Life. mine.

div.head: 98. To Thomas, Baron of Ellesmer, Chancellour of England, a Consolation upon the death of Mary, his only Daughter, an excellent Woman, 1612.
div.l: Nestor, no doubt, and old Mathusalem
Saw many Funerals, and wept for them:
Long livers live, oft see their Childrens Urns:
An happy man, unhappy Fortune mourns,
I, of thy Children grieve thy Loss to see;
But glad, that they saw not the loss of thee.

div.head: 99. On a foolish Writer.
div.l: Thy Books eternal are: My vote I spend;
For neither they beginning have, nor end.

div.head: 100. To his three Mecaenates, E. N. G. S. and R. O.
div.l: You strive, still may you strive, which of you three
Should be the best Mecaenas unto me.
This Strife (a strife-less strife) I will foment;
And wish your Emulation permanent.
You by this noble Strife have nothing lost;
And I thereby great profit have ingrost.

div.head: 101. Upon the Death of Prince Henry, 1612.
div.l: Dead is the Prince, bewall'd with Floods of Tears,
Great Britains Hope, his Parents Joys and Fears.
His second no man, but his German Brother;
And, but his German Sister, not another.
A Prince, while living, honour'd, dead, belov'd;
Both of his Countrey, while he liv'd, he prov'd.
While I these things with weeping Eyes perpend
Salt Tears from both mine Eyes like Floods descend,
Reader, believe me, this me so doth touch,
That I can speak no more I weep so much.

div.head: 102. To the Prince his Ghost.
div.l: Thou, living, didst m' an yearly Stipend give;
Lost now, because thou didst no longer live.
Yet, O I wish thou hadst surviv'd, thought
Had nothing gain'd by thy superstity.
Though neither of us now can t' each incline,
Yet who can barr my thanks unto thy Shrine?

div.head: 103. To the same Prince Henry.
div.l: I said Epigram 1. lib. 1. To E. Noel. thou shalt my Caesar be, but I
Must now, alas, Thou wast my Caesar, cry.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Book.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: The British Owen, with his Latine verse,
Is here rais'd up in English from his Hearse:
Here many things of note accost your Eye:
'Twere pity such-so many things should die.
Not, but that they survive in what he writ,
Yet all our English understand not it.
If any thing seem in the Scene obscene,
'Tis wash'd, and here wrapp'd up in Linnen clean;
You need not fear to lodge between the Sheets,
They be perfum'd with Aromatick Sweets.
I wish t' ye all a sweet-a safe repose
By day, by night: And thus the book I close.

lg.head: Epitaphium Johannis Owen in Templo Divi Pauli Londini.
lg.l: Parva T • be Statua est, quia parva Statura, Supellex
• Parva, volat parvus magna per ora Liber;
Sed non parvus honos, non parva est Gloria, quippe
Ingenio haud quicquam est majus in Orbe tuo:
Parva domus texit, Templum sed grande; Poetae
Tum verè vitam, cum moriuntur, agunt.

closer.signed: Posuit Reverendus Pater D. Johannes Williams, Episcopus Lincolniensis, Magni Sigilli Anglia custos.

lg.head: This Epitaph thus Englished.
lg.l: Thy Statue, Stature, thine Estate, thy Book,
All little, great Men yet on this do look:
Nor is thine Honour, or thy Glory small,
For greater wit than thine, is not at all:
Thy little house in a great Temple lies,
A Poet lives not truly till he dies.
